VIA ELECTRONIC FILING 
The Honorable Megan McKenzie 
Office of Administrative Hearings 
600 North Robert Street 
St. Paul, MN 55164-0620 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE 
by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure 
Partners  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339  
Dear Judge McKenzie: 
On behalf of ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power, as well as Canada Pension 
Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”), 
attached please find the Direct Testimony of the following witnesses: 
 Jennifer J. Cady – Policy and Overall Support;  
 Jeffery J. Scissons – Terms of the Acquisition;  
 Joshua D. Taran – Capital Needs and Credit Ratings;  
 Colin B. Anderson – Affiliate Interests and Post-Merger Cost Accounting;  
 Joshua J. Skelton – Operations;  
 Laura E. Krollman – Commitments to Employees;  
 Jonathan Bram – GIP Introduction and Acquisition Support;  
 Andrew Alley – CPP Investments Introduction and Acquisition Support;  
 Ann E. Bulkley – Cost of Capital Development for Private Companies;  
 Ellen Lapson – Corporate Separateness and Ring-Fencing; and 
 John D. Quackenbush – Access to Capital  
Please contact me if you have any questions. 
The Honorable Megan McKenzie 
December 12, 2024 
Page 2 
  
   
 Sincerely, 
Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP 
Elizabeth M. Brama

Additional Info: Cady Direct - Policy and Overall Support
content:
Direct Testimony and Schedule  
Jennifer J. Cady  
   
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
 
State of Minnesota  
 
 
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No . E015/PA -24-198 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
POLICY  AND OVERALL SUPPORT  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 12 , 2024 
 
 
TABLE OF CONTENTS  
 
Page  
 
 -i- OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  
 I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS ................................ .............................  1

B. Description of the Acquisition  13 
Q. Please describe the nature of the proposed Acquisition.  14 
A. Today, ALLETE is a publicly traded investor -owned utility, meaning ownership of the 15 
Company and its assets is distributed among many investo rs who own shares of stock 16 
in ALLETE. Shareholders are able to  purchase and sell company stock in the public 17 
market at any time. Shareholders invest in the Company by purchasing stock  and expect 18 
a return, or profit, on their investment.  This profit is received through a combination of 19 
an increasing  value in their purchased stock and from receipt of a dividend, or payment , 20 
made to shareholders based on the Company’s profit.  Through this proposed 21 
Acquisition, ALLETE will remain an investor -owned utility but will be privately held 22 
by two investors rather than many shareholders  investing through the publicly traded 23 
stock market. Minnesota Power  will also remain a public utility ,3 and the Commission’s 24 
jurisdiction over the Minnesota Power utility remains unchanged by this Acquis ition.  25 
 26 
 
3 At a high level, Minn. Stat. § 216B.02, subd. 4 defines a public utility as “ persons, corporations, or other legal 
entities, their lessees, trustees, and receivers, now or hereafter operating, maintaining, or controlling in this state 
equipment or facilities for furnishing at retail natural, manufactured, or mixed gas or electric s ervice to or for the 
public or engaged in the production and retail sale thereof  . . . .”

Cady Direct and Schedule  Q. Why does a public utility need investors?  1 
A.  Public utilities provide essential services needed by every individual, business, and 2 
institution in society, and have a responsibility to ensure services are available and 3 
reliable . Given the nature of the business of generating and distributing electricity to 4 
customers , utilities require a significant amount of infrastructure and are therefore 5 
capital -intensive. Accordingly, utilities require steady funding to finance upgrades and 6 
modernization of  aging infrastructure, build  out of  new infrastructure , and operat ion of 7 
the business . Electric utilities raise capital through debt and equity (money invested by 8 
shareholders) to fund investments in infrastructure, like transmission lines or renewable 9 
energy projects. Once  a project is  operational, the utility requests rate recovery of those 10 
approved costs from customers through mechanisms like a general rate case or cost 11 
recovery rider. Ther efore, investors are essential to provide the up -front capital needed 12 
to operate  the utility prior to customers paying for projects after rate recovery is 13 
approved by the regulator. Funding capital -intensive infrastructure projects in this way 14 
– through investors who provide up -front capital to fund project development and 15 
delivery – allows utilities to recover  costs from  customers  over a longer period of time , 16 
mitigating the rate impact of large investments.   17 
 18 
Q.  What will change  as a result of this Acquisition?  19 
A.  As a result of the Acquisition, Minnesota Power will have secured reliable access to the 20 
equity capital required to fund the investments needed for the clean energy transition. 21 
Minnesota Power will also have equity investors who are directly aligned with the 22 
Company’s strategy and invested for the long term, as contrasted to the public markets  23 
which are driven by quarter -to-quarter results . The Acquisition will not result in 24 
negative impacts for customers or on Minnesota Power’s ability to provide safe and 25 
reliable service. As discussed by Company Witness Scissons and Partner Witness es 26 
Alley and  Bram, c ertain investor relations and governance structures  will change after 27 
the Acquisition has closed.  28 
 29 
Q. What will not change as a result of this Acquisition?  30

C. Goals and Benefits of the Acquisition  11 
Q. What is the overall goal of this Acquisition?  12 
A.  ALLETE is a diversified energy company; however, relative to its peers, ALLETE is 13 
the largest investor in renewable energy of all publicly traded utilities in the United 14 
States relative to market capitalization. ALLETE remains  a relatively small company 15 
competing for  increasing amounts of  capital in a demanding market. The primary goal 16 
of transitioning to a private company is to enable Minnesota Power to obtain a reliable 17 
source for the significant  additional equity capital it needs to continue and expand its 18 
investment in clean energy technology and systems, including changing transmission 19 
and generation needs, while continuing  its commitment to provide safe, reliable , and 20 
affordable energy to its customers.  Transitioning ALLETE to a privately held  company 21 
would mitigate the risk of volatility associated with seeking significant financing in the 22 
public markets  and would result in long-term investor alignment with the Company’s 23 
current strategies , values, and commitment to its communities and the clean energy 24 
transition . Like other investors, private investors seek a reasonable return on their 25 
investments and a reasonable opportunity to earn that return. However, as described in 26 
more detail by Company Witness  Taran and Partner Witnesses Alley and Bram , unlike 27 
the public markets , private investors have an ability to exercise more patience with 28 
respect to quarterly earnings and dividends , and the cyclical ups and downs of the 29 
market,  due to a focus on long -term investment  strategies , and may be  particularly 30 
 
 8 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  beneficial during times of rising costs  and higher inflation  when utility stocks tend to be  1 
less favorable among stock market investors . 2 
 3 
Q. Why did ALLETE cho ose the Partners ? 4 
A. The ALLETE  Board of Directors  made its own decision to seek out private 5 
infrastructure investors, particularly those with experience in the energy  industry , and 6 
chose CPP Investments and GIP specifically. It was of utmost importance to the 7 
Company to choose  investors who were aligned with its core values and commitments  8 
to employees, customers,  communities , and the climate. Additionally, it was critical to 9 
the Company that any potential partner understand its unique relationship to the 10 
communities it serves in northeastern Minnesota and make commitments  to honor that 11 
relationship.  The Partners are experienced infrastructure investors with a proven track 12 
record and sufficient capital to support ALLETE’s future needs.  13

1.  Federal Energy Regulatory Commission  8 
Q. What is the proceeding in which FERC is considering the Acquisition?  9 
A. The FERC docket is Docket No. EC24 -105-000. The FERC authorization is under 10 
Section 203 of the Federal Power Act (“FPA”) , and ALLETE and the Partners are 11 
requesting FERC authorization for the disposition of jurisdictional facilities from the 12 
proposed Acquisition .  The FERC issued a notice of filings on July 23, 2024 , setting 13 
August 9, 2024 as the comment due date . On August 1, 2024 , the FERC issued an errata 14 
notice correcting and extending the comment due date to September 17, 2024.  15 
 16 
Q.  What will the FERC consider as part of that proceeding?  17 
A. The FERC will consider whether the proposed Acquisition  complies with the 18 
requirements of Section 203 of the FPA and is consistent with the public interest.   The 19 
FERC considers the following three factors in analyzing whether a proposed transaction 20 
is consistent with the public interest: (1) the effect on competition; (2) the effect on 21 
rates; and (3) the effect on regulation. In addition, FPA Section 203(a)(4) requires the 22 
FERC to consider whether a proposed transaction will result in “cross -subsidization of 23 
a non -utility associate company or the pledge or encumbrance of utility assets for the 24 
benefit of an associate company.”  25 
 26 
Q. What is the current status of the FERC proceeding?  27 
A. ALLETE anticipates that the FERC will issue a decision in the docket by early 2025.  28

entities up through the Partners, ALLETE will maintain certain corporate 17 
separateness (i.e., “ring -fencing”) commitments with respect to the parent and other 18 
upstream entities.  19 
 20 
Q. Did Minnesota Power and the Partners make additional commitments  in the 21 
Petition filed with the Commission on  July 19, 2024?   22 
A. Yes. The additional commitments offered in the Petition include:  23 
• Neither the Company nor the Partners intend to change Minnesota Power’s long - 24 
standing practices with regard to contractors. For example, the Company routinely 25 
contractually requires contractors and subcontractors to pay their workers prevailing 26 
wage as evidenced by local collective bargaining agreements and to ascertain local 27 
conditions, work rules , and union jurisdiction. The Company also seeks to deploy 28 
union labor wherever reasonably possible.  29 
 
 16 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  • Minnesota Power commits that it will not reduce the overall scope or resources 1 
dedicated to its affordability programs, nor current processes for residential 2 
customer access to affordability programs following the completion of the 3 
Acquisition.  4 
• Though not required by Commission order, ALLETE will continue to publish its 5 
Corporate Sustainability Report, which contains information related to 6 
environmental, social, and governance issues, including the Company’s efforts to 7 
encourage diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts.  8 
• The Partners share the Company’s support for a collaborative stakeholder approach 9 
that will continue going forward.  10 
 11 
Q. Why were these commitments made?  12 
A. As stated previously, ALLETE chose these Partners because they share ALLETE’s core 13 
values and support the Company’s strategy. Specifically, as discussed in the Direct 14 
Testimony of Partner  Witnesses Bram and Alley , the Partners share the Company’s 15 
view that customers are the center of its business and that serving customers and meeting 16 
their needs is paramount, consistent with the Company’s long history. The Partners  also 17 
recognize the importance of the Company’s ties to the communities it serves and in 18 
which it operates,  and that relationship will be unchanged by this transaction . The 19 
commitments made in the Merger Agreement and July 19, 2024  Petition were natural 20 
extensions of an alignment in core values.  21 
 22 
D. Employee Retention and Attraction  23 
Q. What additional information on the commitment to Minnesota Power employees 24 
did the Commission request in its referral Order?  25 
A. The Commission, in Order Point 3(F), requested  the following : “How will the 26 
acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non -union workforce and do the 27 
protections included in the acquisition agreement adequately protect that workforce? ” 28 
 29 
 
 17 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  Q. How has this request been addressed between Minnesota Power  and the Partners?  1 
A. Minnesota Power  and the Partners are committed to ensuring that Minnesota Power 2 
remains a sought -after employer  and that current employees, both bargaining employees 3 
and non -bargaining employees, continue to feel appreciated and that Minnesota Power 4 
is able to retain its talented workforce. In light of this, certain commitments were 5 
memorialized in the Merger Agreement for full transparency to  Minnesota Power’s 6 
employees. Company Witness Krollman discusses these commitments, and why 7 
Minnesota Power and the Partners sought to memorialize these commitments in writing, 8 
in her Direct Testimony.  9 
 10 
V. MINNESOTA’S STATE ENERGY  POLICY  11 
Q. How does the State of Minnesota set energy policy for regulated utilities like 12 
Minnesota Power?  13 
A. Energy policy in the State of Minnesota is set through a combination of laws passed by 14 
the Minnesota Legislature (statutes), rules, and orders from the Commission.  15 
 16 
Q. Is there  a specific policy governing decarbonization of electric utilities in 17 
Minnesota?  18 
A. Yes. In 2023 , Minnesota passed the Carbon Free Standard  under Minn. Stat. 19 
§ 216B.1691 , which requires electric utilities to deliver a power supply that is 100 20 
percent carbon free by 2040. The Commission currently has an open proceeding to 21 
provide additional guidance on the implementation of the Carbon Free Standard, in 22 
Docket No. E999/CI -23-151. The Commission, in Order Point 3(G) of its referral Order, 23 
requested additional information on whether the Acquisition would impact Minnesota 24 
Power’s ability to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.  25 
 26 
Q. Please describe Minnesota Power’s history of complying with Minnesota’s evolving 27 
clean energy polic ies. 28 
A. Minnesota Power has an established track record as a clean energy leader in the State 29 
of Minnesota, as ALLETE has nationally . Minnesota Power met the State’s Renewable 30 
Energy  Standard , which required electric utilities to generate 25 percent of their power 31 
 
 18 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  from renewable resources by 2025, a decade early in 2015. Minnesota Power is the only 1 
electric utility to have met the State’s energy conservation  goals for 14 consecutive 2 
years. In 2020, Minnesota Power became the first electric utility in the State of 3 
Minnesota to deliver 50 percent renewable energy to customers and today  continues to 4 
lead the state by delivering the highest percentage of renewable energy to customers.  5 
 6 
Additionally, affordability is key , and Minnesota Power’s average residential customers 7 
enjoy the lowest total monthly electric bills5 in the state while the Company offers best - 8 
in-class affordability programs for income -eligible cust omers, including being the first 9 
in the state to move to a self -declare eligibility system for energy assistance.  10 
 11 
Q. How will the Acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s ability to comply with the 12 
Carbon  Free Standard under  Minn. Stat.  § 216B.1691 , as the Commission inquired 13 
in Order Point 3(G) ?      14 
A. This Acquisition will provide Minnesota Power with long -term access to patient capital 15 
that will fund the investments required to achieve the transition to a carbon -free future, 16 
assisting the Company in its ability to comply with the Carbon Free Standard. Minnesota 17 
Power will continue to be subject to all the requirements established by the Commission 18 
and Minnesota law.  Company Witness Taran further addresses how access to capital is 19 
critical to achieving these standards, and GIP and CPP  Investments  Witnesses Bram and 20 
Alley underscore the Partners’ shared commitment to these standards.  21 
 22 
Q. Will the Acquisition  impact or modify Minnesota Power’s plans associated with 23 
the Nemadji Trail Energy Center?  24 
A.  Minnesota Power will remain fully regulated by the Commission , and, as such, all 25 
Minnesota Power resource decisions , like those associated with the Nemadji Trail 26 
Energy Center , will be made through Commission processes like the Integrated 27 
Resource Plan  (“IRP”) , resource acquisition dockets,  and cost recovery proceedings. To 28 
address the Commission’s questio n in Order Point 3(G), the  Acquisition does not 29 
 
5 Electric Rate Comparison , Minnesota Public Utilities Commission ( Mar.  12, 2024 ), https://mn.gov/puc -
stat/documents/pdf_files/Rates%20Data%20Slides.pdf .  
 
 19 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  change this oversight, nor the Company’s customer load forecast  or resource needs. 1 
Minnesota Power intends to update the Commission on plans associated with the 2 
Nemadji Trail Energy Center, along with the associated energy and capacity attributes 3 
required to meet the region’s energy needs, including procurement of energy resources, 4 
in its upcoming IRP, due on March 1, 2025.  5 
 6 
Q. Please describe how the existing IRP Order affects Minnesota Power’s current 7 
Request for Proposal  process for procuring generation resources . 8 
A. The Commission’s January 9, 2023 Order in Minnesota Power’s 2021 IRP  (Docket N o. 9 
E015/RP -21-33) provides instructions for future resource a cquisition procurement. 10 
These include: ensuring the Request for Proposal (“RFP”) is consistent  with the most 11 
recent IRP order and direction regarding size, type , and timing of required resources; 12 
providing notice to stakeholders and the  Department of Commerce upon RFP issuances ; 13 
providing updates on any changes or deviations from timelines ; includ ing options for 14 
both Power Purchase Agreements (“ PPAs”) and Build Own Transfer ( “BOT”) 15 
proposals, and more. Additionally, the January 9, 2023 IRP Order requires that “in 16 
instances where Minnesota Power or an affiliate proposes a project, [the Company will] 17 
engage an independent evaluator to oversee the bid process and provide a report to the 18 
Commission .”  19 
 20 
Minnesota Power follows these requirements relate d to resource procurement and  also 21 
incorporates best practices for ensuring that customers and communities benefit as much 22 
as possible from resource acquisition. These best practices include  limiting risk where 23 
possible, ensuring affordability , and selecting projects that provide the best value for 24 
customers  and have the greatest likelihood of being built, preferences  for prevailing 25 
wage and local u nion labor , and support for  supplier diversity efforts . Additionally, the 26 
Company follows formal internal processes under legal guidance  and with oversight 27 
from an  independent third -party evaluator  to ensure separation of internal development 28 
of project submission into a competitive RFP and t he RFP selection process . Minnesota 29 
Power will continue to follow these processes in compliance with federal and state 30 
requirements and Commission orders.  31 
 
 20 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule   1 
Q. With respect to not only generation resources but also other procurement and 2 
contracting, h ow will the Company ensure that affiliates of the Partners are not 3 
given preferential selection in any of Minnesota Power’s procurement processes ? 4 
A. Minnesota Power’s obligation to follow Minnesota law, including Minn. Stat. § 5 
216B.48 on Affiliated Interests, and Commission orders like the January 9, 2023 IRP 6 
Order, remain unchanged. The  Company will continue to follow all State and 7 
Commission requirements related to affiliated interest agreements, which include 8 
engaging an independent evaluator if an affiliate provides a proposal in response to a 9 
resource acquisition RFP. Company Witness  Anderson discusses additional information 10 
and protections the Company proposes to help provide further assurance of fair and 11 
reasonable business dealings – a longstanding and continuing core value of Minnesota 12 
Power.  Partner  Witnesses Bram and Alley further underscore these same values within 13 
the Partners’ businesses. Finally, the Commission retains final authority to approve, 14 
deny , or modify any new resource acquisitions for Minnesota Power , and to review both 15 
affiliated interest agreements and cost recovery proposals in future regulatory 16 
proceedings.  In short, the Company , in cooperation with the Partners, remains 17 
committed to integrity in business dealings at all levels, and is both bound by and 18 
committed to the Commission’s continuing oversight .  19 
 20 
VI. CONCLUSION  21 
Q. Please summarize your Direct Testimony  for the Commission’s consideration.  22 
A. My Direct Testimony discussed the underlying policy reasons for the proposed 23 
Acquisition of all outstanding shares of ALLETE by the Partners and why the 24 
Acquisition  is in the public interest. Minnesota Power has been a leader in the State of 25 
Minnesota in decarbonizing its electric generation fleet and transitioning to renewable 26 
energy , as evidenced by its ability to provide  the most renewable energy to customers 27 
in Minnesota  today . Minnesota Power has a unique connection to the customers and 28 
communities it serves and  values its employees as cent ral to all we do each day , and the 29 
Company  deliberately  chose partners who share these values . This intentional 30 
partnership with established long-term infrastructure investors, CPP Investments  and 31 
 
 21 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Direct and Schedule  GIP, will allow Minnesota Power to access capital for the investments needed in the 1 
clean energy transition, while removing this relatively small energy company with 2 
outsized risk due to its unique customer mix from the volatile public markets  driven by 3 
quarter -to-quarter  financial results . Additionally, this Acquisition does nothing to 4 
change the oversight that the Commission has over Minnesota Power’s operations, rates, 5 
resource planning , or resource acquisitions. The Company’s obligations to comply with 6 
Minnesota’s energy policy and Commission directives are unchanged by this 7 
Acquisition and, in fact, are supported by this Acquisition.  8 
 9 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony ? 10 
A. Yes. 11

Direct Testimony  
Jeffery J. Scissons  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
 
State of Minnesota  
 
 
 
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No, E015/PA -24-198 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TERMS OF THE ACQUISITION  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 12 , 2024

Scissons  Direct  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and business address.  2 
A. My name is Jeffery J. Scissons , and my business address is 30 West Superior Street, 3 
Duluth, Minnesota 55802.  4 
 5 
Q. By whom are you employed and in what position?  6 
A. I am employed by ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power  (“Minnesota Power” or “the 7 
Company”) .1 My current position is Vice President and Corporate Treasurer  of 8 
ALLETE , Inc. 9 
 10 
Q. Please summarize your qualifications and experience.  11 
A. I have over 20 years of experience in the utility industry with a background in finance 12 
and investments. I earned a Bachelor of Business Administration degree with a focus 13 
on Finance from the University of Minnesota Duluth in 2000. I spent the first ten years 14 
of my career working for Northern Asset Management (“NAM ”), an investment group 15 
that focused on gas and electric utilities. I started my career at NAM as a research analyst 16 
and ended as an equity portfolio manager. I n 2013 , I started my ALLETE career as a 17 
Financial Analyst and have served in roles in Financial Planning, Treasury, Business 18 
Development, Corporate Development, and as Chief Financial and Strategy Officer at 19 
ALLETE Clean Energy before ascending to my current role as ALLETE Vice President 20 
and Corporate Treasurer.   21 
 22 
In my current and previous roles  at ALLETE, I have been responsible for the financial 23 
analysis of various capital projects, acquisitions  and divestitures. I have also led and/or 24 
participated in financial  forecast ing, treasury, debt and equity issuances  and executing 25 
on the corporate strategy of ALLETE  and its family of businesses.  26 
 27 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Direct Testimony and the 
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” i ndicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
 
 2 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Q. Have you ever testified in any other proceeding  before the Minnesota Public 1 
Utilities  Commission  (“Commission”) ? 2 
A. No. 3 
 4 
Q. What is the purpose of your Direct Testimony ? 5 
A. The purpose of my Direct Testimony is to support the portions of the  Petition  to approve  6 
the acquisition  (the “Acquisition”)  of ALLETE, Inc.  by entities under control or 7 
management by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“ CPP Investments ”) and /or 8 
Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) (together, the “Partners”)  that pertain to the 9 
underlying deal structure and the process by which ALLETE sought and entered into 10 
the Merger Agreement . I support th e approval of the proposed Acquisition which will 11 
provide the Company with the equity capital needed to execute its long -range capital 12 
plans, particularly that of Minnesota’s legislation requiring  Minnesota electric utilities 13 
to source retail sales with 100 percent carbon -free energy by 2040 . Specifically, I will 14 
discuss  ALLETE’s approach to the Acquisition, including how ALLETE identif ied the 15 
appropriate partners for both the utility and non -utility businesses of ALLETE, 16 
governance of the utility today and how it will exist after the Acquisition , how investor 17 
relations may change to the benefit of Minnesota Power’s customers after the 18 
Acquisition, and how utility strategy and planning will remain with the utility after the 19 
Acquisition, just as it is today.  20 
 21 
Q. Are you sponsoring any exhibits in this proceeding?  22 
A. Not at this time.  23 
 24 
 
 3 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  II. THE PETITION  1 
Q. What sections  of the Petition do you sponsor?  2 
A. I sponsor the following sections of the Petition:  3 
• Section II.C: Description of the Acquisition ; 4 
• Section III.B.2: ALLETE Applied Rigorous Due Diligence ; 5 
• Section IV.B.1 .f-I, k-l: Minn. R. 7825.1800, Subp. B: Information required by 6 
Minn. R. 7825.1400, items A to J; purchase price and terms of payment; and 7 
other considerations ; 8 
• Section IV.D.1: A descriptive title of each contract or agreement ; 9 
• Section IV.D.2: A copy of the contract or agreement ; and  10 
• Section IV.D.5: Summary of terms of proposals for service/agreement . 11 
 12 
Q. What Attachments to the  Petition  do you sponsor?  13 
A. I sponsor the following Attachments to the Petition : 14 
• Attachment B: Agreement and Plan of Merger ; and  15 
• Attachment L: Definitive Proxy Statement . 16 
 17 
III. SUMMARY OF THE ACQUISITION  18 
Q. How has th e Acquisition  been summarized to date?  19 
A. The Petition summarizes the description of the Acquisition (page 14 ), as well as 20 
providing the terms of the Acquisition in the Merger Agreement (Attachment B to the 21 
Petition) and extensive detail regarding the process leading to the Merger Agreement 22 
(Attachment L to the Petition ). In addition, Company Witness Jennifer J. Cady provides 23 
a discussion of the interrelationship of Alloy Parent LLC (“Alloy Parent”) , the entity 24 
created to be the parent of ALLETE, Inc.,  and the Partners  in her Direct Testimony .  25 
 26 
Q. What was your role in the Acquisition process  pre-signing ? 27 
A.  I was a part of the core ALLETE team from the beginning , including ALLETE Board 28 
of Directors (the “Board”) meetings and the fireside chats  through out the process to  its 29 
completion.  30 
 31 
 
 4 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Q. What were the reasons for the Acquisition?  1 
A. Minnesota Power  is entering into a historic period where the need to upgrade aging 2 
infrastructure and enable the clean en ergy transformation , combined with significant 3 
utility load growth driven by electrificat ion, domestic manufacturing , and advanced 4 
computing , results in extremely large capital needs  and potential financing challenges . 5 
As discussed in detail in  the ‘Background of the Merger’ section of Attachment L  to the 6 
Petition  (beginning at page 41 of 239) , the Company  evaluated the challenges of being  7 
a relatively small energy company with unique industrial customer risk and  outsized 8 
capital requirements , which include an approximately $20  billion capital plan over the 9 
next 20 years to reduce carbon, expand renewables, enhance resiliency and reliability 10 
of the transmission grid, and also to support the Company’s non -regulated renewable 11 
businesse s that bring diversity to ALLETE . The Company determined that finding the 12 
right partners  to help the Company to execute and finance ALLETE’s Sustainability -in- 13 
Action strategy could provide benefits to its many stakeholders.  14 
 15 
After a thorough and rigorous  process,  the Company identified  the right Partners to work 16 
with to support ALLETE as it addresses historic changes  facing the Company, industr y 17 
and the region.  Company Witnesses Cady and Joshua D. Taran provide more 18 
information on this strategy and the capital needs in their Direct Testimony.  19 
 20 
Q. How does current trading of ALLETE stock in public markets (i.e., short -term  21 
trading) impact the Company and the Minnesota Power utility specifically?  22 
A. Short -term trading can lead to increased volatility in the stock price as investors can buy 23 
and sell shares easily – this is true for ALLETE stock as well as any other publicly 24 
traded stock. With ALLETE’s Sustainability -in-Action strategy, which includes an 25 
approximately $20 billion capital plan over the next 20 years  (mentioned above ), access 26 
to available and patient equity capital is incredibly valuable. The majority of ALLETE’s 27 
capital needs are driven by Minnesota Power  and its Energy Forward2 plan to build a 28 
100 percent carbon -free future ; therefore, p artners that have a long -term view , 29 
 
2 Please see https://www.mnpower.com/energyforward  for more information  on Minnesota Power’s long -standing  
carbon -free energy vision.  
 
 5 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  willing ness to be patient around the timing of dividends , and flexibility around equity 1 
infusions will enable efficient execution of the capital plan. Trying to issue additional 2 
shares during a public market downturn could lead to limiting or delaying the necessary 3 
capital spend to execute the Company’s strategy. Having to issue equity annually, and 4 
the risk of the inevitable economic cycles, is something the ALLETE Board saw value 5 
in mitigating with this transaction.  Company Witness Taran provides more discussion 6 
of this issue, which is further underscored by Company and Partner Witness John 7 
Quackenbush . 8 
 9 
Q. Was ALLETE determined to complete a transaction  from the beginning of the 10 
process?  11 
A. No. ALLETE, with direction from the ALLETE Board of Directors , entered into the 12 
process to see if there was an interested acquisition partner  or partners  that valued the 13 
company, employees, ALLETE’s  strategy, and all the many stakeholders  of ALLETE’s 14 
companie s. There was also a particular focus on the alignment of culture and values, as 15 
well as the ability to finance the Company’s capital plan driven primarily by the 16 
regulated utility needs and obligations to achieve Minnesota state energy policy goals.  17 
As discussed in the Petition, ALLETE continually evaluated the transaction with a 18 
stand -alone plan  in tandem with due diligence of the Partners  and are excited to have 19 
found these Partners to help execute ALLETE’s strategy.  20 
 21 
Q. Please explain how the Company  decided  that CPP Investments  and GIP were the 22 
right Partners . 23 
A. CPP Investments  and GIP are two of  the largest , most recognizable infrastructure 24 
investor s in the world , with experience investing in utility , renewable  and energy 25 
infrastructure companies  globally . As discussed in the Direct Testimony of Partner  26 
Witnesses Johnathan Bram and Andrew Alley  and the Petition, CPP Investments  and 27 
GIP understand the extensive capital needs required to undertake large and visionary 28 
market changes, like Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard , discussed in more detail in the 29 
Direct Testimony of Company Witness  Cady. The Company was impressed that these  30 
sophisticated  Partners performed extensive diligence on ALLETE/Minnesota Power 31 
 
 6 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  and its ongoing strategy , and are aligned in transitioning to more renewable sources of 1 
energy, modernizing the transmission and distribution grid while meeting evolving 2 
customer needs. Additionally, t he Partners are focused  on long-term investments  and 3 
are willing to look through short -term market volatility that impacts public equity 4 
markets  as discussed in the Direct Testimony  of Partner  Witnesses Bram and Alley,  and 5 
of Company Witness  Taran . Important  to the Board and management, through many 6 
discussions and ultimately the Merger Agreement terms, the Partners demonstrated that 7 
they valued the existing employees and the company's  culture and understand  the 8 
critical  role the Company plays as a corporate partner in the region.  9 
 10 
Q. What process did Minnesota Power undertake to evaluate the Partner s prior to 11 
executing the Merger Agreement?  12 
A.  As discussed in detail in the  ‘Background of the Merger’ section of Attachment L in the 13 
Petition, the initial screening3 was performed by J.P. Morgan,  one of the largest and 14 
most experienced investment banks in the industry. The initial criteria centered on th e 15 
prospects ’ interest and perceived  value regarding  investing in small -cap utilities  along 16 
with the ability to fund a large go -forward capital plan. As the process progressed  17 
through fireside chats and management presentations , discussions evolved to confirm  18 
alignment with the ALLETE  values and strategy  and the capital investment needed to 19 
fund execution , followed by commitments  to the region, employees, customers, 20 
regulators and the environment . The competitive process was driven by ALLETE  as a 21 
whole  with cle ar goals in mind and all stakeholders considered .   22 
 23 
Q. Despite these considerations, did ALLETE also consider as an alternative 24 
continuing to operate as a wholly separate, publicly -traded entity?  25 
A. Yes.  As an alternative to partnering with investors dedicated to long -term investments 26 
and results in the energy sector, the Company always considered the possibility of 27 
continuing in its current, publicly -traded form. This analysis was referred to as the 28 
“stand -alone” plan, which is referenced in the  “Background  of the Merger”  in the 29 
 
3 As discussed in the Definitive Proxy Statement (Attachment L to the Petition), other potential investors were also 
reviewed prior to focusing the inquiry on the Partners.  
 
 7 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Definitive Proxy Statement (Attachment L of the Petition ). More specifically, the stand - 1 
alone plan  references  a planning scenario  of the Company that excludes partners from 2 
aiding in the future financing of the Company.   3 
 4 
Q. What was the biggest concern with the stand -alone plan?  5 
A. When the Board reviewed the  stand -alone plan , it highlighted the annual pressure on 6 
issuing equity shares in the public market  (discussed in more detail by Company 7 
Witness Taran) and the amount of Company time and resources that would be required 8 
to execute  on financing ALLETE’s  Sustainability -in-Action strategy . Solely focusing 9 
on financing the investments necessary to  meet Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard 10 
highlighted these risks and challenges. As discussed at pages 50 to 51 of the Company’s 11 
Definitive  Proxy Statement (Attachment L to the Petition) , the plan also identified 12 
potential constraints and risks regarding economic cycles  impacting access to capital 13 
which could lead to delays in projects being completed and a higher cost of capital for 14 
all of ALLETE.  15 
 16 
Q. How were the Minnesota Power utility and its customers considered as part of this 17 
evaluation process ? 18 
A. Customers were central to the Company’s considerations  in this evaluation process . All 19 
Minnesota Power customers, from low -income resident s to large industrial customers , 20 
were considered in this evaluation process, along with many other stakeholder 21 
perspectives . ALLETE’s capital plan is being driven by Minnesota Power and its need 22 
to ensure reliability and resiliency while  meet ing Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard . 23 
Minnesota Power is well-positioned  with existing critical transmission infrastructure in 24 
key geographic  locations  to support investments in the transmission system  that will 25 
support  reliability and resiliency and increasingly clean generation  – not just in the 26 
Company’s service territory , but in the entire region.   27 
 28 
As part of the consideration of a transaction and ultimately selecting GIP and CPP 29 
Investments  as Partners, the Company determined that f inding partners  who are aligned 30 
with the Company’s values  and strategy and have the financial resources to support 31 
 
 8 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Minnesota Power in this critical  transition is a benefit  for Minnesota Power’s customers . 1 
The commitments set forth in Section III.B.4  of the Petition ( which references 2 
commitments  included in the Merger Agreement ) also ensure that Minnesota Power will 3 
maintain its employees , benefits,  and headquarters  as well as continue to be active in 4 
the many communities it serves  and are discussed further in the Direct Testimony of 5 
Company Witness  Cady . 6 
 7 
Q. How w ill the Partners be more capable  to support Minnesota Power’s 8 
decarbonization strategy  than if the Company remain s as a listed company on a 9 
public market?  10 
A. The Partners have the ability to not only provide the required equity capital and do so 11 
on a more reliable, readily available basis  (i.e., without having to complete equity 12 
placements on the open market, in large quantities relative to the size of ALLETE) , but 13 
also to exercise more patience with respect to quarterly earnings and dividends due to a 14 
focus on long -term investments.  This equity capital can be raised based on the Partners’ 15 
clear understanding of the Company’s goals and investments , and a shared interest in 16 
advancing the clean energy transition over the years of progress that will be required,  17 
bypassing the complexities and fickleness of the public markets.  The Partners discuss 18 
these shared interests in the Direct Testimony  of Partner Witnesses Bram and Alley . 19 
Further, Company Witness Taran and Witness  Quackenbush , respectively,  provide 20 
additional analysis on the public markets.  21 
 22 
Q. How does the Acquisition help support Minnesota’s State energy policy goals, as 23 
compared to leaving ALLETE to seek capital in public markets?  24 
A. To meet Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard  by 2040, it is critical for the Company to 25 
have reliable access to equity capital.  Recognizing that ALLETE is a relatively small 26 
company  with significant  equity needs in the coming years,  without the Acquisition  27 
there is no guarantee that the Company will be able to access the capital it needs for 28 
Minnesota Power’s clean energy transition investment s. Seeking financing in the public 29 
markets  at the same time as larger peers looking to raise even greater dollar amount s 30 
poses a challenge  due to t he volatility and short -term focus of public markets in contrast 31 
 
 9 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  with the patient capital from private investors like the Partners, who support long -term 1 
goals. Th e Acquisition is expected to provide more reliable access  to equity  capital, 2 
unaffected by share price fluctuations, benefiting Minnesota Power customers by 3 
reducing capital raising risks .  4 
 5 
Post-Acquisition , ALLETE would transition from a public investor base to the Partners 6 
and their funds , who are  sophisticated, long -term investors aligned with ALLETE’s 7 
Sustainability -in-Action strategy  for all of the ALLETE companies . This choice 8 
preserves ALLETE’s commitment and its success in serving  customers. The proposed 9 
Acquisition will not alter the regulatory authority of the Commission  over Minnesota 10 
Power . As discussed in the Petition, Minnesota Power will remain unchanged in terms 11 
of regulatory requirements, customer profile, system load, employee obligations, utility 12 
infrastructure, financing needs, and alignment with State policy goals.  13 
 14 
IV. GOVERNANCE OF THE UTILITY  15 
Q. What is the current function of the ALLETE Board of Directors?  16 
A. As described in ALLETE’s annual proxy statement ,4 the current function of the  Board 17 
is to provide oversight focused on ensuring that the Company is managed in a manner 18 
that builds long -term value for our shareholders, customers, employees, and 19 
communities.  20 
 21 
The Board takes an active role overseeing ALLETE’s strategy and approves the 22 
strategic direction of the Company, any changes in long -term capital structure, 23 
significant transactions, and any entry into substantial new lines of business.  24 
 25 
Q. Does Minnesota Power have its own Board of Directors?  26 
A. No. Minnesota Power  and ALLETE ’s Board are one in the same . When the Board holds 27 
meetings, it discusses both utility and non -utility business. However, the Board has an 28 
 
4 ALLETE’s SEC Form DEFA14  filed Mar. 28, 2024.  
 
 10 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  obligation to review Minnesota Power strategy , operational and safety performance, 1 
budget, and forecast  and to approve major regulatory filings and project decisions .  2 
 3 
Q. What is the current makeup of the ALLETE Board?  4 
A. As detailed in ALLETE’s annual proxy statement, t he current Board consists of ten 5 
members, nine independent directors and Bethany  M. Owen , the ALLETE Chair, 6 
President, and CEO. The current Board is elected annually by the shareholders as a 7 
voting recommendation included in ALLETE’s annual Proxy Statement (SEC Schedule 8 
14A).  The goal is for the Board to consist of members with  diverse backgrounds and 9 
perspectives  and expertise to direct  the Company on strategic matters . 10 
  11 
Q. What will be the makeup of the ALLETE Board of Directors after the Acquisition, 12 
if approved by the Commission?  13 
A. As explained by the Direct Testimony  of Partner Witnesses Bram and Alley,  and in the 14 
Petition, ALLETE will continue to have its own Board of Directors (the “Post - 15 
Acquisition Board”)  with similar responsibilities and authority to  the current Board. At 16 
least one Director must be from Minnesota, another from Wisconsin , and at least two 17 
will be independen t. The CEO of ALLETE, Bethany M. Owen , will also be on the Post- 18 
Acquisition Board.  19 
 20 
Q. Will Minnesota Power have a separate Board of Directors?  21 
A. No. Once again, the  Post-Acquisition Board structure and role will be similar to the 22 
structure  of the current Board . 23 
 24 
Q. Will the Partners select Directors and how will those Directors be identified and 25 
seated on the Board of Directors after the Acquisition?  26 
A. Similar to current Board members  who are determined by the equity owners, the 27 
Partners will appoint the Directors of the ALLETE  Board . Please see the Direct 28 
Testimony of Partner  Witness es Bram and Alley for additional details on governance.  29 
 30 
 
 11 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Q. How does Minnesota Power currently undertake the development of strategy and 1 
planning?  2 
A. Minnesota Power’s strategy development is a comprehensive and collaborative process 3 
that is led by a dedicated cross -functional team of experts. The team aggregates and 4 
considers key inputs from both within the Company and from external sources including 5 
customer data and forecasts, technology assessments, policy and regulatory guidelines, 6 
energy markets, operational realities and stakeholder input to develop Integrated 7 
Resource Plan s (“IRP”) and Integrated Distribution Plan s (“IDP”) that guide  Minnesota 8 
Power’s  future investments upon Commission approval.  9 
 10 
Q. Are changes to strategy and planning for Minnesota Power anticipated after the 11 
Acquisition?  12 
A. No changes as to how Minnesota Power develops its strategy are anticipated after the 13 
Acquisition. Currently, talented professionals at Minnesota Power develop strategic 14 
plans and submit them to the Board for approval. Following the transaction , strategic 15 
plans will still be developed by professionals at Minnesota Power and submitted to the 16 
Board for approval , and the strategic planning is expected to be developed by the same 17 
teams and individuals because of commitments by the Partners to the continuity of 18 
Minnesota Power’s workforce . Additionally, as further detailed in the Direct Testimony 19 
of Company Witness Cady, the Partners are supportive of Minnesota Power’s 20 
collaborative approach to stakeholder engagement going forward.  21 
 22 
While the Partners have extensive experience with infrastructure assets, t hey do not 23 
have or intend to hire personnel that could replace the Company’s current teams or 24 
expertise. Through diligence of the existing Minnesota Power strategy, the Partners are 25 
aligned and committed to support the execution of the ALLETE strategy with the 26 
existing team. In short, t he Partners ’ role post -Acquisition would be similar to that of 27 
the current ALLETE Board.  28 
 29 
 
 12 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Q. Will the Commission retain all of its authority over Minnesota Power’s strategy 1 
and planning?  2 
A. Yes. The Commission’s regulatory oversight of Minnesota Power will remain the same  3 
and it will retain regulatory oversight of important decisions such as setting rates, 4 
selecting the resource mix, and approving IRPs and IDPs . The proposed Acquisition is 5 
a change in financial investors, but it does not change the critical role of the Commission 6 
or change the Company’s operations.  7 
 8 
Q. Do you expect Minnesota Power and its customers will benefit from the experience 9 
of the Partners investments in other utility and infrastructure companies?  10 
A. Yes, the Company  and its customers may benefit from the scale and expertise of the 11 
Partners , but achieving operational synergies was not a core catalyst for the transaction  12 
as discussed in the Direct Testimony of Partner Witnesses Alley and Bram . Company 13 
Witnesses Cady and Colin B. Anderson discuss how affiliated interest of the Partners 14 
will be managed in competitive resource acquisitions and procurement, respectively.  15 
 16 
V. INVESTOR RELATIONS  17 
Q. How are investor relations and shareholder services currently managed for 18 
ALLETE?  19 
A. ALLETE has an investor relations and shareholder services team that currently includes 20 
three dedicated employees and is supported by the ALLETE CEO, CFO and Treasurer 21 
along with other senior management  and the Corporate C ommunications team . 22 
 23 
Q. Does Minnesota Power pay for any of the costs associated with these investor 24 
relations activities?  25 
A. Yes. The Commission has historically approved recovery of  50 percent of investor 26 
relation expenses through customer  rates in each of its rate cases.  27 
 28 
 
 13 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  Q. Will investor relations activities still be necessary for some time period after the 1 
Acquisition?  2 
A. Yes, once the Acquisition closes and into the following calendar year, shareholder 3 
services anticipates that significant resources will be needed to assist shareholders in 4 
establishing cost basis and other information. After completing work with selling 5 
shareholders, the expectation is there will be overall less time and resources dedicated 6 
to shareholder activities and those allocated savings will flow back to Minnesota Power 7 
customers in subsequent rate cases.  8 
 9 
Q. Will the investor relations and shareholder services team continue to provide value 10 
after the Acquisition?  11 
A. Yes. Post-Acquisition, Minnesota Power will remain an investor -owned public utility, 12 
but will be privately held instead of publicly traded. The Company  will still need to 13 
raise debt publicly and will need to support those offerings and address  debt investor 14 
questions . The Partners will also have ongoing reporting needs and questions regarding 15 
their investment, and it will be the Company’s responsibility to support the new Partners 16 
as ALLETE’s new equity investors.  17 
 18 
Q. What will be the impact to the investor relations and sha reholders services  role if 19 
the Acquisition does not close ? 20 
A. If the Acquisition does not close, ALLETE will need to commit considerably  more time 21 
and resources to the investor relations team. The n eed to raise hundred s of  millions of 22 
dollars of equity and debt annually would require a large expansion of the investor base. 23 
ALLETE  would have to market the Company at as many conferences and meet with as 24 
many potential and current investors as reasonably possible  in North America and 25 
globally . The execution of the debt and equity offerings is taxing on the entire 26 
organization as information is requested and provided, data rooms are established , and 27 
senior management  is responsible for answering questions regarding  strategy and 28 
performance.  29 
 30 
 
 14 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Scissons  Direct  VI. CONCLUSION  1 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony ? 2 
A. Yes. 3

Direct Testimony  
Joshua D. Taran  
   
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
 
State of Minnesota  
 
 
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339

CAPITAL NEEDS  AND CREDIT RATINGS  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 12 , 2024 
 
 
TABLE OF CONTENTS  
 
  Page  
 
 -i- OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339

Taran Direct  
  
I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS ................................ .............................  1 
II. THE PETITION  ................................ ................................ ................................ ............  2 
III. ALLETE AND MINNESOTA POWER CAPITAL NEEDS AND ACCESS  .............  3

 1 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  I. INTRODUCTION AND  QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and business address.  2 
A. My name is Joshua D. Taran , and my business address is 30 West Superior Street, 3 
Duluth, Minnesota 55802.  4 
 5 
Q. By whom are you employed and in what position?  6 
A. I am employed by ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.1 My current position is 7 
Manager – Financial Planning . 8 
 9 
Q. Please summarize your qualifications and experience.  10 
A. I have 13 years of experience in utility  finance. I have a Bachelor of Business 11 
Administration in Finance from the University of Minnesota Duluth. I joined ALLETE 12 
in 2011 as a Financial Analyst. In 2018, I became a Senior Financial Analyst and was 13 
named Supervisor – Financial Planning in 2020. I have been in my current position since 14 
2022.  As the Manager – Financial Planning, I am responsible for financial forecasting 15 
for ALLETE.  16 
 17 
Q. Have you ever testified in any other proceeding?  18 
A. Yes. I previously provided testimony in Minnesota Power’s most recent general rate 19 
case before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (“Commission”) (Docket No. 20 
E015/GR -23-155) on capital structure and cost of capital . Additionally, I testified in 21 
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission  Docket No. ER24 -1473 -000 to support 22 
ALLETE’s request to recover construction work in progress costs in rate base  for 23 
transmission investments . 24 
 25 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Direct Testimony and the 
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” i ndicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
 
 2 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. What is the purpose of your Direct Testimony ? 1 
A. The purpose of my Direct Testimony is to provide an understanding of the basics of 2 
utility financing , credit metrics,  and ALLETE’s capital needs, including those of 3 
Minnesota Power. First, I identify the portions of the Petition of Minnesota Power for 4 
the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP 5 
Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partner s (“GIP”) (together, the “Partners”) (the 6 
“Petition”). Next, I discuss the capital needs of ALLETE and Minnesota Power. Then, 7 
I provide a discussion of how regulated utility financing works in the public markets 8 
and with individual investors. I will also discuss risks and challenges associated with 9 
public equity market s, including how credit ratings  interact with these markets . Finally, 10 
I discuss the potential consequences of Minnesota Power not having access to capital 11 
when necessary, particularly given the need to ensure compliance with Minnesota’s 12 
Carbon Free Standard . 13 
 14 
Q. Are you sponsoring any exhibits in this proceeding?  15 
A. Not at this time.  16 
 17 
II. THE PETITION  18 
Q. What sections  of the Petition do you sponsor ? 19 
A. I sponsor the following sections of the Petition:  20 
• Section IV.B.1.g: Copies of resolutions by the directors authorizing the petition 21 
for the issue or assumption of liability in respect to which the petition is made; 22 
and if approval of stockholders has been obtained, copies of the resolution of the 23 
stockholders shall be furnished (Minn. R. 7825.1400, Subp. G) ; 24 
• Section IV.C.1 : Minn. R. 7825.1700: Petition for approval of transaction;  25 
• Section. IV.C.2 : Minn. R. 7825.1100: Capital structure information; and   26 
• Section IV.D.3 : A list and past history of all contracts or agreements between 27 
the petitioner and affiliated interest, consideration received, and summary of 28 
costs (as to the ownership interest of BlackRock Fund Advisors and Vanguard 29 
Group Inc. in ALLETE) . 30 
 
 3 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct   1 
Q. What Attachments to the  Petition  do you sponsor?  2 
A. I sponsor the following Attachments to the Petition : 3 
• Attachment J -1: July 3, 2024 Moody’s Ratings Credit Opinion ; 4 
• Attachment J -2: May 7, 2024 S&P Global Ratings Credit Opinion ; and  5 
• Attachment M: Holder Position History . 6 
 7 
III. ALLETE AND MINNESOTA POWER CAPITAL NEEDS  AND ACCESS  8 
A. The Company’s Capital Needs  9 
Q. What are ALLETE and Minnesota Power’s capital needs?  10 
A. The Company has a significant need for capital from investors at levels that are several 11 
times the size of historic levels  to continue ALLETE’s Sustainability -in-Action 12 
Strategy, which seeks to decarbonize Minnesota Power’s generation portfolio while 13 
continuing to provide safe, affordable , and reliable electric service to our customers and 14 
communities.  As part of this strategy, ALLETE will need to make substantial 15 
investments in renewable energy, carbon  reduction, grid resiliency, reliability, and clean  16 
energy -enabling technologies in the years ahead. Company Witnesses Jennifer J. Cady 17 
and Jeffery J. Scissons provide more information on this strategy in their Direct 18 
Testimony.  19 
 20 
The majority of ALLETE’s capital needs are driven by Minnesota Power. This is 21 
evidenced by the Company’s forward -looking capital projections . Within the 22 
Company’s most recent Capital Structure Petition ,2 the five -year capital expenditure 23 
projections for regulated operations were over $4 billion and  accounted for  87 percent 24 
of the ALLETE Consolidated  capital expenditures .  25 
 26 
 
2 In the Matter of the Petition of Minn . Power  Under Minnesota Statutes 216B.49 for Approval  of its Capital 
Structure and Authorization to Issue  Securities , Docket No. E015/S -24-108. 
 
 4 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. Why are non -regulated businesses part of the Company’s plans at all ? 1 
A. While the majority of ALLETE’s capital needs are driven by Minnesota Power, 2 
ALLETE has intentionally structured its mix of businesses to be complementary to each 3 
other and to ensure flexibility. Due to the required nature of Minnesota Power’s 4 
investments, regulated utility capital needs are prioritized. In contrast, ALLETE’s non - 5 
utility operations are designed with optionality in mind and to be flexible around their 6 
capital needs. A diverse mix of businesses has been beneficial to the overall financial 7 
health of ALLETE over the years and has helped weather difficult economic cycles.  8 
 9 
Q. How are Minnesota Power’s capital needs determined?  10 
A. Regulated utility investments are identified  as part of the Company’s robust resource 11 
planning process with input from all stakeholder groups. This process  includes  12 
Minnesota Power’s Integrated Resource Plan (“IRP”)3 and Integrated Distribution Plan 13 
(“IDP”),4 both approved by the Commission, and regional transmission planning 14 
processes.  15 
 16 
Q. What types of projects does Minnesota Power need to construct that require 17 
capital in the five - to ten -year horizon?  18 
A. In an Order dated January  9, 2023, the Commission  approved  Minnesota Power’s  2021 19 
IRP, which  set forth a path to reducing carbon emissions 80 percent by 2035 and 20 
included significant additions of wind and solar energy generation as well as energy 21 
storage  resources . The Company plans to submit its next IRP  by March  1, 2025 , which 22 
will address additional resources  necessary to meet the State of Minnesota’s 100 percent 23 
by 2040 Carbon Free Standard .  These are in addition to transmission investments 24 
necessary to achieve these long -term goals, including projects to strengthen or enhance 25 
the transmission grid.  Some of these projects were identified as part of the Midwest 26 
Independent System Operator, Inc. (“MISO”) long -range transmission planning 27 
process , and require long planning and capital horizons to finance.  28 
 29 
 
3 In the Matter of Minn . Power’s 2021 -2035 Integrated Resource Plan , Docket No. E015/M -21-33. 
4 In the Matter of Minn. Power’s 2023 Integrated Distribution Plan , Docket No. E015/M -23-258. 
 
 5 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Additional investments will also be needed for Minnesota Power’s existing facilities to 1 
maintain aging infrastructure , in addition to the previously mentioned carbon reduction 2 
initiatives . This includes investment in transmission and distribution  projects  to 3 
maintain and  expand its system to address reliability and resiliency. Additionally,  4 
investments  are needed  in the generation fleet to meet safety, environmental, regulatory, 5 
and system reliability objectives.  All of these needs are significantly increasing the 6 
Company’s need for capital in the years ahead.  7 
 8 
Q. Why are these investments  necessary?  9 
A. This level of investment is necessary for Minnesota Power to continue to provide the 10 
safe, reliable, and affordable electric service that Minnesota Power’s customers expect 11 
while continuing to advance the State of Minnesota’s clean energy goals. Such 12 
incremental additions in carbon -free generation and transmission infrastructure are 13 
critically important when considering the anticipated transition away from coal 14 
generation at Minnesota Power’s last remaining baseload generating facility, Boswell 15 
Energy Center, and the around -the-clock requirements from the Company’s large 16 
industrial customer base. The Company does not have the ability to delay or defer these 17 
projects given the need to ensure compliance with Minnesota’s 2040 Carbon Free 18 
Standard . 19 
 20 
Q. Can you give an example of h ow these levels of regulated capital expenditures  21 
compare to historical levels?  22 
A. Yes.  Over the next five years, ALLETE’s regulated capital plan of over $4 billion 23 
represents a dramatic increase compared to historical investments, which were lower and 24 
more manageable from an access -to-capital perspective. The Company’s five -year 25 
capital needs represent an approximately 3.8 -times  increase in regulated investment 26 
compared to the historical ten -year average, as shown in Figure 1 , below . 27 
 28 
 
 6 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Figure 1.  ALLETE Regulated Operations – Historical and Forecasted Capital 1 
Expenditures5 ($ in millions)  2 
 3 
 4 
Q. Why does Minnesota Power need  to access capital markets for financing?  5 
A. Company operations alone will not generate sufficient cash flow to fund the capital 6 
investments discussed above . By their nature, regulated utility investments require a 7 
significant amount of upfront capital that is then recovered through rates over the lives 8 
of the assets.  As a result, utilities rely on capital markets to provide upfront capital . To 9 
contextualize , the capital plan for ALLETE’s regulated operations alone represents 131  10 
percent  of ALLETE’s unaffected market capitalization on December 4, 2023 ,6 which is 11 
above its peer group and much higher than historic levels.    12 
 13 
Prior to announcing the Acquisition , ALLETE’s investor relations materials disclosed 14 
a need for approximately $1 billion of external equity over the next five years alone to 15 
fund the over $4 billion  in planned capital expenditures , in addition to significant new 16 
debt issuances and refinancing. This level of  equity is needed to maintain the regulated 17 
capital structure and credit metrics. I describe the debt and equity markets in more detail 18 
in Section III.B, below.  19 
 20
