225$  849 $      3.8xAverageHistorical  Forecasted  
 
 7 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. What challenges would the utility face if it did not have access to sufficient capital 1 
for the clean energy transition ahead?  2 
A. Because ALLETE’s operations do not generate sufficient cash flow to fund its capital 3 
needs, the Company would not be able to make the necessary investments to meet the 4 
State’s Carbon Free  Standard without external capital. Minnesota Power would be 5 
forced to delay investments that are necessary to continue providing safe, reliable 6 
service to customers, at likely higher costs. Even if ALLETE were able to access the 7 
public markets at the scale discussed in the Company’s Direct Testimony, the cost of 8 
such access for a Company of ALLETE’s size is difficult to predict and unlikely to be 9 
reliable, given the ease with which public shareholders can sell stock in small or large 10 
quantities.  11 
 12 
There are several additional risks from attempting to obtain the quantity of equity 13 
ALLETE will require from public markets. First, the amount of time and resources to 14 
obtain equity from public markets is material. Public issuances would require sustained 15 
focus from ALLETE and Minnesota Power leadership over the coming years, limiting 16 
their ability to attend to other important issues. Additionally, if ALLETE is able to 17 
obtain public equity financing on the timelines that it requires, the cost of successive 18 
issuances in a short time period could be significantly higher than historical levels, and 19 
thereby impact customer rates and credit ratings.  20 
 21 
Q. Will ALLETE have difficulty meeting Minnesota Power’s future capital needs if it 22 
remains publicly traded?  23 
A. It is highly likely that ALLETE would have difficulty raising the amounts of capital 24 
Minnesota Power will need in the future without the Acquisition. ALLETE is one of the 25 
smallest public utilities in the nation with one of the largest capital programs, relative 26 
to its size. Additionally, Minnesota Power has a unique risk profile due to the 27 
concentration of sales to industrial customers. The size and risk profile of the Company 28 
relative to other industry participants and in relation to its ongoing capital needs creates 29 
a unique risk for the Company in terms of access to capital. While ALLETE has been 30 
able to navigate the risks of public markets in the past, the outsized and ongoing nature 31 
 
 8 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  of the projected capital needs presents a significant risk that needs to be addressed. The 1 
proposed acquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments and GIP (the “ Acquisition ”) is 2 
critically important to address this risk.  3 
 4 
Q. If regional transmission projects are cost allocated in MISO , why does Minnesota 5 
Power need to raise capital to construct these projects?  6 
A. As described a bove, Minnesota Power is making investment s in regionally cost - 7 
allocated transmission projects. This includes an estimated investment of $650  million 8 
to $750 million in MISO Tranche 1,7 with additional investments expected in Tranche 9 
2.8 From a capital -raising perspective, t hese projects function similarly to any other 10 
regulated utility inves tment . When a project  is cost allocated among all of MISO’s 11 
participants , that simply means that MISO customers will pay their portion of the 12 
revenue requirements over the life of the  project . Minnesota Power must still finance 13 
the up -front costs of construct ion the regulated utility is supporting . 14 
 15 
B. Regulated Utility Financing  16 
Q. How do publicly  traded utilities raise money for capital needs?  17 
A. Publicly  traded utilities  generally rely on debt and equity capital to fund the large -scale 18 
investments in utility assets that cannot be covered by internally generated funds . Debt 19 
and equity investors commit capital  to utilities with the expectation that they will earn 20 
a reasonable return on their investment.  Additionally, utilities can reinvest a portion of 21 
their profits back into the business in the form of retained earnings.  22 
 
7 In July of 2022, MISO's  Board of Directors unanimously approved  $10.3 billion in new transmission 
projects.  The Long Range Transmission Planning Tranche 1 Portfolio  is the first of four planned tranches of 
transmission solutions developed to provide reliable and economic energy delivery to address future reliability 
needs.  
8 MISO’s Long Range Transmission Planning  Tranche 2.1  addresses transmission in MISO's Midwest Subregion.  
As of September 19, 2024, Tranche 2.1 includes 24 projects totaling $21.8 billion and provides benefits in excess 
of costs.   Planning with stakeholders commenced during the fourth quarter of 2022 and is expected to be finalized 
with MISO Board of Directors’ approval in December 2024.   
 
 
 9 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct   1 
Q. What does it mean when one refers to a utility’s debt financing?  2 
A. Debt financing refers to a utility borrowing money from an investor for a specified 3 
period of time. The debt investor provides capital to the utility in return for periodic 4 
interest payments and the return of capital at the end of the debt security term.  5 
 6 
Q. What does it mean when one refers to a utility’s equity financing?  7 
A. Equity financing is when an investor acquires an ownership interest in a utility. Equity 8 
investors provide capital to the utility with the expectation that they will receive 9 
dividend payments and an increase in value of their original investment. For a publicly  10 
traded utility, an equity investment refers to buying shares of the utility company’s stock 11 
and taking on the associated risks. For a privately  owned company, an equity investment 12 
refers to the ownership interests of the equity investor that is likewise taking on the 13 
associated risk of the investment.  14 
 15 
Q. What information do investors rely on to make such investments?  16 
A. Investors rely on a variety of information to determine the level of risk and to analyze a 17 
company’s financial position before making an investment. For equity investors this 18 
includes reviewing company financial statements and ratios , assessing the company’s 19 
historic dividends and potential for future growth , understanding industry trends , and 20 
making comparisons to alternative investment options , among other things. Public 21 
equity investors also rely upon reports from equity research analysts who provide 22 
financial analysis and recommendations of a stock’s value.  23 
 24 
Debt investors  also review company financial statements and ratios  to assess  a 25 
company’s financial leverage, risk, and creditworthiness.  Debt investors also rely on 26 
ratings and r eports from  independent  credit rating agencies.  27 
 28 
Ultimately, all investors rely on assessments of the level of risk associated with their 29 
investment  in determining their expectation for returns . The lower the risk of an 30 
 
 10 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  investment, the lower the rate of return that is expected . In contrast, the higher the risk 1 
of an investment, the higher the expected rate of return . 2 
 3 
Q. What types of investors are drawn to debt or equity investments?  4 
A. Debt investors have priority of being paid first in the event an investment experiences  5 
financial difficulties. As such, deb t investments represent a lower risk than equity , and 6 
debt investor s expect a lower return.  Therefore, d ebt investors often include insurance 7 
companies and banks , as they are drawn to the  relatively lower risk profile and fixed 8 
interest payments.  9 
 10 
Equity invest ors, on the other hand , only have a residual claim on the investment’s 11 
earnings , meaning that equity investments are considered higher risk than debt 12 
investments. As a result, equity investors expect a higher rate of return.  Equity investors 13 
are drawn to the prospect of regular and increasing dividend payments and stock price 14 
appreciation but  must  accept the volatility and risk of loss that is associated  with equity 15 
ownership.  Equity investors include institutional investors,  like mutual funds and 16 
pension funds that invest large sums of money in equity , and individual investors who 17 
buy shares for their personal investment . 18 
 19 
Q. Why do utilities utilize both debt and equity in their capital structure ? 20 
A. Utilities typically fund their operations using a mix of debt and equity to balance 21 
financial considerations and risk management. Debt financing is generally lower cost 22 
than equity due to the lower risk of loss to the investor. While debt capital comes at a 23 
lower cost, it adds financial risk due to the obligation to make regular interest payments , 24 
placing pressure on credit ratings . As a result, utilities seek a balanced capital structure 25 
that allows for just and reasonable rates  while maintaining access to capital markets at 26 
competitive rates on behalf of customers.  27 
 
 11 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct   1 
Q. What changes are expected under the proposed Acquisition  with respect to debt 2 
and equity financing ? 3 
A. The Acquisition primarily  would result in a change in the Company’s equity investors. 4 
Upon closing of the Acquisition, all outstanding publicly held shares of ALLETE stock  5 
will be acquired by the Partners , who will then hold all equity ownership of ALLETE .  6 
 7 
No changes will occur in relation to the Company’s outstanding debt, and ALLETE and 8 
Minnesota Power will continue to secure debt as needed to fund future projects.  9 
Importantly, t here will be no changes in the Company’s operations  or assets as a result 10 
of the Acquisition.   11 
 12 
1. Equity Markets  13 
Q. How do public equity markets function?  14 
A. Public equity markets function to connect buyers and sellers of equity securities. 15 
Companies who are looking to raise capital issue shares to the public through an initial 16 
public offering (in the case of a company first becoming listed publicly) or through 17 
subsequent follow -on offerings in which additional shares are sold to raise capital. 18 
Under this process, the company is selling a portion of the company’s ownership to 19 
investors in exchange for funds. This type of issuance of shares by the company, in 20 
which new shares are being created in exchange for funds, is referred to as a primary 21 
market.  22 
 23 
Once shares have been issued, they can be traded among investors on a stock exchange. 24 
This is a centralized marketplace where buyers and sellers can exchange shares. The 25 
price at which shares are traded is determined by supply and demand . These exchanges 26 
are referred to as secondary markets  and investors are buying and selling  shares from 27 
each other (i.e. , the company whose shares they are trading is not involved in the 28 
transaction).  29 
 30 
 
 12 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. What risks exist in public equity market financing?  1 
A. There are numerous risks that exist in public equity markets , including many that are 2 
beyond a publicly traded company’s ability to control. Among the largest risks is 3 
uncertainty over the ability to raise the amount of equity needed to fund capital 4 
expenditures. This is particularly critical for a public utility with responsibility for 5 
investments needed to reliably deliver an essential service and meet essential public 6 
policy obligations. As discussed in Section III.A of my testimony, Minnesota Power’s 7 
capital investment requirements going forward will be significant , necessitating access 8 
to equity capital at the time it is needed, in the amount that is needed, and at a price that 9 
is reasonable.  10 
 11 
As a small utility with a significant concentration of industrial customers, this presents 12 
a significant challenge to the Company given the scale of equity needs in the future and 13 
the volatility of public equity markets. When the Company needs to access equity 14 
markets, it becomes vulnerable to economic cycles, geopolitical events, interest rate 15 
volatility, and other influencing factors, and is in direct competition with other publicly 16 
traded companies pursuing the same finite pool of investment dollars. The risks of 17 
equity markets are further discussed in the Direct Testimony of Company and Partner 18 
Witness John D. Quackenbush .   19 
 20 
Q. What is involved in a follow -on equity offering?  21 
A. In public markets, a follow -on equity offering is a significant undertaking that adds cost, 22 
complexity , and risk to accessing equity capital. This includes working with 23 
underwriters, marketing the offering to potential investors who conduct thorough due 24 
diligence, and seeking regulatory approvals. Due diligence involves establishing a data 25 
room, management presentations , and answering information requests from potential 26 
investors.  Underwriting and other fees add significant cost to such offerings, which 27 
reduce the proceeds to the company. Additionally, backstop financing is often required 28 
to ensure funds are available i f the offering is unsuccessful in raising the necessary 29 
funds, which adds credit risk. Additional shares  are issued at a discount to the ma rket 30 
price and  have a dilutive impact on existing shareholders, which can push the share price 31 
 
 13 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  down  further . Ultimately, this increases the cost of capital  (and thus customer rates)  and 1 
adds additional challenges to attracting capital in the future.  This is significant for 2 
ALLETE, given the serial need  for external equity . 3 
 4 
Q. What benefits exist in public equity market financing?  5 
A. Public equity markets are not without benefit. They provide a liquid market for shares 6 
to be bought and sold and allow companies to seek investments from any parties who 7 
may be interested and able to invest. However, for ALLETE, these benefits are 8 
outweighed by the uncertainties ALLETE faces getting timely, reliable, economic 9 
access to public equity as a comparatively very small utility with a higher risk profile 10 
and unprecedented capital investment requirements going forward.   11 
 12 
Q. Do the same  risks exist in a structure like that proposed as part of the Acquisition?  13 
A. No. The Acquisition would allow Minnesota Power  to more reliably access equity 14 
capital  without exposure to the risks described for the public market .  The Acquisition 15 
removes the pricing volatility associated with public equity markets as well as 16 
limitations on the amounts of equity that can be accessed at any given time due to the 17 
Company’s relatively small market capitalization.  18 
 19 
It is important to note that  while  the Acquisition de -risks the Compan y’s access to 20 
capital,  the underlying risks of the business remain unchanged . Like other investors, 21 
private infra structure investors , such as the Partners , seek a reasonable return on their 22 
investments and a re asonable opportunity to earn the return authorized by the 23 
Commissi on. Company and Partner W itness Ann E.  Bulkley p rovides additional 24 
information on the impact o f Commission -approved returns on investment s in her Direct 25 
Testimony.  26 
 27 
Q. What benefits exist in the Acquisition -proposed structure for financing?  28 
A. In short, the Partners will provide the equity capital that Minnesota Power needs without 29 
the risks of obtaining the capital from the public market. The Partners are proposing to 30 
acquire ALLETE because they are aligned with the Company’s long -term strategy and 31 
 
 14 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  understand the capital needs associated with that strategy.  This alignment allows the 1 
Company to access more reliable financing than exists in public equity markets. The 2 
Partners not only can provide capital, and do so on a more readily available basis, but 3 
they represent more patient capital compared to public equity markets.  4 
 5 
Q. What do you mean by “patient capital” when discussing the Acquisition and the 6 
Partners?  7 
A. As a publicly traded utility company, ALLETE carries the expectation of regularly 8 
distributing dividends to equity holders, which limits ALLETE’s ability to retain 9 
earnings and represents another burden on the Company’s cash flow. The reference to 10 
more patient capital relates to the Partners’ ability to exercise more patience with respect 11 
to quarterly earnings and dividends due to a focus on long -term returns. Public equity 12 
investors and analysts are often focused on the near term and do not give credit to long - 13 
term growth projections or project announcements.  14 
 15 
In contrast, infrastructure and pensions plan investors by nature invest in core 16 
infrastructure with long -term horizons with the expectation of sustainable growth and 17 
returns over time. Moreover, private equity investments allow for greater flexibility to 18 
re-invest the capital that would otherwise be returned as dividends to public 19 
shareholders.  20 
 21 
Q. Does access to equity through the Partners impact the Company’s access to debt 22 
capital?  23 
A. Yes. Having reliable access to equity when needed will help support the Company’s 24 
credit rating and access to debt capita l. This will allow the Company to maintain its 25 
regulated capital structure  and credit metrics , which will all ow the Company to access 26 
debt capital at a reasonable cost on behalf of customers.  27 
 28 
 
 15 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  2. Credit  Rating  1 
Q. What are credit ratings ? 2 
A. Credit ratings are the primary measure used by investors to evaluate the risk and 3 
creditworthiness of companies . Credit rating agencies make  independent, third -party  4 
assessments of a compan y’s risk and its ability to meet financial obligations in full and 5 
on time.  Credit rating s are assign ed based on various financial and business risk factors. 6 
ALLETE is rated by two independ ent credit rating agencies: S&P Global Ratings  7 
(“S&P”) and Moody’s Investor Services (“Moody’s”).  8 
 9 
Business risk refers to the qualitative assessment made by rating agenc ies and includes 10 
items such as customer concentration , regulatory framework , and size.  Financial risk 11 
refers to the quantitative assessments made by rating agencies , including financial 12 
metrics that measure a company’s ability to cover its interest expense and debt 13 
repayments based on the cash flows generated.  14 
 15 
Q. Are credit ratings  different for an entity traded on a public stock exchange versus 16 
one owned by a limited number of investors?  17 
A. No. Credit rating agencies use the same process and methodology to rate public ly traded 18 
and privately  held companies. As discussed above, ALLETE will continue to secure 19 
debt capital as needed to fund a portion of its capital needs. As a result, ALLETE will 20 
continue to maintain its own corporate credit rating  post-closing .   21 
 22 
Q. How do credit ratings  impact  a utility’s ability to raise capital?  23 
A. Credit ratings play a critical role in a u tility’s ability to raise capital. The stronger a 24 
company’s credit rating, the greater the number of investors willing to consider 25 
investing in the company’s debt and the less the company will need to pay in interest 26 
and fees in order to issue debt  (which in turn reduces the cost of capital to customers).  27 
Additionally, because the income available to equity holders is subordinate to debt 28 
obligations, the weakening of a company’s credit worthiness also increase s the cost of 29 
equity.  30 
 31 
 
 16 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. What role do current cost recovery ride rs play in credit ratin g? 1 
A. Current  cost recovery riders benefit cash flow  and thus credit metrics by providing an 2 
equity and debt return on the Construction Work in Progress (“CWIP”) during 3 
construction and recovery of revenue requirements between general rate cases. It is 4 
important to note , however, that they are not designed to recover the full up -front capital 5 
costs of a project  during construction . The utility must finance the up -front capital costs 6 
and recover the related revenue requirements over the life of the project  regardless of 7 
whether project costs are recovered through a cost recovery rider or rate case.  8 
 9 
Q. Has the announcement of the Acquisition had any impact on ALLETE’s credit 10 
rating?  11 
A. Upon announcement of the Acquisition, both S&P and Moody’s published updated 12 
credit reports on ALLETE affirming ALLETE’s current credit rating. Moody’s report 13 
included its view that the Acquisition was credit neutral and it does not expect material 14 
changes in the Company’s credit profile post -closing, reinforcing the fact that 15 
underlying risks of the business are unchanged by this Acquisition , while it does address 16 
the risk of accessing capital in the future. S&P affirmed its ratings on ALLETE ; 17 
however, consistent with S&P’s  treatment of similar transactions, it did revise its 18 
outlook from stable to negative based on the possibility that ALLETE’s credit quality 19 
could weaken if the post -Acquisition capital structure incorporates a greater level of 20 
debt leverage. However, as discussed by Partner Witnesses  Andre w Alley and Jonathan 21 
Bram , this Acquisition will not be heavily leveraged.  Additionally , the Company  and 22 
the Partners  made commitments to corporate separateness measures  in the Merger 23 
Agreement , which is discussed in more detail in the Direct Testimony of  Partner and 24 
Company Witness Ellen Lapson and Company Witness Colin B. Anderson . These 25 
measures are  designed to  mitigate risk of negative impact on ALLETE’s credit metrics. 26 
Ultimately, the credit rating agencies will continue to monitor the Acquisition through 27 
the regulatory approval process.  28 
 29 
 
 17 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. If the Acquisition does not close, are there any potential impacts to ALLETE’s 1 
credit rating?  2 
A. Yes. If the Acquisition does not close or is materially delayed , the Company’s credit 3 
rating could be harmed. As discussed above, there are material risks and challenge s 4 
associated with accessing the amount of capital needed to carry out the Company’s 5 
strategy . The Acquisition presents an opportunity to mitigate these risks and safeguard 6 
the financial health of the Comp any; therefore, the inability to close or a material delay 7 
would place the Company in a vulnerable  position.   8 
 9 
Q. What might that mean for Minnesota Power?  10 
A. This could lead to limited or expensive access to capital for Minnesota Power, which 11 
would increase the cost and delay the Company’s ability to complete necessary projects 12 
to address generation, transmission , and distribution system needs.  This would result in 13 
negative impacts for all of Minnesota Power’s stakeholders.  14 
 15 
C. Effect of the Acquisition  16 
Q. What assurances do you have that the Partners will be able to provide Minnesota 17 
Power the access to equity capital it needs?  18 
A. As discussed in the Direct Testimony of Company Witness Scissons, ALLETE’s 19 
approach to the Acquisition was designed from the start to identify partners who were 20 
aligned with the Company’s long -term strategy and had the capital necessary to execute 21 
it. The Partners represent experienced infrastructure investors with a proven track 22 
record. As described in the Petition, CPP Investments has assets under management 23 
totaling C AD$632.3 billion , and GIP has approximately $115 billion as of March 31, 24 
2024. Following the closing of the Acquisition , the Partners will have a vested interest 25 
in the success of ALLETE, just as they have an interest in the positive performance of 26 
all their investments; the success of ALLETE, and specifically Minnesota Power and its 27 
customers, is success for the Partners as well. Please see the Direct Testimony provided 28 
the Partners  for additional detail on their financial strength and capital commitments.  29 
 30 
 
 18 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Q. Are any changes to Minnesota Power’s capital structure proposed as part of the 1 
Acquisition?  2 
A. No. As described in the Petition, the Company is proposing to maintain the approved 3 
capital structure of Minnesota Power. Minnesota Power will continue to secure external 4 
debt to finance a portion of its capital needs and will receive equity infusions from the 5 
Partners to fund the equity portion of its rate base.  6 
 7 
Q. Will the Commission still maintain oversight over Minnesota Power’s capital 8 
structure after the Acquisition?  9 
A. Yes. The Commission will still maintain oversight of Minnesota Power’s capital 10 
structure. First, the Commission will continue to determine the appropriate regulated 11 
capital structure for Minnesota Power in future rate case proceedings. Additionally, 12 
Minnesota Power will continue to file annual capital structure petitions with the 13 
Commission for approval to issue securities, to set the overall common equity ratio, and 14 
total capitalization in which the Company will operate.  15 
 16 
Q. Please explain what reporting to the Commission after the Acquisition might look 17 
like for Minnesota Power’s capital structure filings?  18 
A. The Commission will continue to receive similar reporting from ALLETE’s capital 19 
structure filings going forward consistent with Minn. Stat. § 216B.49 and Minn. R. 20 
7825.1000 -7825.1500.  21 
 22 
Q. If the Acquisition did not close , what would be the likely result for Minnesota 23 
Power and its customers?  24 
A. As discussed above, if the Acquisition  does not close, the Company will be in a 25 
challenging position  and will face mat erial risks in accessing the amount of capital 26 
needed to serve customers. A failed transaction would be a significant event for the 27 
Company and would harm its standing among credit rating agencies and investors . It is 28 
possible, or even likely, that it could lead to a material negative impact on ALLETE’s 29 
share price, which would make it even more challenging to raise equity capital in the 30 
public markets.   This would add an additional layer of challenge , on top of the 31 
 
 19 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran Direct  Company’s small size and unique risk profile , as it seeks to attract  an unprecedented  1 
amount of capital investment on an annual basis . This could lead to increased costs and 2 
delay s in project execution, which would negatively impact the Company and its 3 
customers. Additionally, the Company would not be in a strong position to serve  4 
additional load growth opportunities  in its service territory to the detriment of current 5 
customers and regional stakeholders.  6 
 7 
Q. Would a delay in approval of the Acquisition impact the Company?  8 
A. Yes. As stated in the Merger Agreement , the Partners  have committed to provide  interim 9 
financing  for a period of time. A material delay in regulatory approval would exacerbate  10 
the access to capital risks  that face the Company.  A timely approval of the Acquisition 11 
is critical to  allow the Company to access both debt and equity  at competitive rates  on 12 
behalf of customers.  13 
 14 
IV. CONCLUSION  15 
Q. Please summarize your Direct Testimony  for the Commission’s consideration.  16 
A. ALLETE has significant capital needs, driven primarily by Minnesota Power. Th ese 17 
capital needs pose a unique risk to the Company , which  the proposed Acquisition  can 18 
help mitigate . The Acquisition is consistent with the public interest in that it will provide 19 
the Company with the capital necessary to continue leading the State of Minnesota in 20 
transitioning to a cleaner energy future while maintaining the reliable, safe, and 21 
affordable service on which Minnesota Power customers depend.  Additionally, the 22 
Acquisition  will provide the Company access to the capital necessary to meet the State 23 
of Minnesota’s Carbon Free S tandard.  Finally, the Acquisition is a change in the equity 24 
ownership of ALLETE, which will not cause any adverse impacts on customers, utility 25 
operations, electric service cost or quality, employees, or communities.  26 
 27 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony ? 28 
A. Yes. 29

 9 
Q. Please summarize your qualifications and experience.  10 
A. I graduated with a Bachelor of Business Administration degree in Finance from the 11

Power . 20 
 21

the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (“Commission”)  (Docket No. E015/GR -23- 24

Commission . 26

Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” i ndicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.

Q. Please provide a brief summary of the transaction described in the Petition.  3 
A. In the Petition, Minnesota Power seeks approval by the Commission of a transaction in 4 
which entities controlled or managed by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 5 
(collectively “CPP Investments”) and/or Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”)2 6 
(together, the “Partners”)  will, through a new Partner -created entity known as Alloy 7

The organizational structure after the Acquisition, as  shown in the diagram on  9 
Attachment A -2 to the Petition, includes ALLETE, Parent (immediately above 10 
ALLETE), other intermediate entities, and then CPP Investments and GIP.  11

III. COST ALLOCATIONS  13 
Q. Please briefly describe how Minnesota Power fits into ALLETE.  14 
A. Minnesota Power is a division, not a subsidiary, of ALLETE and comprises the majority 15 
of ALLETE’s activities. Net income from Minnesota Power regulated operations was 16 
approximately 60 percent of total consolidated ALLETE net income in 2023, excluding 17 
a non -recurring gain recognized for a favorable arbitration ruling involving a subsidiary 18 
of ALLETE Clean Energy, and is projected to be 65 percent of total consolidated 19 
ALLETE net income in 2024, excluding merger -related expenses. The remaining 35 20 
percent of ALLETE’s projected consolidated net income in 2024 comes primarily from 21 
the following wholly owned subsidiaries, which are not regulated by the Commission: 22 
ALLETE Clean Energy; BNI Energy; New Energy Equity; Superior Water, Light & 23 
Power Company; and an investment in the American Transmission Company.  24

Anderson  Direct and Schedule  Q.  Does the Company have procedures in place to ensure accurate cost assignments, 1 
often referred to as “allocations,” between the regulated activities of Minnesota 2 
Power and the Company’s non -regulated activities?  3 
A. Yes. I provided detailed Direct Testimony about these procedures  in the 2023 Rate Case.  4 
 5 
Q. Please provide an overview of those procedures.  6 
A. The starting point is guidance developed by the Commission in Docket No. G,E999/CI - 7 
90-1008. In that docket, the Commission identified four principles for ensuring cost 8 
separation between regulated and non -regulated activities:  9 
• Tariffed rates shall be used to value tariffed services provided to the non - 10 
regulated activity;  11 
• Costs shall be directly assigned to either regulated or non -regulated activities 12 
whenever possible;  13 
• Costs that cannot be directly assigned are common costs, which shall be grouped 14 
into homogeneous cost categories. Each cost category shall be allocated based 15 
on direct analysis of the origin of the costs whenever possible. If direct analysis 16 
is not possible, common costs shall be allocated based upon an indirect cost - 17 
causative linkage to another cost category or group of cost categories for which 18 
direct assignment or allocation is available; and  19 
• When neither direct nor indirect measures of cost causation can be found, the 20 
cost category shall be allocated based upon a general allocator computed by 21 
using the ratio of all expenses directly assigned or attributed to regulated and 22 
non-regulated activities, excluding the cost of fuel, gas, purchased power, and 23 
the cost of purchased goods sold.3 24 
 25 
Q. How does the Company implement this guidance?  26 
A. First, the Company directly assigns costs whenever possible. Approximately 90 percent 27 
of Minnesota Power’s 2023 regulated and non -regulated O&M expenses were directly 28

The remaining approximately 10 percent of expenses cannot be directly assigned. These 4 
expenses are mostly for general and administrative support activities that benefit all 5 
entities in the ALLETE consolidated group. To allocate such costs, a cost pool is created 6 
for each similar type of administrative and general activity. Expenses within each cost 7 
pool are then allocated utilizing an allocation method specifically designed for that 8 
activity. There are 29 different Allocation Methods currently being utilized by the 9 
Company.4 The allocators are specific in nature and include factors such as number of 10 
employees, fixed asset balances, corporate equity, number of plan participants, and 11 
number of desktop and laptop computers. Again, more detail about the allocation 12 
process is provided in the 2023 Rate Case.  13 
 14 
The objective of the cost allocation process is to allocate general and administrative 15 
costs in a reasonable, prudent, and fair manner that correlates the benefit each activity 16 
provides to the Company’s regulated versus non -regulated and subsidiary activities. 17 
Thus, there are no general or default allocations, nor default assumptions as to whether 18 
costs should be allocated to regulated, non -regulated, or subsidiary activities.  19

Q. What is the purpose of these filings?  6 
A. As I understand it, the essential purpose of Minnesota’s affiliated interest law  and the 7 
Company’s affiliated interest filings made with the Commission is to allow the 8 
Commission to ensure that agreements among affiliated companies are reasonable and 9 
to identify potential self -dealing that could harm customers.  Therefore , the affiliated 10 
interest statute should be interpreted and applied consistent with the Commission’s core 11 
responsibility to establish just and reasonable rates.  12

The Vanguard  Group, Inc. (“Vanguard”) . Institutional investors  like BlackRock and 18 
Vanguard  typically  own stock in hundreds or thousands of individual companies.  19

Anderson  Direct and Schedule  Q. Has the Commission  considered other  businesses in which such institutional 1 
investors own interests  as affiliates ? 2 
A. No. The Commission  has not historically treated  other businesses  in which such 3 
institutional investors own similar  interests  as requiring data or filings in Minnesota 4 
Power  affiliated interest filings . This treatment  has been  consistent ly applied by the 5 
Commission in sim ilar instances with other utilities.   6 
 7 
Q. Is the Commission’s historical approach reasonable ? 8 
A. Yes. The approach taken to date by the Commission provides enough information to 9 
allow stakeholders to analyze affiliated interest issues and to protect against self - 10 
dealing.  It recognizes that institutional investors are investors, not operators of public 11 
utilities.  Changing the Commission’s historical approach would turn innumerable 12 
companies owned by institutional investors  into affiliates of each Minnesota public 13 
utility, without regard for their role as investors , not operators.  This would be entirely 14 
unworkable —both for the Commission and for the utilities the Commission regulates. 15 
Further, c hanging the Commission’s historical approach  is not necessary to achieve the 16 
purpose of the affiliated interest requirements , because  it would not protect against 17 
affiliate self -dealing and would  not advance  the Commission’s core purpose  of 18 
establishing  just and reasonable rates . 19 
  20 
Q. How should  the Commission consider affiliated interest requirements in the 21 
context of  the Acquisition?  22 
A. The Commission should take a reasonable and flexible view of affiliated interest 23 
requirements, consistent with its historical approach. A reasonable application of 24 
affiliated interest requirements is necessary in a modern marketplace where investments 25 
of the size and scope needed by a public utility are regularly made through multi -tiered 26 
investment structures and by large institutional investors that have investments in , 27 
without direct control over,  many other businesses. The affiliated interest statute will 28 
remain  an effective tool to protect the public from harm that may result from self -dealing 29 
among related companies . But it does not follow that affiliated interest scrutiny needs 30 
to apply where th ere is a lack of direct control over the contracting company or 31 
 
 10 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Anderson  Direct and Schedule  companies, whether it be the utility or its counterparties. Put another way, if there is not 1 
an ability on the part of an investor to directly control or influence the contracting 2 
decisions of an entity, that entity’s contracts will be entered into at arms -length relative 3 
to other interests of the investor, and the concerns of self -dealing are not present.  4

Q. Does Minnesota Power also have a Supplier Code of Conduct?  4 
A. Yes.  The Company’s Supplier Code of Conduct is shared with all vendors and is part 5 
of the supplier onboarding process which  helps create a more ethical, compliant, and 6 
sustainable supply chain, benefiting both the Company and its suppliers  and ensures that 7 
we are working with the right vendors in an effort  to provide the best value to our 8 
customers . The supplier code of conduct is a valuable tool for several reasons:  9 
1. Promotes Ethical Behavior : It sets clear expectations for suppliers regarding 10 
ethical standards, such as fair labor practices, environmental responsibility, and 11 
anti-corruption measures.  12 
2. Ensures Compliance : It helps ensure that suppliers comply with laws and 13 
regulations, reducing the risk of legal issues and penalties.  14 
3. Protects Reputation : By holding suppliers to high ethical standards, companies 15 
can protect and enhance their reputation.  16 
4. Builds Trust : A clear code of conduct builds trust between the company and its 17 
suppliers, fostering long -term, sustainable relationships.  18 
5. Mitigates Risk : It helps identify and mitigate potential risks in the supply chain, 19 
such as labor violations or environmental harm.  20 
6. Encourages Improvement : It encourages suppliers to continuously improve 21 
their practices, aligning with the company's commitment to social responsibility.  22 
7. Ensures Consistency : It provides a consistent framework for evaluating and 23 
managing suppliers, ensuring fairness and transparency.  24

value s and we believe this , along  with the addition of the ownership question on the 35

Q. Have Minnesota Power and the Partners made “ring -fencing” commitments 6 
relating to corporate separateness and financing?  7 
A. Yes. Ring -fencing is a term that is used to describe arrangements that keep a regulated 8 
utility business separate from the non -utility affiliates or holding company parent of the 9 
utility. In the context of the Acquisition, ring -fencing refers to measures and 10 
commitments undertaken by ALLETE and the Partners that are intended to protect the 11 
regulated utility and its customers from non -regulated risks and expenditures, as well as 12 
the business and financial risks of the Partners. The “ring -fencing” commitments made 13 
by Minnesota Power and the Partners are outlined starting on page 20 of the Petition. 14 
We believe these commitments demonstrate that Minnesota Power and its customers 15 
will be adequately and appropriately protected and separated from non -regulated risks.  16 
 17

ALLETE’s financial accounts. This separation is crucial to maintaining  the separateness 20 
of the two entities.  21

after the acquisition closes. Alloy Parent has also received a commitment for  a $100 31

A. No. Minnesota Power will not attempt to recover  its transaction costs or transition costs  24

ALLETE employees track and report their time and other expenses associated with the 27

addition, the Company has implemented a process to review invoices from vendors 31

Q.  Will transaction or transition costs  incurred at Alloy Parent LLC or above,  or by 4 
the Partners , be passed down to Minnesota Power?  5 
A. No. Any costs re lated to the acquisition  incurred at the Alloy Parent LLC level or at the 6 
intermediate levels above , will be recorded at that level and will not be passed down to 7 
ALLETE. All costs incurred by the Partners will remain with the Partners .  8

Q.  Will adjustments to the Company’s books and records to reflect the Acquisition 10 
transaction be pushed down to utility customers in any other way?  11 
A. No. Minnesota Power and the Partners will not deploy “push down accounting” (i.e., 12 
adjustment of Minnesota Power’s asset or liability values or books and records to reflect 13 
the purchase price) with respect to the Acquisition.  Minnesota Power maintains its 14 
books in accordance with the Uniform System of Accounts and does not intend to adjust 15 
the historical cost values of its assets and liabilities, record any goodwill, or include 16 
costs in its cost of service that are related to the Acquisition. In accordance with 17 
Generally Accepted Accounting Principles in the United States, Alloy Parent LLC  will 18 
account for the transaction using the acquisition (or purchase) method of accounting for 19 
business combinations. The related purchase accounting journal entries, including the 20 
creation of goodwill, will be recorded at Alloy Parent  LLC  and will not be pushed down 21 
to ALLETE . Thus, the costs cannot be built into the rates of Minnesota  Power’s 22 
customers.  23

CHAPTER 1 – PURCHASING & CONTRACTS INTRODUCTION  
 
Purpose  
 
For the Company  to maintain its position of leadership, it is imperative that we continually strive to lower costs 
while obtaining the best value in every area of our business operations . Purchased materials and services 
account for a large percent of the Company ’s costs  and provide us with an excellent opportunity for cost 
reduction and control .  
 
Purchasing is an important activity where the responsibility for procurement of materials and services is 
assigned to a group of employees ( buyers ) trained in negotiating, cost  reduction, strategic sourcing, 
electronic commerce, and other purchasing techniques.  
 
The primary responsibility of the Purchasing and Contracts department (Purchasing) is to purchase materials, 
supplies,  and services with the objective of delivery at the proper time, in the proper place, in a quantity, 
quality and price consistent with the needs of the Company . This balancing of several factors is critical.  
 
To achieve this overall objective, the responsi bilities, authorities,  and controls set forth in this policy and 
referenced policies must be adhered to by all employees.  
 
Responsibilities  
 
Purchasing has the responsibility for the procurement of all goods and services and the processing and sale 
of surp lus and obsolete materials.  
 
Only those persons delegated by the Company  CEO/ -President are authorized to act as agents and commit 
the Company  for materials, equipment, supplies, and services.  
 
Purchasing has the responsibility for obligating the Company  and for making the determination of source of 
supply, quantities purchased, delivery schedule and price negotiations, except where others are so 
spec ifically authorized by the CEO/ President. Thes e decisions will be made in conjunction with Operations, 
Accounting, Engineering, and other departments, as appropriate.  
 
Purchasing has the responsibility to initiate and maintain effective and professional relationships with current 
and prospective suppl iers, as well as all Company  personnel, who are the d epartment's clients. All 
employees involved in purchasing activities will work to maintain and enhance the Company 's image by their 
personal conduct, methods of doing business, and practicing good public relations, giving all visitors, callers, 
and Company  personnel professional , courteous treatment.  
 
Purchasing serves as the primary channel through which requests reg arding prices for products and services 
are handled. Buyers will conduct appropriate communication with suppliers regarding  prices or quotations. In 
cases where technical details are necessary, the user department may communicate directly with supplier.  
 
 
All negotiations are to include the appropriate b uyers within their delegated authority.

Buyer  Responsibilities : 
 
- Obtain and purchase all materials and services at the best economic value, considering the guidelines 
of prices, service, quality, and deliv ery. This duty will be performed in conjunction with the user.  
- Ensure all the appropriate approvals have been attained for ordered materials and services . See 
approval levels.  
- Inform user departments whenever the quantity or specifications of materials or services ordered are 
inconsistent with sound purchasing practices or market conditions and coordinate with the users in 
meeting their needs.  
- Ensure that suppliers of services have required insurance and safety orientation .  
- Coordinate  with int ernal Legal Department to ensure that risk is mitigated through review of 
agreements before execution.  
- Ensure  punctual delivery of specified goods and services in correct quantities and on schedule based 
on user information.  
- Negotiate the return of rejecte d material or supplies to suppliers  upon notification from requestor .  
- Negotiate resolution to any unacceptable services in accordance with the contract  upon notification 
from requestor . 
 
Buyers and all users will treat P urchasing data in a confidential ma nner. This includes pricing information, 
contract details, proprietary technical specifications, bid awards and supplier information.  
 
The Manager of Purchasing will advise management  of economic conditions and changes significant to the 
Company 's long and short -term interests.

CHAPTER 3 – PURCHASING LAW & AUTHORITY TO SIGN/CHANGE 
CONTRACTS  
 
Purchasing Law  
• Buyers have sufficient knowledge of the law to enable them to understand the legal relationship between 
themselves and the Company , and the legal consequences of the acts performed in the Company ’s name.  
• Buyers’ knowledge of legal fundamentals makes them e quipped to recognize when situations require 
legal guidance.  
 
Authorized Approval Levels  
• Authorized to approve an expense; not to make the purchase.  
 
Employees Authorized to Contractually O bligate the Company  
• Officers   
• Buyers, manager of Purchasing, d irector of Support Services  
• No other persons are authorized to sign contracts, agreements, proposals, letters of intent, etc.  
• All others who commit the Company  to the purchase of materials or services are not protected by the 
Company  and may b e held personally liable.  
 
Authority Granted/Review by Legal  
• The Board of Directors  has given contract authority to sign contracts to Company  officers which include 
Vice President, President, CEO and Controller  
• No ot her titles are included under “ officers. ” 
• Other authorized agents of the Company  are those in Purchasing.  
• Buyers, m anager of Purchasing and d irector of Support Services are authorized to sign contracts, 
agreements and proposals that are associated with purchase order s. 
• The purchase order  is the contract with or without additional attached documents.  
• Contracts and agreements submitted by s uppliers must be reviewed and approved by the Purchasing  
and/or Legal Department  prior to purchase.  
 
Agreements Outside of Purchasing’s Procurement Autho rity 
• Contracts, proposals,  or agreements that  
o (a) have no dollar value (such as non -disclosure agreements) AND  
o (b) are outside of the scope of Purchasing’s procurement authority (for example, an agreement 
that is not associated with a Purchase or a Purchase Order) need to be signed by an officer ( Vice 
President, President, CEO, Controller )  
• These types of agreements should also be reviewed by the Company’s  Legal d epartment before signing.

Personal Liability  
• As agents of the Company , buyers are protected and not likely to become personally liable for purchases 
on behalf of the Company.  
• Personal liability may occur if the scope of business authority is exceeded.  
• Buyers should not make false statements regarding their authority, make fals e statements with the intent 
to deceive or take any action without authority that could result in damages to others.  
• Other employees may be held personally liable if making purchases outside company  policies.

CHAPTER 4 – ETHICS  
 
Conflict of Interest   
User and Buyer Responsibility  
• Employees may not have either direct or indirect financial interest of consequence in any business that 
competes with or supplies materials or services to the Company  or its subsidiari es. 
• Under very unusual circumstances, exceptions may be granted with prior approval from the President.  
• Similar directives are pertinent to employees performing work or being paid by the Company  for work 
outside their normal duties ( see Ethics Manual ) 
 
Related Party Transactions  
User and Buyer Responsibility  
• Regardless of dollar value, contracts awarded to related parties, (i.e., relatives of employees, affiliated 
entities,  etc.) must:  
o Be quoted.  
o Have management approval.  
o Meet all purchase order  requirem ents (contract, insurance, 1099R)  
• Employees are not to disclose any company  proprietary information to unauthorized persons.  
• Employees are not to take personal advantage of their position with the Company.  
• If an employee finds themselves in a financial con flicting position, they are to state  the facts in a letter to 
the p resident/CEO, who will make a decision in respects to the situation.  
 
Gifts/Gratuities/Entertainment  
User and Buyer  Responsibility  
• Employees are not to accept gifts, gratuities,  or entertai nment (dinners, recreational outings, sporting 
events, etc .) which are beyond a nominal amount and would place the employee in a position to feel 
obligated to a current or prospective supplier.   
• Under no conditions are loans, cash,  or cash equivalents, to be accepted from individuals or 
organizations that currently or prospectively may have a business relation with the Company.  
o The exception is if the individual or organization is in the business of making loans to individuals.   
• Associations with suppliers at luncheons, dinners or organizational meetings help establish business 
relationships and should not be considered unethical provided employees do not place themselves in the 
position of being obligated to the supplier.  
o To ensu re this, company  personnel are expected to act as hosts for suppliers on occasion.

CHAPTER 5 – SUPPLIER GUIDELINES  
 
Obligation of Company  to Suppliers  
• Suppliers are to be treated with professional courtesy.  
• All approved suppliers are to have equal opportunity to provide pricing.   
• Avoid putting suppliers through unnecessary expense or inconvenience.   
• Decline to take advantage of supplier’s errors.  
• Explain  clearly the reasons for rejection of bids/proposal without divulging price or other proprietary 
details.  
• Provide information to suppliers regarding company  safety and security requirements.  
• Share no competitor’s pricing or proprietary information.  
 
Obliga tions of Supplier to Company  
• Communicate directly with b uyers regarding negotiations  and purchases.  
• Suppliers of services must submit a Certificate of Insurance  naming the Company  as an additional 
insured per the li mits required in each company ’s terms and c onditions. ( Minnesota Power, Superior 
Water, Light and Power Company , and ALLETE Clean Energy  dollar limits differ)  
•  Suppliers must comply with all required training prior to coming on -site at an ALLETE facility o r 
performing work on behalf of ALLETE at a customer site.  
• No materials or serv ices are to be supplied to the Company  without receiving written notice or 
authorization from buyers.  
• Negotiations are to be conducted ethically without attempt to influence thr ough offering personal gifts or 
entertainment.  
• All changes to current agreements must be directed to and approved by buyers.  
• The Company  may request a visit to the supplier’s location of business.  
• Suppliers are not to share Company  proprietary information with Company  competitors.  
 
Supplier Samples  
User and Buyer Responsibility:  
• Samples of products offered for evaluation should only be accepted if:  
o The product is currently being used or could potentially be used.  
o The quantity/size are small and of low value.  
• No chemicals are to be accepted unless accompanied by an  approved  safety d ata sheet.  
• There should be a prompt evaluation of the product.  
• If the product sampled is more than nominal value and an extended period  will be necessary for 
evaluation, the sample shall be purchased.

CHAPTER 7 – QUOTING POLICY  
 
As a regulated utility, Minnesota Power is required to obtain competitive quotations or provide a single 
source/justification letter explaining why we did not  get competitive quotes on all purchases of materials and 
services  over $50,000 . All business units do this as a best practice.  
 
Limit for Quoting Above $5 0,000  
Buyer Responsibility  
• All requests over $50,000 need competitive quotes . The exception is POs generated from a BPA, as 
BPAs have their own competitive bidding process.  
• This $50,000 is exclusive of tax and shipping costs.  
• There needs to be a minimum of two to three quotes depending on the availability of suppliers and value 
of request.  
• The user may send budgetary quotes they have obtained with an approved requisition, but purchasing  
may need to re -quote formally to obtain all information necessary to complete a purchase order. 
• Purchasing reserves,  the right to quote vendors and award purchase order s to vendors that represent 
the best economic value to the Company.  
o Many times,  suppliers do not include freight options, lead time, etc.  
o Purchasing will include the appropriate terms and c onditions with formal quotes, which may also 
change the supplier’s quote response.  
o Purchasing will utilize existing contracts and alliances with vendors where applicable.  
 
Technical Questions Arising During Bidding Process  
User Responsibility:  
• If technical questions arise during bidding process, all answers supplied by th e user should be routed to 
Purchasing  who will share with all bidders.  
• Purchasing is to notify all suppliers of added information . 
o This will place all suppliers on equal ground and make sure responses are uniform.  
 
Award Requirements  
Buyer Responsibility:  
• Award is to be to the lowest bidder.  
o Unless a better economic value can be obtained and documented  
• Factors that may be considered other than pricing include:  
o Ability to meet specification requirements.  
o Ability to meet timeline.  
o Availability of equipment necessary to complete service.  
o Previous record of performance  
o Financial stability  
o Cyber security requirements  
 
User Respo nsibility:

• If selecting  a supplier that is not lowest bidder, documentation needs to include a listing of qualitative 
factors considered, the persons that completed the evaluation (team members) and description of the 
evaluation process.  
• Documentation also needs to have signature ap proval of appropriate dollar level and submitted for 
Purchasing  to attach in Oracle to the purchase order.  
 
Single or Sole Source Documentation (see definitions in Chapter 2)  
User Responsibility:  
• If a material or service is a single or sole source there needs to be written documentation attached to the 
purchase requisition and approved by appropriate authority (same authority as requisition)  
 
Quote Analysis  
Buyer Responsibility:  
• An analysis is performed by buyers, usually through Oracle sourcing , to evaluate the commercial 
components of supplier quotes.  
• The analysis should include pricing, lead time, freight, etc.  
• The analysis should be attached to the PO and will be reviewed as part of the Oracle Purchasing approval 
process.  
• Approval levels can be found in the s ection titled “CHAPTER 6 – APPROVAL LEVELS ” 
 
User Responsibility :  
• Coordinate with Buyer to provide analysis of quotes including  any discrepancies/exceptions from RFQ 
requirements, specifications,  and other selection criteria.  
 
Sharing of Award Results  
User and Buyer Responsibility:  
• No dollar amounts or proprietary information are to be shared with any supplier competitors.  
 
Buyer Responsibility  
• Unsuccessful bidders are to be notified by telephone, in person, electronically or by letter.  
• Documentation of notification should be attached in Oracle to purchase order.  
• Formal quotes received by Purchasing  will be shared with the user if the quotes need  user evaluation or 
if the user requests to evaluate.  
• If quotes are for standard items that meet part number specification or equivalent given by user and no 
user evaluation is necessary, the b uyer will place the order based on pricing.  
• If delivery is crit ical, it should be noted on the requisition.  
o Delivery requirements may change the award of the purchase order.  
 
Document Retention  
Buyer Responsibility:  
• All quotes, quote evaluations/analysis, single/sole source and approval documentation will be maintained with the 
final purchase order  file copy in Oracle.

enable ALLETE to leverage freight discounts through consolidated spend, increase

CHAPTER 1 5 – NON -PO INVOICE POLICY  
 
For ALLETE to remain an industry leader, it is imperative we con tinually strive to lower costs  
while obtaining the best value in every area of our business operations. Following corpor ate 
purchasing policy is an easy and efficient way to ensure  that we receive the best payment 
terms and pricing available. 
 
Purchas ing off-contract often leads to higher costs. Additionally, the Non-PO invoice process 
is more costly internally as it requires more time to process these types of invoices. Although 
we realize there are bus iness reasons to occasionally use the non-PO invoice proce ss, it is in 
the compan y’s best interest to reduce the use of non-PO invoices. Additionally, a reduction in 
Non-PO invoices c reates benefits for our sales tax department, as it allows us to utilize the 
Oracle system capabilities to streamline our sales tax classifications and  ensure proper 
sales tax treatment on invoices. The following policy was developed with these concepts in 
mind. 
 
The following purchases req uire a PO: 
 
o Any service (regardless of dollar amount). This ensures  we have proper 
insurance in p lace. 
o Material purchases for inventory items. In order to proce ss an item as inventory 
it must be tied to a PO. 
o Material purchases o ver $3,000. Purchases over this amou nt need to be 
coordinated through the Purchas ing department to ensure  competitive 
pricing and compliance with contracts. 
 
Note: Purchasing will not create new purchase orders for materials  and/or services 
which have already been ordered, received,  or completed . Any purchases that fall into 
this category are a direct violation of the Purchasing  Non-PO invoice policy.  The 
reque ster will need a Deviation form  (provi ded by Accounts Payable or Purchasing) 
approved by the ALLETE Treasurer or VP -ALLETE Controller & Chief Accounting Officer  
in order to pay the invoice through the non-PO process.  
 
 
Purchas ing can help users with the creation of internal POs. These are POs that are not sent 
to the vendor but created internally to allow for more efficient process ing of invoices. Work with 
Purchasing to determine the best type of PO to use for these types of expenses. 
 
Examples of what could be on an internal PO are as follows: 
 
• Insurance 
• Landowner Payments  
• Payroll 
• Taxes 
• Utility Bills

CHAPTER 1 8 – CONTRACT BONDS  
 
Bonds transfer the risk of a contractor’s nonpayment or failure to perform to a third-party  
surety. Bonds are a way to manage the risk of a contractor’s failure to (1) complete a project or 
(2) pay its subcontractors and suppliers. Bonds differ from insura nce as bonds are intended to 
prevent a loss from happening while insurance responds after the loss occurs.  
 
 
User Responsibility:  
 
The user shall notify the Buyer , prior to the RFQ being issued, if the project will meet one of 
the following criteria:  (1) is valued at mo re than $5 Million; (2) involves  five or more 
subcontractors; or (3) will take mo re than 12 months to complete. The user should work with 
the Buyer  to determine if a bond is appropriate for the contractor to obtain .  
 
 
Buyer Responsibility:  
 
When ALLETE, or any of its subsidiary companies, intends to enter into a construction or 
major equipment contract, the buyer will require the project manager to determine whether the 
contractor should bond the project when the project: (1) is valued at more than $5 Million; (2) 
involved 5 or more subcontractors; or (3) will take mo re than 12 months to complete.  
 
Bond Summary Guide:  
 
Please reference the Bond Summary Guide , found on the  Purchasing department  Stream page 
under “Purchasing tools for employees” for additional information on  Contract Bonds.

CHAPTER 19 – SCRAP SALES PROCEDURES  
 
For scrap materials that have an estimated value greater than $ 50,000 this section shall apply .  
 
User Responsibility:  
 
1. Material is identified that needs to be scrapped out by the appropriate department.  
2. Department who has identified the material and wishes to scrap it ( Scrap Seller ) will 
compile  all applicable documentation for the material to be scrapped including project 
and task information and estimated scrap value.  
a. Examples of this documentation would be : 
i. PCB reports (for transformers),  
ii. Pictures of material,  
iii. Material specificatio ns,  
iv. Estimated pounds  or percentages of metals/oils/etc.,  
v. Location of materials,  
vi. Scrap Seller c ontact information and  
vii. Dates material will be available for viewing.  
3. Contact Purchasing  and Environmental  (if applicable)  departments with the 
documentation listed above. The Environmental department will advise on the materials 
identified and what environmental concerns and or steps need to be taken. This could 
include environmental testing or approved scrap vendor recommen dations.  
4. Review all proposals submitted from scrap vendors for accuracy and work with the 
appropriate Buyer  to award scrap sale.  
a.   Scrap sales are tied to the purchasing department commodity codes so please 
work with the appropriate purchasing department c ontact . The list of purchasing 
“Category Codes by Buyer” is found on the Purchasing Stream page under 
“Purchasing tools for employee .” 
5. If scrap is being sold on a per pound  basis,  then all scale tickets must be submitted  by 
the selected scrap vendor  to the  Scrap Seller.  
6. Ensure that a signed  Form 3426  Bill of Sale, tax exempt certificate (if required) and 
payment has been received prior to material being removed from the site  unless other 
arrangements have been made by Scrap Seller . 
a. Payment may be waived unt il after the material has been processed by the 
selected scrap vendor in situations where the Scrap Seller is unable to determine 
the weight of the material being scrapped until it has been processed.  
7. Forward payment s, signed  Form 3426  Bill of Sale, tax e xempt certificate (if required) to 
Purchasing . 
8. Coordinate with selected scrap vendor for removal of material from site.

intact, with its current commitments to employees, customers, and other stakeholders 18

employees we would continue existing relationships with both bargaining and non- 25 
bargaining employees and collective bargaining organizations, we would have concrete 26 
and verifiable evidence of these commitments by Minnesota Power – and the 27 
recognition of these relationships by the Partners.  28 
 29 
Thus, as stated in the Petition, “For the two-year period following the Acquisition, each 30 
ALLETE nonunion employee . . . will retain extensive protections, including the same 31 
or better employment position in the same location, and wages, incentive, benefits, and 32 
 
 4 OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
Krollman Direct employee protections no less favorable than those available to the employee 1 
immediately prior to the Acquisition.”2 Additionally, the Petition noted “ALLETE will 2 
also continue to honor its union contracts.”3 Partner Witnesses Jonathan Bram and 3 
Andrew Alley also discuss the Partners’ commitments to our workforce in their Direct 4 
Testimony. 5 
 6 
Q. What additional protections for employees are included in the Merger 7 
Agreement?4 8 
A. In addition to the two-year timeframe explained above, employees are provided with 9 
other customary employee protections, such as recognition of pre-Acquisition service 10 
with ALLETE for benefit plan purposes, waiver of pre-existing condition limitations 11 
under post-Acquisition health plans, and credit for deductibles and co-payments under 12 
post-closing plans for the year of the Acquisition.  13 
 14 
Q. How will these terms protect Minnesota Power’s workforce? 15 
A. The Company knows that to attract, engage, and retain our top talent, we need to have 16 
continuity of our market-prevalent compensation and benefit programs. The certainties 17 
outlined in my Direct Testimony and the Direct Testimony of Witnesses Bram and Alley 18 
ensure this consistency for our current and future workforce. 19 
 20 
Q. Do you have anything else to add at this time? 21 
A. While the Merger Agreement outlines protections for employees, which again provides 22 
concrete and verifiable evidence of the commitment to our employees, there is 23 
additional value the Acquisition brings to our employees in terms of how we execute 24 
our growth strategy. Recognizing that we are a relatively small energy company seeking 25 
significant financing in the public markets, without this transaction there is no guarantee 26 
that Minnesota Power would be able to access the capital it needs for clean energy 27 
transition investments, which could have an impact on our workforce needs. 28 
 
2 Petition at 18. 
3 Petition at 18. 
4 Petition at Attachment B. 
 
 5 OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
Krollman Direct  1 
The last point I will add is that it is crucial to have a timely regulatory approval process. 2 
Such timely approvals are likely to minimize the stress and uncertainty that employees 3 
might experience. Prolonged periods of ambiguity can lead to anxiety, decreased 4 
productivity, and even attrition as employees worry about the Company’s future and its 5 
workforce needs. While we have committed to provide frequent updates to employees 6 
and have strong employee protections included in the Merger Agreement, the longer it 7 
takes to gain required approvals and close on the Acquisition, the more stress employees 8 
will need to endure.  9 
 10 
IV. CONCLUSION 11 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony? 12 
A. Yes. 13
