1 I. INTRODUCTION  1 
Q. Please state your name and employer.   2 
A. My name is Jonathan Bram  and I am a founding partner of Global Infrastructure Partners, 3 
which is the trading name for Global Infrastructure Management, LLC  along with related 4 
funds (collectively “GIP”).   5 
 6 
Q. Please summarize your responsibilities at GIP.    7 
A. I serve in a variety of roles at GIP.  I am an investment partner at GIP and participate in 8 
the origination and management of infrastructure investments that are held within our 9 
investment vehicles.    10 
 11 
Q. Please describe  your educational qualifications  and professional experience .  12 
A.  For the past 18 years, I have participated in investment management and operations at GIP, 13 
focusing on electricity and renewables in North America . GIP has approximately $115 14 
billion in current assets under management. In my capacity as founding partner, I am a 15 
member of the Investment Committee and Operating Committee of GIP’s Flagship Funds, 16 
Core, Australian , and Credit Funds , which involves oversight of all investment activities 17 
to be carried out by the GIP team in respect of each of its funds. This oversight 18 
responsibility includes identifying, structuring, negotiating, consummating and executing 19 
investments. My responsibilities include reviewing operations, financial, and 20 
environmental, social, and governance (“ ESG ”) performance, as well as day -to-day 21 
responsibility for the initial investment process across portfolio companies.  22 
 23 
Before founding GIP, I was a Managing Director of the Investment Banking Division at 24 
Credit Suisse  where I also held a variety of other positions , including Co -Head of the 25 
Global Industrial and Services Group and Chief Operating Officer of the Investment 26 
Banking Division. At Credit Suisse I built a focus on project finance and the power sector, 27 
including serving as Co -Head of corporate finance and advisory for the Credit Suisse 28 
Energy Group. Collectively, I have spent over 30 years in the energy and infrastructure 29 
investment sector since earning my economics degree from Columbia College. I currently 30 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
2 serve as chairman of the board of Clearway Energy, one of the largest owners of clean 1 
energy generation assets in the United States, and on the board of Chile Renovables, which 2 
focuses  on large scale renewable energy assets.    3 
 4 
II. PURPOSE AND OVERVIEW  5 
Q. What is the purpose of your Direct Testimony?  6 
A. The purpose of my  Direct  Testimony is to provide information about GIP and the GIP - 7 
managed funds that , if the acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. by GIP and Canada Pension Plan 8 
Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) (the “Acquisition”) is approved,  will own a portion 9 
of ALLETE, Inc. which includes the public utility, Minnesota Power.1  I will explain certain 10 
aspects of the Acquisition , how it will benefit Minnesota Power and its customers , and why 11 
it is consistent with the public interest .  I will also address some potential concerns that 12 
have been or could be raised regarding the Acquisition .    13 
 14 
Q. Please provide a brief overview of your Direct Testimony.  15 
A. My Direct Testimony will provide a brief overview of the Application. I will then describe 16 
GIP, our investment mission, and why we are interested in acquiring ALLETE. Finally, I 17 
will describe the benefits of the Acquisition and provide information about why the 18 
Acquisition is in the public interest and should be approved.   19 
 20 
III. THE PETITION   21 
Q. What sections of the Petition do you sponsor?  22 
A. I sponsor the following sections of the Petition:  23 
• Section II.B.2 : Global Infrastructure Partners ; 24 
 
1  Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Direct Testimony and the  
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all regulated and non -regulated sub sidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
3 • Section II.C: Description of the Acquisition (as to post -Acquisition organizational 1 
structure);  2 
• Section III.B.1: The Commission’s Authority Will Be Unchanged by the Acquisition  3 
(purpose and benefits of the Acquisition) ; 4 
• Section III.B.3: The Reasons for the Acquisition are Sound (as to the Partners’ 5 
interest in the Acquisition);  6 
• Section III.B. 4: Commitments to Minnesota (as to GIP) ; 7 
• Section IV.B.1.h: Statement on affiliated interest (Minn. R. 7825.1400, Subp. H); and  8 
• Section IV.D.3: A list and past history of all contracts or agreements between the 9 
petitioner and affiliated interest, consideration received, and summary of costs.  10 
 11 
Q. What Attachments to the Petition do you sponsor?  12 
A. I co-sponsor the following Attachments to the Petition:  13 
• Attachment A -2: Post -Acquisition Organizational Structure ; and  14 
• Attachment B: Agreement and Plan of Merger . 15 
 16 
IV. DESCRIPTION OF ACQUISITION   17 
Q. Please briefly  describe the Acquisition .  18 
A. Through the Acquisition, ALLETE will transition from a publicly traded entity to a 19 
privately held company wholly  owned by entities managed by GIP and CPP Investments 20 
(the “Partners”) .  The Acquisition will provid e ALLETE and Minnesota Power (together, 21 
the “Company”) with improved access to capital and Partner resources that can support 22 
Minnesota Power’s investment in the clean energy transition and the continu ed delivery of 23 
the safe, reliable, and affordable electric service that Minnesota Power’s customers expect.  24 
 25 
While the Acquisition will change the ownership of ALLETE, many things will not change, 26 
including: (1) ALLETE’s and Minnesota Power’s management team and employees, as 27 
well as its operations, strategy, and values; (2) the authority of the Minnesota Public Utility 28 
Commission (the “Commission”) over Minnesota Power and its Minnesota operations; 29 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
4 (3) Minnesota Power’s commitments to the customers and communities it has served for 1 
over a century; and (4) the transparency to which the Commission is accustomed in its 2 
regulation of Minnesota Power. Moreover, the Acquisition is not expected to impact retail 3 
or municipal rates for utility customers or otherwise adversely affect  the utility or its 4 
customers . To the contrary, the Acquisition will position Minnesota Power to continue 5 
providing safe, reliable, and affordable service to Minnesota Power’s customers  while 6 
accomplishing Minnesota’s ambitious goals for the energy transition.  7 
 8 
Q. Why is GIP making this investment in ALLETE?    9 
A. GIP believes that the Company  represent s a unique opportunity to acquire a growth - 10 
oriented regulated electric utility in the United States  with high -quality assets across both 11 
regulated utility and unregulated renewables businesses, and that also is in alignment with 12 
GIP’s invest ment  criteria.  GIP’s decision to pursue the Acquisition is directly tied to 13 
ALLETE’s significant expected growth, which is being driven by the need to comply with 14 
Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard and requires Minnesota Power to invest unprecedented 15 
capital to decarbonize its generation fleet without compromising reliabil ity. At the same 16 
time, Minnesota Power will need to invest in its transmission and distribution systems to 17 
deliver this decarbonized power to the region and to Minnesota Power’s  customers. The 18 
scale of these investments and the speed at which they must be deployed make ALLETE 19 
an attractive investment opportunity for GIP and make GIP and CPP Investments the right 20 
partners for ALLETE.  21 
 22 
Equally important to GIP is the high quality of ALLETE’s management team and 23 
employees, along with the Company’s established track record of delivering on its 24 
commitments to the customers and communities it serves. ALLETE’s strong leadership 25 
team is comprised of experienced energy executives with long tenures managing utility 26 
operations, executing and optimizing large -scale energy infrastructure projects with 27 
exceptional levels of reliability. This management team also has an established track record 28 
of deep engagement with communities and stakeholders as well as valuing its employees 29 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
5 and union workers who have been instrumental in Minnesota Power’s success.  In addition, 1 
ALLETE’s robust ESG  organization has well -established policies, reporting, and 2 
governance practices committed to addressing climate risk and focused on positive 3 
stakeholder impacts including commitments to invest in its communities, encourage 4 
economic development, and protect low -income customers. The quality of this 5 
management team was a primary factor in GIP’s decision to pursue the Acquisition.  6 
Maintaining this team will ensure that Minnesota Power continue s to operate and provide 7 
high-quality service while making the significant investments needed to comply with the 8 
Carbon Free Standard . 9 
 10 
The Company also has attractive renewables platforms across utility -scale wind and 11 
distributed solar generation with full lifecycle capabilities, providing growth opportunities 12 
and long -term contracted cash flows across a diverse mix of primarily investment -grade 13 
counterparties including utilities, municipalities, cooperatives, and corporates with an 14 
attractive renewable development pipeline.  15 
 16 
Following the completion of the Acquisition , GIP expects to support the management team 17 
in executing its ambitious and policy -driven investment plan. In particular, Minnesota 18 
Power will benefit from GIP’s experience in renewables.   GIP currently operates 19 
22 gigawatts (“GW”) of renewable assets globally, including bringing approximately 20 
5 GW online in the past year and approximately 176 GW under construction or in 21 
development assets. GIP is well positioned to support and reduce the risks of Minnesota 22 
Power’s growth plan in the long -term. This will allow Minnesota Power to maintain strong 23 
operational performance, execute its mission of decarbonization, and increase its value, 24 
which will benefit GIP’s investors, Minnesota Power’s customers, and other stakeholders.  25 
 26 
Q. Please briefly describe the partner  entities that will become owners of ALLETE.    27 
A. Upon closing of the Acquisition, a wholly  owned subsidiary of CPP Investments will 28 
acquire 40  percent of the outstanding common stock of ALLETE. GIP will hold the 29 
remaining 60 percent of the interests in ALLETE through two funds: Global Infrastructure 30 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
6 Partners V (“GIP Fund V”) which will hold 40  percent of the interests,  and Tower Bridge 1 
Infrastructure Partners, L.P. (“Tower Bridge”)  which will hold 20  percent of the interests.  2 
GIP Fund V is a fund managed by a GIP -controlled affiliate and Tower Bridge is a 3 
separately managed account (“SMA”) managed by GIP on behalf of the California Public 4 
Employees’ Retirement System (“CalPERS”) . 5 
 6 
Q. What is a separately managed account?  7 
A. An SMA is an investment vehicle with a single financial investor (as opposed to a fund 8 
with multiple investors). Tower Bridge is an SMA managed by GIP in which CalPERS is 9 
the sole limited partner and financial investor.  10 
 11 
Q. How did GIP Investments in ALLETE come about?    12 
A. As explained in the Direct Testimony of  Company  Witness Jeffery J. Scissons and 13 
discussed in further detail in the Background of the Merger section of Attachment L in the 14 
Petition, ALLETE engaged J.P. Morgan to perform an initial screening of potential 15 
investors.  GIP has a long track record of investment in the utility sector, maintains 16 
relationships across the investment industry, and has the financial capability, regulatory 17 
experience , and ability to consummate a transaction like the Acquisition.  As a result, GIP 18 
was one of the initial potential buyers contacted by J.P. Morgan.  From GIP’s perspective, 19 
we immediately recognized that ALLETE represents a unique opportunity to invest in an 20 
entity that fits well with GIP’s core investment goals for the reasons described earlier in 21 
my Direct Testimony.  22 
 23 
Based on my understanding of Witness  Andrew Alley’s Direct Testimony on behalf of CPP 24 
Investments, a similar process unfolded with respect to CPP Investments as GIP was 25 
evaluating the potential Acquisition with ALLETE. Ultimately, GIP determined it could 26 
secure capital to fund at least 50  percent  of the Acquisition , and possibly more if GIP could 27 
participate in the Acquisition  jointly with additional equity partners.  GIP pursued 28 
opportunities to partner with other investors, but those discussions ended without 29 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
7 agreement. After CPP Investments went through a similar process, at the direction of the 1 
ALLETE Board of  Directors , representatives of J.P. Morgan introduced representatives at 2 
each of GIP and CPP Investments to allow the Partners to pursue the Acquisition  together. 3 
We were already familiar with CPP Investments and its management team and previously 4 
partnered with CPP Investments on  a prior infrastructure investment in Pacific National, a 5 
rail freight infrastructure company in Australia. The Partners began coordinating next steps 6 
in the potential acquisition, and in that process, it quickly became clear that the goals and 7 
capabilities of GIP and CPP Investments were an excellent fit for each other and for 8 
ALLETE.  9 
 10 
Q.  Is GIP’s investment in ALLETE intended to be a short -term or long -term 11 
investment?  12 
A. GIP’s investment in ALLETE is intended to be a long -term investment . ALLETE’s  13 
business plan involves significant growth of both generation and transmission operations  14 
over multiple decades drive n by Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard .  While these plans 15 
require significant investment in the near term, given the nature of utility regulation, GIP 16 
recognizes that earnings on those investments will be recovered over the long  term. Further, 17 
such investments require a significant amount of time to plan, permit, and execute, 18 
requiring a long -term orientation.  19 
 20 
V. DESCRIPT ION OF GIP  21 
Q. Please provide a summary of the topics you will address in this section of your Direct 22 
Testimony.  23 
A. In this section of my Direct Testimony, I will provide brief descriptions of the history of 24 
GIP, including  GIP’s  focus on infrastructure investment, brief descriptions of GIP Fund V, 25 
Tower Bridge and BlackRock  Inc. (“BlackRock”) , and the close fit of the Company  to 26 
GIP’s investment goals.    27 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
8 A. History and Investment Focus  1 
Q. Please briefly describe GIP and its  business focus.   2 
A. As explained above, GIP is the trading name for Global Infrastructure Management, LLC , 3 
an independent, specialist infrastructure fund manager . GIP  provides investment 4 
management services and advice to the GIP funds , which hold, indirectly, investments in 5 
portfolio companies. GIP’s investment approach is based on combining industry expertise 6 
with industr y best practice business management. GIP was founded in 2006 to pursue long - 7 
term investments in high -quality infrastructure assets and is focused on the energy 8 
transportation, digital , and water / waste sectors, each an area in which the GIP team has a 9 
depth of expertise and relationships.  10 
 11 
The first investment by a GIP Flagship Fund was made in 2008  and GIP currently manages 12 
approximately $115 billion on behalf of its investors (such as pension funds, endowments, 13 
insurance companies, and other sophisticated investors ) across a variety of funds. Through 14 
its Flagship Funds, GIP employs a differentiated investment strategy of targeting control - 15 
oriented investments in high -quality businesses of scale through focused and proprietary 16 
origination and the application of a rigorous and independent risk and ESG assessment 17 
process.  18 
 19 
Q. What is a fund manager?  20 
A. A fund manager is a business that specializes in forming investment funds and providing 21 
investment management and advice to the funds. The fund manager does not typically 22 
make any significant investments on its own behalf (although it may have limited 23 
ownership interests in funds) but acts as the manager of the funds that are formed and 24 
directs their investments.  25 
 26 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
9 Q. What is an investment fund?  1 
A. An investment fund is a business entity that is formed to invest in other businesses, which 2 
are typically referred to as portfolio companies. An investment fund raises money from 3 
investors and invests it on their behalf.  4 
 5 
Q. You mentioned there are other GIP funds – please provide a brief description of the 6 
GIP funds that preceded GIP Fund V.  7 
A. GIP is currently investing out of its fifth Flagship Fund, GIP Fund V, which is the fund 8 
that will hold the investment in ALLETE if the Acquisition is successfully completed. GIP 9 
Fund V is preceded by GIP Fund I, GIP Fund II, GIP Fund III and GIP Fund IV, each of 10 
which is briefly described below:  11 
 12

 13 
Note: Table excludes two additional potential investments in GIP Fund V , ALLETE and 14 
Malaysia Airports Holding Berhard “MAHB,” which have been announced but are subject 15 
to approvals and have not yet closed.  16 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
10  1 
Q. What is the status of GIP Fund V? 2 
A. GIP Fund V is currently fundraising with a target of $25.0 billion in aggregate 3 
commitments, the majority of which has already been raised as of December 12, 2024 , the 4 
date of this  Direct  Testimony .  5 
 6 
Q. Can you briefly explain how GIP funds are or ganized and managed?   7 
A. As I mentioned, GIP creates funds  for the purpose of raising capital from investors then 8 
deploying that capital by making certain types or categories of investments (such as an 9 
infrastructure fund that would have the purpose of investing in infrastructure including, 10 
among other things, public utilities).  GIP funds are commonly organized as a limited 11 
partnership , and w hen an investor commits to making a capital commitment to the fund, it 12 
becomes a limited partner in the fund limited partnership. These limited partners hold only 13 
passive interests in portfolio companies through the fund. The fund also has a general 14 
partner, which is controlled by GIP and participates alongside the limited partners in the 15 
investment s made by the fund , though the general partner generally does not have a 16 
significant ownership or financial stake in the fund. This structure allows GIP to provide 17 
clear lines of ownership and control of the assets in which each fund invests.  18 
 19 
The general partner of the fund is the entity that controls the fund and makes decisions 20 
about the fund’s operations and investment decisions. Through GIP’s control of the general 21 
partner entity, GIP makes investment decisions on behalf of the fund and determines 22 
whether to invest capital into specific companies, like ALLETE. The fund (i.e., the limited 23 
partnership) is the legal entity that makes the actual investment into companies and is the 24 
entity to which the limited partners and the general partner commit capital . The limited 25 
partners provide nearly all the capital to make the investments and receive investment 26 
income in return, but do not have control over the investment decisions.  This is the post - 27 
Acquisition structure shown in Figure 2 in and Attachment  A-2 to the Petition with respect 28 
to ALLETE. An investment committee of decision makers , including founders and senior 29 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
11 management members of GIP , sits at GIP’s general partner entity  and make s investment 1 
decisions on behalf of the general partner of GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge, with GIP 2 
providing advisor services.  3 
 4 
Q. How will GIP be compensated for its management services related to ALLETE?  5 
A. As with its other portfolio company investments, GIP’s primary compensation in relation 6 
to ALLETE will be through fees paid by investors in GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge  in 7 
return for investment management services  provided by GIP .  This is a standard private 8 
equity structure in which the management fees will be based on investor commitments and 9 
actual invested capital .  10 
 11 
Q. How do GIP’s goals for investments differ from a public shareholder’s goals in 12 
investing in stocks of a publicly traded company?  13 
A. There are different expectations, timelines, and risk levels between shareholders of publicly 14 
traded stock and a private equity fund. Public shareholders typically desire a regular 15 
payment of dividends or other forms of cash from their investments, whereas private 16 
investors are more focused on long -term investments and therefore have an ability and 17 
desire to exercise more patience by forgoing short -term quarterly earnings and dividends 18 
in favor of longer -term growth of the portfolio company and thus their investment. Public 19 
shareholders’ holdings are liquid, meaning they can exit or sell their holdings at any time. 20 
In contrast, GIP’s investment i n ALLETE is not liquid . Thus, while GIP and its investors 21 
operate on and commit capital based on a long -term investment assumption, public 22 
shareholders are not bound to any investment period and are able to (and often do) sell 23 
interests based on shorter -term considerations.  24 
 25 
Q. How does GIP’s focus on infrastructure investments affect specific portfolio 26 
companies like ALLETE ? 27 
A. GIP’s focus on and experience in  private equity infrastructure investments allow s GIP to 28 
provide unique support to its portfolio companies in a variety of ways. As discussed later 29 
in my Direct Testimony , GIP and CPP Investments both will provide  stable and consistent 30 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
12 access to equity  capital through the Acquisition but also can facilitate deep lending 1 
relationships to support the goals and needs of the Company . This support from the Partners 2 
will allow the Company to focus less on day -to-day market conditions and more on 3 
strategies and operations to meet customers’ needs and the State  of Minnesota ’s energy 4 
goals over the long term.  5 
  6 
Q. How does this type of support look in practice?  7 
A. GIP does not conduct the day -to-day operation of its portfolio companies .  As I have 8 
explained, the Partners ha ve committed to maintain the existing  ALLETE senior 9 
management team with the expectation that existing senior management will continue to 10 
operate the utility in the normal course and consistent with management functions. The 11 
support of the Partners will be an additional asset, helping to unlock value for customers 12 
while helping Minnesota Power  meet its goals and the policy goals of the State of 13 
Minnesota. GIP will provide  this support to the Company  through the appointment of 14 
experienced, professional board members who will cooperate with other board members 15 
and the current Company management. Furthermore, joint governance between GIP and 16 
CPP Investments will ensure that the expertise of each will be utilized and that the interests 17 
of the Partners  and the Company  are aligned. The stability that results ensures that the 18 
business plan is executed efficiently.    19 
 20 
An example from GIP’s current fund investments might be helpful.  To encourage 21 
alignment across our portfolio, GIP has formed a CEO Council of certain platform 22 
companies in the utility subsector to share best practices between its investments, 23 
including, for example, benefits of development knowledge, expertise, relationships, 24 
operations and maintenance best practices, and purchasing power. The CEO Council 25 
consists of the CEOs of Vena Energy, Clearway, Eolian, Skyborn and Atlas Renewable 26 
Energy, along with two GIP investment partners. This council allows GIP to provide 27 
through portfolio company board members valuable insight into options available to the 28 
company to capture value and mitigat e risk across multiple areas of the business . In this 29 
way, GIP’s experience provides a number of potential areas for collaboration with 30 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
13 ALLETE, including procurement, capex management, energy yield optimization, debt 1 
financing, tax equity , and other areas to share best practices. This is one way that GIP 2 
expects to be able to leverage its scale and capabilities to add value to Minnesota Power , 3 
its customers, and communities.  4 
 5 
Q. You mentioned that GIP invested in other utilities;  can you  give examples of some of 6 
those utility investments ?  7 
A. Yes, GIP has made several utility investments across previous GIP funds (GIP Fund III 8 
and GIP Fund  IV) and SMAs  (like Tower Bridge, which are  GIP-managed investment 9 
vehicles on behalf of single investors).  GIP currently owns a co-controlling stake  in 10 
Naturgy Energy Group (“Naturgy”) , which is one of the largest integrated utilities and 11 
infrastructure companies in Europe with over 3.8 million electric customers in Spain and 12 
over 1 million electric customers in Argentina and Panama. Naturgy  also owns gas utilities 13 
in Europe and Latin America serving over 10 million customers. GIP invested in Naturgy 14 
in September 2016  and during this period has invested €12.5  billion  of capex, of which 15 
€7.4 billion  was related to growth  projects, including  the addition of approximately 2 GW 16 
of renewable capacity (+65  percent  increase) and an approximately 30  percent  reduction 17 
in total greenhouse gas emissions relative to 2017 levels .   18 
 19 
GIP also owns a co -controlling stake in Scotia Gas Networks (“SGN”) , which is the second 20 
largest gas utility in the United Kingdom with assets in both England and Scotland, serving 21 
approximately 6 million customers. GIP invested in SGN through SMAs in March 2022  22 
and, in addition to expected upgrades and investments to maintain safety and deliver on 23 
long-term performance objectives , GIP  has helped SGN launch the world’s first 100  24 
percent  hydrogen -to-homes heating network, which is still under construction and will 25

15 Q. Does GIP have a specific focus when looking at potential  investments ?   1

GIP’s investment assessment process involves a rigorous and independent risk and ESG 3

portfolio companies.  GIP focuses on investments in these areas because GIP has 8 
determined that they present opportunities to deploy large amounts of capital that will result 9

focused and careful approach to new infrastructure investments.  12

operating Minnesota Power and its other utility and non -utility businesses , and ALLETE 4

to jointly govern through consent rights . As explained in Company Witness  Scissons ’ 6

responsibilities and authority to the current Board.  8

managed in a manner that builds long -term value for shareholders, customers, employees, 12 
and communities, continuing to focus on the current values, culture, and strategy of the 13 
Company.  The ALLETE B oard will continue to have an active role overseeing the 14 
Company’s strategy and approving the strategic direction of the Company, including any 15 
changes in long -term capital structure, significant transactions, and any entry into 16 
substantial new lines of business.  17

important commitments that help ensure consistency and representation of local interests 24 
on the ALLETE Board.  Maintaining local representation on the ALLETE B oard will help 25 
ensure the Board has the benefit of knowledge and information of local interests to factor 26 
into its decisions.  27

of capital from the Partners to support the needs of the Company.  Obtaining improved 18

volatile than relying on public equity financing.   Access to capital from the Partners also 20 
will help ALLETE overcome some of the challenges it could face obtaining equity in the 21 
public equity markets.  These benefit s are more fully explained in the Direct Testimon ies 22 
of Company Witness Joshua D. Taran  and Company and Partner Witness John D. 23 
Quackenbush.   24

and that is one of the primary reasons the Acquisition is beneficial to both the Partners and 4 
ALLETE, including Minnesota Power.  5

in decarbonization with regulated returns . To the extent that there are risks in achieving the 16 
capital plan, the  challenges factored into GIP’s valuation  and decision to invest .  The 17 
Acquisition will also benefit the Company  by allow ing it to access capital from the Partners 18 
when needed to support the reliability, safety, and development of evolving electricity 19

regulatory requirements, i ndividual investment decisions for Minnesota Power will 9

Carbon Free Standard .  18

interest s and needs of Minnesota Power and ALLETE more broadly.  Like any other 21

Minnesota Power continuing to provide safe, reliable, and affordable electricity service to 26 
customers and complying with the regulatory requirements of the Commission  and the 27 
policy goals of the State of Minnesota . In short, GIP’s investment will only do well if 28 
Minnesota Power does well, and GIP recognizes that substantial investments into 29

Anderson provides more information about how that will work at the ALLETE level 24 
following the Acquisition.   GIP is committed to following the Commission’s requirements 25 
related to affiliated interests, as protecting the integrity of its investments is a core part of 26 
GIP’s business model.    27 
 28 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
29 Q.  Will the Acquisition by the Partners impose significant added debt on ALLETE or 1 
the ownership structure of ALLETE?  2 
A. No.  The Acquisition is structured with very low debt leverage, expected to be $300 million 3 
of a total of $3.9 billion Acquisition price, which is less than 8 percent . This is unlike many 4 
Acquisitions, which often include debt financing for a substantial portion of the Acquisition 5 
price.  As I mentioned above, this debt will remain at the Alloy Parent level  and will not be 6 
additional debt of ALLETE .  Similarly, in connection with and following the Acquisition, 7 
the Partners commit that ALLETE will not lend to the Partners, Alloy Parent or its 8 
affiliates , nor will the Partners pledge the assets of ALLETE (including Minnesota Power  9 
utility assets) to secure debt of the Partners .  As explained by Company Witness Anderson, 10 
Minnesota Power assets will only be used as collateral for first mortgage bonds or other  11 
Company  debt. 12 
 13 
Q. Will there be some additional debt at the Alloy Parent level?  14 
A. We expect that Alloy  Parent  will carry some amount of debt in support of its obligations 15 
to ALLETE’s regulated and unregulated businesses, with the amount to be determined by 16 
Alloy  Parent  during the availability period of the obtained committed financing.  Any such 17 
debt would be held at the parent or holding company level, separate from the Minnesota 18 
Power utility.  ALLETE (and Minnesota Power) would not be an obligor under such debt, 19 
and none of the assets of ALLETE (including any assets of Minnesota Power) would be 20 
encumbered by liens securing such debt  for any entity other than ALLETE  and its 21 
subsidiaries .  This is a key component of our ring -fencing commitments that protects 22 
ALLETE and its customers and compliments the low level of debt leverage in the 23 
Acquisition.   24 
 25 
Q. Will the Acquisition lead to reduced compensation for ALLETE employees?  26 
A. No. As part of the Acquisition, the Partners agreed to provide each Company non- 27 
bargaining  employee who continues employment as of the effective time of the Acquisition 28 
with certain protections (generally for the two -year period following the Acquisition ), 29 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
30 including (1)  the same or better employment position in the same location as held by the 1 
Company employee immediately prior to the effective time, (2) a base salary or wage rate 2 
that is no less favorable than that provided to the Company employee immediately prior to 3 
the Acquisition , (3) aggregate annual and long -term incentive compensation target 4 
opportunities that are no less favorable than those provided to the Company employee 5 
immediately prior to the Acquisition , and (4) employee benefits that are no less favorable 6 
in the aggregate than those provided to the Company employee immediately prior to the 7 
Acquisition . The Partners have  also agreed to other customary employee protections, such 8 
as recognition of pre -Acquisition  service with the Company for benefit plan purposes, 9 
waiver of pre -existing condition limitations under post -Acquisition  health plans and credit 10 
for deductibles and co -payments under post -closing plans for the year of the Acquisition . 11 
 12 
Q. Will ALLETE’s collective bargaining agreements  continue to be honored after the 13 
Partners become the owners?  14 
A. Yes.  With respect to each Company employee who is covered by a Company collective 15 
bargaining agreement , Alloy  Parent will cause the Company  or its applicable subsidiary to 16 
honor the collective bargaining agreements  in effect at the effective time of the Merger 17 
Agreement.  18 
 19 
Q. Will ALLETE’s non-bargaining  employee s and their compensation level be retained 20 
after the Partners become the owners of ALLETE?  21 
A. Yes.  The Merger Agreement provides Company non-barga ining employees who continue 22 
employment as of the effective time of the Merger Agreement with protections (generally 23 
for the two -year period following the Merger), including the employee protections I 24 
mentioned above.  25 
 26 
Q. Will the Acquisition lead to cross subsidy or self-dealing?  27 
A. No. GIP will benefit from the Acquisition by virtue of ensuring ALLETE remains 28 
successful and deploys capital consistent with its plans for growth and investment , not by 29 
cross -subsidization or self -dealing . After the close of the Acquisition, the Commission’s 30 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
31 authority over Minnesota Power and its Minnesota operations will continue unchanged, 1 
including protections against subsidization. As evidenced by various commitments 2 
provided in the Merger Agreement and Petition, a detailed list of which is provided in the 3 
Petition at page 20, ALLETE will maintain certain corporate separateness (i.e., “ring - 4 
fencing”) commitments that will help protect against any risk of cross -subsidization or self - 5 
dealing.   Company and Partner Witness Lapson also explains the ring -fencing proposed by 6 
ALLETE and the Partners.    7 
 8 
Q. Will the Acquisition lead to reduced service quality?  9 
A. No, the Acquisition will not reduce the quality of service provided by ALLETE or 10 
Minnesota Power. The Partners recognize that Minnesota Power has been consistently 11 
focused on maintaining reasonable costs and a high quality of service for decades, 12 
consistent with its ongoing constructive relationships with stakeholders and the 13 
Commission. The purpose of the Acquisition is not to change the nature or quality of 14 
service provided by the utility. Rather, the driving force for the Acquisition is the need for 15 
capital that can facilitate future investments necessary to serve customers, not cutting costs ; 16 
cutting costs  could negatively impact Minnesota Power’s effective operations and high 17 
quality of service, both of which are key attributes that make ALLETE an attractive 18 
investment.  19 
 20 
GIP also recognizes that Minnesota Power, which is the core businesses of ALLETE, has 21 
an obligation to provide safe, reliable, and affordable service to customers, and that the 22 
provision of this service is subject to close regulation by the Commission.  23 
 24 
Q. Does the Acquisition reduce or alter the Commission’s oversight authority ?  25 
A. No.  There is nothing about the Acquisition that reduces Commission oversight or 26 
regulatory authority , and GIP has no intention of reducing regulatory oversight or seeking 27 
to modify the regulatory environment in which Minnesota Power operates.  The regulated 28 
status of Minnesota Power was one of the main features of the Acquisition that was 29 
attractive to the Partners. The regulated nature of Minnesota Power is attractive to GIP 30 
 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bram  Direct  
 
32 because it will provide  for a stable stream of returns on the significant investments that 1 
must be made in the coming years, subject to appropriate oversight from the Commission. 2 
Furthermore, the Merger Agreement contains commitments to maintain current oversight 3 
and as I explained above, t he day -to-day operations of Minnesota Power will be conducted  4 
by the same individuals operating the business prior to the Acquisition and under the same 5 
regulatory oversight.  6 
 7 
VIII. CONCLUSION  8 
Q. Please summarize the conclusions of your Direct Testimony.  9 
A. The Company  need s external equity to fund the unprecedented increase in capital 10 
expenditures needed to meet Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard.  The Partners’ long -term 11 
investment goals will provide  the Company  with a reliable source of that equity capital that 12 
is insulated from the short -term pressures of the public equity market.  The Partners’ long - 13 
term goals and priorities, enhanced by their extensive experience with infrastructure 14 
investment in renewable energy, are an optimal match for the Company .  The Partners will 15 
also continue ALLETE’s and Minnesota Power’s commitments to their stakeholders and 16 
will not cause risks for ALLETE or Minnesota Power.  The Acquisition will position 17 
Minnesota Power to achieve its long -term goals to comply with Minnesota policy 18 
requirements, such as the Carbon Free Standard, while continuing to provide safe, reliable, 19 
and affordable service to its customers. As a result, the Acquisition is in the public interest 20 
and should be approved.   21 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony?  22 
A. Yes. 23

content:
Direct Testimony  
Andrew Alley  
 
 
 Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
 
State of Minnesota  
 
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada  
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
  
 
 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339

CPP INVESTMENTS INTRODUCTION AND ACQUISITION SUPPORT  
 
 
 
 
 
December  12, 2024
TABLE OF CONTENTS  
 
Page

OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  
1 
 I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and employer.   2 
A. My name is Andrew Alley  and I am Managing Director, Head of Infrastructure, North 3 
America & Australasia at  Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”).   4 
 5 
Q. Please summarize your responsibilities at CPP Investments.   6 
A. In my role at  CPP Investments, I am responsible for overseeing the infrastructure 7 
investments and operations of CPP Investments in North America, Australia , and Asia  8 
(excluding India),  which includes finding, evaluating, executing , and managing  investment 9 
opportunities in those regions . I ensure that the portfolio is optimized and aligned with the 10 
organization ’s strategic priorities.   11 
 12 
Q. Have you included a description of your educational qualifications and professional 13 
experience?   14 
A. Yes, a description of my qualifications and experience is included as  CPP-GIP Exhibit  ___ 15 
(Alley), Direct  Schedule  1. I am Managing Director , Head of Infrastructure , North America 16 
& Australasia for CPP  Investments . I have served in senior roles in Infrastructure in our 17 
Hong Kong, Sydney, London , and Toronto offices . Prior to joining CPP  Investments  in 18 
October  2007, I worked in the Energy Investment Banking group at RBC Capital Markets 19 
in Calgary, Alberta and in the Business Development group at Pengrowth Energy Trust . I 20 
hold an MBA from the Richard Ivey School of Business at the University of Western 21 
Ontario and a BA, Finance from Michigan State University . I am a Chartered Financial 22 
Analyst  (“CFA ”) Charterholder . I am currently on the boards of  the following businesses:  23 
407 International, Transurban Chesapeake , and PT Lintas Marga Sedaya (Cipali).1 24 
 25 
 
1 These are companies in which CPP Investment s has made investments  and that own toll roads located in Ontario, 
Canada , the greater Washington DC a rea, and Indonesia , respectively .  
2 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  Q. What is the purpose of your Direct Testimony?   1 
A. My testimony provide s the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (“ Commission ”) with 2 
a better understanding of CPP Investments, its relationship with Global Infrastructure 3 
Partners  (“GIP” ) (GIP and CPP Investments  together, the “Partners”), and the present 4 
transaction in which entities managed by the Partners will become the owners of  ALLETE, 5 
Inc. and Minnesota Power2 (the “Acquisition”) . Specifically, I provide information about 6 
CPP Investments , its interest in ALLETE , and its proposed 40 percent ownership of 7 
ALLETE, a s well as  the benefits of private investment for utilities with energy transition 8 
goals, specific public interest benefits of the Acquisition, and an overview of the operation 9 
and management of ALLETE following the Acquisition.  10 
 11 
Q. Please provide a brief overview of your Direct Testimony.   12 
A. My Direct Testimony will provide a brief overview of the Application. I will then describe 13 
CPP Investments, our investment mission, and why we are interested in acquiring 14 
ALLETE. Finally, I will describe the benefits of the Acquisition and provide information 15 
about why the Acquisition is in the public interest and should be approved.   16 
 17 
II. THE PETITION  18 
Q. What sections  of the Petition do you sponsor?  19 
A. I sponsor the following sections  of the Petition:  20 
• Section  II.B.1:  CPP Investments;  21 
• Section  II.C: Description of the Acquisition (as to post -Acquisition organizational  22 
structure);  23 
• Section  III.B.3:  The Reasons for the Acquisition  are Sound (as to the Partners’ 24 
interest in the Acquisition);  25 
• Section  III.B. 4: Commitments to Minnesota (as to CPP Investments ); 26 
 
2 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc . Throughout this Direct Testimony and the 
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility . Unless otherwise specifically defined, references to 
“ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota Power and all regulated and 
non-regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a M innesota Power.  
3 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  • Section  IV.B.1.h:  Statement on affiliated interest (Minn . R. 7825.1400, Subp . H); and  1 
• Section  IV.D.3:  A list and past history of all contracts or agreements between the 2 
petitioner and affiliated interest, consideration received, and summary of costs.  3 
 4 
Q. What Attachments to the Petition do you sponsor?  5 
A. I sponsor  the following Attachments to the Petition:  6 
• Attachment A -2: Post-Acquisition Organizational Structure ; and 7 
• Attachment B: Agreement and Plan of Merger (as to CPPIB).  8 
 9 
III. OVERVIEW OF C ANADA PENSION PLAN  AND CPP INVESTMENTS  10 
A. History  and Mission  11 
Q. Please describe  the history  of the Canada Pension Plan and its  mission and mandate .  12 
A. The Canada Pension Plan (the “CPP”) was created in 1965 pursuant to the Canada Pension 13 
Plan  Act (the “CPP Act”),3 which is described in the statute as “ [a]n Act to establish a 14 
comprehensive program of old age pensions and supplementary benefits in Canada payable 15 
to and in respect of contributors .” The underlying goal of the CPP is to help ensure all 16 
workers in Canada have a minimum level of financial security in retirement, and to provide 17 
income support through disability, death, survivor, children’s , and post -retirement benefits 18 
for eligible contributors and their families . The CPP is funded by the contributions of 19 
employees, employers, and self-employed persons , as well as revenue earned by CPP 20 
Investments . It covers substantially all employed and self -employed people in Canada, 21 
excluding Quebec, which operates its own plan . As of March  2024, the CPP has more than 22 
22 million participating contributors and beneficiaries.  23 
 24 
Q. What is CPP Investments  and how is it related to the CPP ? 25 
A. As noted above, the CPP was created in 1965 and originally was solely funded from 26 
contributions of employees, employers , and self -employed persons  to the CPP. As 27 
Canada’s demographics and economy evolved, the premiums being paid into the CPP 28 
 
3 Canada Pension Plan , https://laws -lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/c -8/page -1.html#h -167616 .  
4 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  became insufficient to cover the benefits drawn by contributors , jeopardizing  the CPP’s 1 
ability to pay pensions in the long run.  2 
 3 
In 1997,  CPP Investments was created pursuant to an act of Parliament , the Canada Pension 4 
Plan Investment Board Act (the “CPPIB Act”) .4 CPP Investments invests the funds 5 
transferred to it from the CPP that are not currently needed to pay benefits in an effort to 6 
grow the CPP fund in the best interests of the CPP contributors and beneficiaries . The 7 
returns on those investments are used to fund the benefits provided by  the CPP. Today , 8 
CPP Investments manages CAD $675. 1 billion in assets, with over 2,000 employees 9 
worldwide and investments in 56 countries.5  10 
 11 
Q. How  does CPP Investments  obtain funds from the CPP ? 12 
A. The CPP transfers to CPP Investments funds  collected from CPP contributors that are not 13 
immediately required to pay CPP benefits . Following the transfer, these  funds are legally 14 
and beneficially owned by CPP Investments and are invested in CPP Investments’ own 15 
name and legal capacity.  16 
 17 
Q. Please summarize the role of CPP Investments.  18 
A. CPP Investments is a professional investment management organization . It is not a pension 19 
fund, pension plan, or pension plan administrator, and was structured to ensure its 20 
independence . Its investment decision -making  is overseen by an independent Board of 21 
Directors . CPP Investments ’ mandate , the “investment -only mandate ,” is set forth in the 22 
CPPIB Act , which states that the “objects” of CPP Investments are to: (a) assist the CPP in 23 
meeting its obligations to contributors and beneficiaries under the CPP; (b) manage 24 
amounts transferred to it under the CPP Act in the best interests of CPP contributors and 25 
beneficiaries; and (c) invest its assets with a view to achieving a maximum rate of return, 26 
without undue risk of loss, having regard to the factors that may affect the funding of the 27 
 
4 197 S.C. ch.40 (Can.) of 1997, available at https://laws -lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C -8.3/. Note that the CPPIB Act 
applies only to CPP Investments; other Canadian pension funds are governed by separate statutes.  
5 These figures are as of September  30, 2024 , and therefore differ slightly from those contained in the Petition.   
5 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  CPP and the ability of the CPP to meet its financial obligations on any given business day .6 1 
CPP Investments’ investment strategy is informed by the CPPIB Act, its guiding principles, 2 
and investment beliefs , as I discuss herein  and as described more fully in CPP Investment s’ 3 
Annual Report .7 I also describe CPP Investments’ investment -only mandate in more detail 4 
below .  5 
 6 
Q. Is CPP  or any Canadian governmental authority involved in the investment decisions 7 
of CPP Investments?  8 
A. No. CPP Investments operates independently of the CPP and at arm’s length from both the 9 
Canadian federal government and Canadian provincial governments . As defined in the CPP 10 
Act, the purpose of CPP Investments  is to help CPP provide a foundation upon which 11 
contributors and beneficiaries can build their financial security in retirement  and to 12 
contribute to the financial strength of the CPP by maximizing returns without undue risk 13 
of loss . Importantly , CPP Investment s’ Parliamentary mandate does not allow for any 14 
Canadian Government involvement in its decision -making or any secondary policy -related 15 
objectives (absent Parliamentary legislation to introduce a change).   16 
 17 
Q. Please explain CPP Investment s’ independence from Canadian provincial and federal 18 
governments.   19 
A. The CPPIB Act establishes a governance model premised on CPP Investments operating 20 
free from political interference so that it can effectively achieve its statutory investment 21 
mandate . The governance system created under the CPPIB Act is recognized worldwide as 22 
a leading standard for national pension plans . The CPPIB Act prohibits  CPP Investments 23 
from making investments for the purpose of implementing, advancing , or promoting 24 
policies of any government . CPP Investments may not in any way be directed by the 25 
government as to which investments it may make . CPP Investments does not submit its 26 
investment strategy, business plan , or compensation policies for government approval . 27 
 
6 CPPIB Act at §  5. 
7 CPP Investments’ Annual Report is available at https://www.cppinvestments.com/wp -
content/uploads/2024/07/CPP -Investments -F2024 -Annual -Report.pdf . 
6 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  Moreover, CPP Investments’ Code of Conduct expressly provides that directors, officers 1 
and employees shall not allow any of its business activities to be subject to political 2 
interference . The CPPIB Act further assures  CPP Investments’ independence, as the 3 
legislation itself can only be changed by agreement by both the federal government  and 4 
two-thirds of the participating provinces  that also represent two -thirds of the population.  5 
 6 
Q. What is the investment -only mandate?  7 
A. As discussed above, CPP Investments’ “investment -only mandate” is set forth in the 8 
CPPIB Act . This mandate  prohibits CPP Investments from engaging in activities other than 9 
investing its assets . CPP Investments and its employees limit their involvement to an 10 
investment management role, for example, by appointing directors and permitting those 11 
directors to prudently exercise their duties as contemplated within the applicable 12 
governance structure . CPP Investments and its employees do not perform the fu nctions of 13 
the senior officers or managers and do not otherwise participate in the day -to-day 14 
managerial or operational control of any of the companies  in which it invests .    15 
 16 
Q. Is CPP Investments’ approach to investment long -term or short -term?  17 
A. CPP Investments takes a long -term approach to investing because Canadians will continue 18 
to contribute to the CPP and draw on their benefits in perpetuity . To ensure that these  19 
investments will be available  in the long -term, Canada’s Office of the Chief Actuary of 20 
Canada, an independent federal body, asses ses the state of the  plan every three  years . The 21 
most recent review, completed in December  2022, concluded that the CPP will continue to 22 
be sustainable for 75 years and beyond.   23 
 24 
Q. How does the mission of CPP  affect CPP Investments’ overall approach to investing?   25 
A. As explained above, t he CPP must serve Canadians for many generations to come . As a 26 
result, CPP Investments has a longer investment horizon than many other types of 27 
investors . CPP Investments can assess the prospects of its strategies and opportunities over 28 
decades, not just over quarters or years . CPP Investments can withstand short -term 29 
downturns to create value over the long run, particularly  in contrast to public equity 30 
7 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  investors,  which often  take a shorter -term approach  to stock price and the need for dividend 1 
payments . As a result, public equity investors may be more limited than CPP Investments 2 
in their ability to invest or retain investments where the benefits are expected to be fully 3 
realized over a longer -term horizon . 4 
 5 
Q. Please describe how private investments fit into CPP Investment s’ strategy.   6 
A. Private investments play a vital role in CPP Investments’ strategy by providing 7 
diversification, long-term growth potential, access to unique investments, alignment of 8 
interests, and superior risk -adjusted returns . Private investments help CPP Investments 9 
fulfill its statutory mandate to maximize returns for the CPP while managing risk and 10 
ensuring the long -term financial security of Canadian retirees.  11 
 12 
Q. Please describe how CPP Investments approaches private investments.   13 
A. CPP Investments takes a comprehensive and strategic approach to private investments, 14 
leveraging its scale, expertise , and long -term perspective . In particular, CPP Investments 15 
invests in a wide range of private assets globally, both directly and with partners like GIP . 16 
In contrast to investments made in public companies, private investments are less liquid  17 
because  they cannot be sold readily into established market s, and therefore CPP 18 
Investments focus es on earning returns through a long er-term strategy and value creation.  19 
 20 
B. CPP Investments ’ Organization al Structure  21 
Q. Please explain how CPP Investments is organized.   22 
A. CPP Investments  employs a diversified investment strategy, allocating assets across public 23 
equities, private equities , fixed income , and real assets  to build a balanced portfolio . The 24 
Acquisition is managed through CPP Investments’ infrastructure group, which is part of 25 
the real assets department . Real asset investments include investments in conventional and 26 
renewable energies, infrastructure, and real estate  globally . Reflecting the complex nature 27 
of its investments , CPP Investments organizes  its investments through subsidiaries and 28 
investment vehicles, as discussed further below .  29 
 30 
8 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  Q. Does  CPP Investments have a particular focus on  any types of investments or 1 
projects?   2 
A. CPP Investment s’ focus is on  fulfilling its mandate, rather than being  focused on any 3 
specific sector or type of project . Over CPP Investments’ 25 -year history, it has generated , 4 
and continue s to generate , returns by remaining focused on the long term and on building 5 
diversified portfolios with robust governance and risk management . To achieve maximum 6 
returns without undue risk of loss, CPP Investments’ investments span multiple asset 7 
classes  and geographic jurisdictions . This diversification is reflected through CPP 8 
Investments’ different Investment Departments , including the real assets  department, 9 
through which the ALLETE transaction  is being executed . CPP Investments’ sector, 10 
geographical , and operational expertise  enables such diverse investments , leveraging CPP 11 
Investments’ global relationships to identify and access differentiated investment 12 
opportunities at scale . CPP Investments’  flexibility of capital and legislative mandate 13 
enable it to invest in the areas of greatest relative value . Engaged management of CPP 14 
Investments’ assets and portfolio , including focusing on investments in entities with strong 15 
management teams,  further enable s CPP Investments  to maximize value creation at all 16 
stages of the investment life cycle  while respecting the investment -only mandate .  17 
 18 
C. CPP Investments’ Experience and Expertise in the Energy Industry  19 
Q. How does the energy industry fit into CPP Investments’ strategy?  20 
A. As an institutional investor with a broad global portfolio, CPP Investments invests across 21 
the energy sector, including investments related to the energy transition . CPP Investments 22 
also has deep expertise across utilities, midstream  energy companies , and energy 23 
generation and has strategically partnered with numerous companies across these sectors.   24 
 25 
Q. How do climate -related considerations fit into that approach?  26 
A. As a long -term investor, CPP Investments consider s sustainability -related factors to make 27 
more informed decisions to deliver strong  long-term investment outcomes, in alignment 28 
with its legislative mandate.  CPP Investments’ diversified investment strategy affords 29 
flexibility to invest across asset classes and into all types of climate change -related 30 
9 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  opportunities . Effective management of sustainability risks and opportunities is one of the 1 
ways companies can preserve and increase their value over the long term . CPP Investments 2 
recognizes that climate commitments at various levels of governments represent an 3 
investment opportunity and that its performance will be contingent on the ability of CPP 4 
Investments and the companies in which it invests to adapt to those climate commitments.      5 
 6 
Q. Does  CPP Investments have  investments in other utilities?   7 
A. Yes. CPP Investments  holds substantial  investments in utility and energy companies , many 8 
of which  are in  the United States . For example, CPP Investment s’ portfolio includes 9 
ownership interests in Essential Utilities , Pattern Energy Group LP , and Cordelio Power 10 
LP. Through these investments and otherwise, CPP Investment s has been involved in the 11 
development and upstream ownership of large energy infrastructure projects, including 12 
renewable generation facilities and geothermal and battery storage facilities . CPP 13 
Investments’ ownership in Cordelio Power LP includes an investment in approximately 14 
650 megawatts (“ MW”) of wind and solar facilit ies in the Midcontinent Independent 15 
System Operator, Inc. market in the United States . Additionally, through Pattern, CPP  16 
Investments  has been involved in the development of significant transmission projects , 17 
such as SunZia Transmission , LLC’s ongoing development  of two approximately 550 - 18 
mile, single circuit, 500 kilovolt (“ kV”) transmission lines in New Mexico and Arizona . In 19 
addition, CPP Investments has made numerous investments in regulated infrastructure 20 
assets both in the United States  and globally . These investments includ e Puget Energy, Inc. 21 
(“Puget Energy”) (owns Washington electric and gas utility), Essential Utilities  (owns 22 
Pennsylvania water and gas utility) , Transelec SA (Chilean electricity transmission), 23 
Nedgia (Spanish gas distribution), and Iguá Saneamento  (Brazilian water utility) . 24 
 25 
Q. Please describe the investment in Puget Energy.   26 
A. CPP Investments ’ past investment s include a successful  partnership with Puget Sound 27 
Energy (“ PSE”), through its parent, Puget Energy,  the largest electric and gas utility in 28 
Washington state with over 1.2  million customers, through  a take -private transaction . CPP 29 
Investments alongside a consortium of financial investor s reached an agreement to take 30 
10 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  Puget  Energy  private at a total cost of approximately $7.4 billion .8 The transaction closed 1 
in 2009 after receiving all requisite regulatory approvals , including approval from the 2 
Washington Utilities and Transport ation  Commission  (“WUTC”) . This partnership 3 
enabled Puget Energy to execute its long -term growth strategy and accelerate its 4 
decarbonization efforts.  5 
 6 
CPP Investments  was interest ed in Puget Energy for many of the same reasons it is 7 
interested in ALLETE . Regulated utilities provide stable long-term cash flows that fit with 8 
CPP Investments ’ investment strategy to focus on the long -term health of the CPP . A 9

Alley  Direct  a key component of our ring -fencing commitments that protects ALLETE and its 1 
customers and compliments the low level of debt leverage in the Acquisition.   2 
 3 
Q. Will the Acquisition impose on Minnesota Power customers transaction costs, 4 
transition costs, or recovery of an acquisition  premium?   5 
A.  Both Partners have explicitly agree d that t he Acquisition of A LLETE  will not result in the 6 
impos ition of  transaction costs or transition costs, or involve the recovery of an acquisition 7 
premium from  Minnesota Power customers . These commitments ensure that any financial 8 
burden of the Acquisition will not be passed on to Minnesota Power’s customers so as to 9 
protect them from costs associated with the transaction.  10 
 11 
Q. Will the Acquisition lead to reduced compensation or job loss for ALLETE 12 
employees?   13 
A.  The Partners have structured the A cquisition to protect the interests of A LLETE  14 
employees  to ensur e that employee  compensation and benefits remain intact , provided that 15 
the employee remains in good standing . The Partners have committed across multiple 16 
public filings that t he Acquisition will not lead to reduced compensation for A LLETE  17 
employees . The Partners have committed in the Merger Agreement to maintain the current 18 
senior management team and to honor existing collective bargaining agreements and union 19 
contracts , to retain non -bargaining  employees at no less than current compensation levels, 20 
and to maintain benefit levels . Many of the companies in which CPP Investments invests 21 
have unionized workforces and, as a long -term investor, CPP Investments has  seen the 22 
importance of constructive labor relations in producing positive outcomes for all 23 
stakeholders.  24 
 25 
Q. Will the Acquisition lead to cross subsidies or self -dealing?   26 
A. No. Cross subsidiz ing operations or engag ing in self -dealing  goes against CPP 27 
Investments’ investment approach . There are a number of reasons for this . First, given its 28 
investment -only mandate, CPP Investments does not participate in the day -to-day 29 
operation of its investments , and accordingly  would not be able to  identify opportunities 30 
27 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  for, or engage in any type of , cross subsidization or self -dealing . This mandate is the 1 
cornerstone of CPP Investments’ approach to investment . Second, ring-fencing 2 
commitments in the Merger Agreement , such as t he appointment of independent directors 3 
to the A LLETE  Board  to ensur e impartial oversight  and maintain ing corporate 4 
separateness , will insulat e ALLETE  from self-dealing risks . As a first principle, 5 
operational and regulatory strategies and decisions will continue to rest with management . 6 
Significant transactions will require approval processes involving  proposals brought to  the 7 
ALLETE Board on the recommendation of management for approval where necessary , 8 
which will prevent self -dealing and ensur e arm’s length transactions . In addition, even if 9 
either Partner wanted to engage in self-dealing (which they do not), neither would be able 10 
to engage in self -dealing without harming the other, and therefore it is in the interest of 11 
both parties to serve as a check on the other to prevent any self-dealing . Finally, the Federal 12 
Energy Regulatory Commission (“FERC”) , the Commission , and the Public Service 13 
Commission of Wisconsin  (“PSCW ”) all impose and oversee r egulatory conditions that 14 
will ensure compliance with regulatory requirements with respect to self -dealing . 15 
 16 
 Q. Will the Acquisition adversely affect the quality of service provided by Minnesota 17 
Power ?  18 
A. No. It is not in the interest of the Partners to reduce service quality . As mentioned above, 19 
the quality of ALLETE’s operations  was part of what attracted CPP Investments to the 20 
Acquisition , and maintaining quality of service to Minnesota Power customers benefit s not 21 
only customers, but other stakeholders, including  CPP Investments and GIP, in light of 22 
their long-term investment strategy . The Merger Agreement include s several safeguards to 23 
ensure service quality is maintained , such as the appointment of local representation to the 24 
Board and committing to maintain historic levels of economic development and charitable 25 
contributions in service territories for five years after closing . A reduction in service quality 26 
would be adverse to CPP Investments’ interests and commitments to building and 27 
maintaining the long -run success of Minnesota Power . CPP Investments recognizes that 28 
owning a public utility in Minnesota comes with the obligation to provide safe, reliable, 29 
28 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  and affordable utility service to customers, to comply with all Minnesota requirements, and 1 
to be closely regulated by the Commission.  2 
 3 
 CPP Investments recognizes that providing high -quality service is core to the success of 4 
the Company . In order for CPP Investments’ investment in ALLETE to be successful, 5 
Minnesota Power needs to be successful  and maintain its strong relationships with 6 
stakeholders and with the Commission . CPP Investments’ incentives are aligned with those 7 
of Minnesota Power and its customers.  8 
 9 
Q Will the Acquisition lead to loss of regulatory oversight?   10 
A. No. The transaction is subject to regulatory approval from FERC , the Commission , and the 11 
PSCW . FERC, the Commission , and PSCW will continue to exercise regulatory oversight 12 
over ALLETE  to ensure compliance with all relevant laws and standards . The Merger 13 
Agreement  also explicitly includes commitments to maintain regulatory compliance , and 14 
ALLETE’s  governance structure includes provisions for maintaining corporate 15 
separateness between A LLETE’ s regulated and unregulated businesses . Although 16 
ALLETE will no longer be subject to oversight applicable to public companies, in its 17 
capacity as a public utility,  Minnesota Power  will continue to be subject to the 18 
comprehensive regulatory regime governing public utilities.  19 
   20 
V. CONCLUSION  21 
Q. Please summarize the conclusions of your Direct Testimony.  22 
A. The Company is  in need of access to a significant amount of equity to fund the substantial 23 
increase in capital expenditures required to satisfy Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard. The 24 
Partners have long -term investment goals and are well -positioned to provide the Company  25 
with a reliable and stable source of equity capital that is not subject to the same pressures 26 
that exist in the public equity market. CPP Investments’ investment -only mandate and 27 
priorities, coupled with its extensive experience with infrastructure investment and 28 
development, are an optimal match for the Company . In addition, CPP Investments ’ 29 
priorities align with those of the Company  on multiple fronts, including a commitment to 30 
29 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Alley  Direct  a sustainable, clean -energy future  that continues to provide  safe, reliable, and affordable 1 
energy services to customers . The Partners also do not expect the Acquisition to introduce 2 
any material risks , and for all of these reasons, the Acquisition is in the public interest and 3 
should be approved.    4 
 5 
Q. Does this conclude your testimony?  6 
A. Yes. 7

 Ann E. Bulkley

Bulkley  Direct and Schedule  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and business address.  2 
A.  My name is Ann E. Bulkley.  My business address is One Beacon Street, Suite 3 
2600, Boston, Massachusetts 02108.  4 
 5 
Q. By whom are you employed and in what position?  6 
A.  I am a Principal at The Brattle Group (“Brattle”).  7 
 8 
Q. Please summarize your qualifications and experience.  9 
A.  I hold a Bachelor’s degree in Economics and Finance from Simmons College and 10 
a Master’s degree in Economics from Boston University, with more than 25 years 11 
of experience consulting to the energy industry.  I have advised numerous energy 12 
and utility clients on a wide range of financial and economic issues with primary 13 
concentrations in valuation and utility rate matters.  Many of these assignments 14 
have included the determination of the cost of capital for valuation and ratemaking 15 
purposes.  I have included my qualifications  as MP Exhibit  ___ (Bulkley), Direct 16 
Schedule 1 to this testimony.  17 
 18 
Q. Have you ever testified in any other proceeding?  19 
A.  Yes. I have testified in multiple regulatory proceedings, including before the 20 
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (“Commission”). I have included a 21 
summary of testimony that I have filed in other proceedings as part of  MP Exhibit 22 
___ (Bulkley), Direct Schedule 1 to this testimony.  23 
 24 
 
2 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  Q. On whose behalf are you testifying?  1 
A.  I am submitting this Direct Testimony before the Commission on behalf of 2 
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power ,1 as well as Canada Pension Plan Investment 3 
Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”).  4 
 5 
Q. What is the purpose of your Direct Testimony?  6 
A.  The purpose of my Direct Testimony is to provide the Commission with 7 
information regarding how the  return on equity (“ROE”) and overall rate of return 8 
can be analyzed for Minnesota Power following the acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. 9 
by CPP Investments and GIP  (CPP Investments and GIP together, the “Partners”) 10 
(the “Acquisition”) .  I do not make any specific proposals regarding ROE , as this 11 
is not a cost recovery proceeding.  Rather, I first provide information about 12 
consolidation in the energy industry, underscoring that other commissions have 13 
also considered transactions and therefore have needed to (and been able to) 14 
consider cost of capital determination processes  for utilities post -merger or 15 
acquisition.  I also provide insight into the reasons  why the established process for 16 
determining  a utility’s  authorized cost of capital  in Minnesota, primarily  via a proxy 17 
group , well -known  ROE models , and comparisons to other authorized ROEs,  will 18 
be unchange d as a result of the Acquisition.  19 
 20 
 Q. Are you sponsoring any exhibits in this proceeding?  21 
A.  Yes. I am sponsoring MP Exhibit ___ (Bulkley), Direct Schedule 1 to my Direct 22 
Testimony . 23 
 24 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Direct Testimony and 
the Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise 
specifically defined, references to “ALLETE” i ndicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including 
Minnesota Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general 
reference to ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
 
3 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  II. CONSOLIDATION AND ACQUISITIONS IN THE ELECTRIC UTILITY 1 
INDUSTRY  2 
Q. What is the purpose of this section of your Direct Testimony?  3 
A. This section of my Direct Testimony d iscusses  the consolidation of the regulated 4 
electric utility industry and the expectations of investors  in the regulated electric 5 
utility industry .  I provide this information as a backdrop for the later discussion in 6 
my Direct Testimony of how a utility’s risk and cost of capital is assessed post - 7 
merger or acquisition.  8 
 9 
Q. To what extent has the industry faced transactions involving the acquisition of 10 
publicly traded electric utilities ?   11 
A.  As shown  below, over the past 30 years, the electric utility indust ry has experienced 12 
significant consolidation. In 1995, there were 95 companies classified by Value 13 
Line as regulated electric utilities. Since that time, there has been steady 14 
consolidation of the industry and currently there remain 39 companies that are 15 
classified by Value Line as regulated electric utilities. The majority of these 16 
companies are holding companies that are predominantly regulated but do also have 17 
unregulated operations.  18 
 
4 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  Figure 1: Number of Investor - Owned Utilities 1995 -20232 1 
  2 
 3 
Q. Is the consolidation in the industry limited to utility company mergers?  4 
A.  No. Some of these transactions that the Commission has had experience with are 5 
utility mergers, such as the acquisition of Minnesota Energy Resources 6 
Corporation ’s (“MERC”) parent company Integrys Energy Group by what is now 7 
WEC Energy Group, the acquisition of Minnegasco by Reliant Energy, and the 8 
consolidation of Northern States Power (“NSP”), Southwestern Public Service 9 
(“SPS”) and Public Service of Colorado (“PSCo”) into Xcel Energy .  However , 10 
infrastructure partners and other investors have been acquiring utility companies 11 
over this time period.  12 
 13 
Q. Please provide examples of utility company acquisitions that are not the 14 
merger or consolidation of regulated utility operations.  15 
A.  Berkshire Hathaway Energy has acquired several utilities over time, specifically, 16 
MidAmerican Energy, PacifiCorp, Rocky Mountain Power, Nevada Power and 17 
Sierra Pacific Power.  18
