Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule   1 
Q. Do investment fund owners consider the risk of utility operations and available 2 
returns on equity in their investments?  3 
A. Yes.  As discussed in the Petition, the Partners bring sector expertise and long -term 4 
capital support that can be used to finance the investments in the Company’s clean 5 
energy transition. These funds are often focused on investments in certain 6 
industries ; in this case, the general  infrastructure investment . However, the purpose 7 
of the Partners’ investments is to maximize the return on its investments for 8 
investors, commensurate with the risk of the investment portfolio.  Therefore, they 9 
do consider the risk of utility operations in setting their expectations regarding the 10 
return requirements for the investment.  11 
 12 
Q. What market evidence demonstrates that investment funds consider the risk 13 
of the utility operations they own?  14 
A. In his February 2024 letter to Shareholders, Berkshire Hathaway Chief Executive 15 
Officer Warren Buffett noted the unexpected risks associated with the regulatory 16 
risk faced by the company’s utility holdings through Berkshire Hathaway Energy 17 
(“BHE”).  18 
Our second and even more severe earnings disappointment last 19 
year occurred at BHE. Most of its large electric -utility 20 
businesses, as well as its extensive gas pipelines, performed 21 
about as expected. But the regulatory climate in a few states 22 
has raised the specter of zero profitability or even bankruptcy 23 
(an actual outcome at California’s largest utility and a current 24 
threat in Hawaii). In such jurisdictions, it is difficult to project 25 
both earnings and asset values in what was once regarded as 26 
among the most stable industries in America.  27 
*** 28 
It will be many years until we know the final tally from BHE’s 29 
forest -fire losses and can intelligently make decisions about 30 
the desirability of future investments in vulnerable western 31 
states. It remains to be seen whether the regulatory 32 
environment will change elsewhere.  33 
*** 34 
 
6 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  When the dust settles, America’s power needs and the 1 
consequent capital expenditure will be staggering. I did not 2 
anticipate or even consider the adverse developments in 3 
regulatory returns and, along with Berkshire’s two partners at 4 
BHE, I made a costly mistake in not doing so.  5 
 6 
While I recognize that the source of the performance issues  noted above  related to 7 
regulatory support surrounding wildfire risk, this summary of the risks of BHE’s 8 
electric utility operations, particularly the risk related to regulation , highlights the 9 
importance of continued constructive regulation for Minnesota Power.  These 10 
examples  also illustrate that while equity and infrastructure fund investors have 11 
increased capability to fund energy companies as a whole , particularly where they 12 
are aligned with the  goals of the underlying company, investors continue to pay 13 
attention to risk and obtaining reasonable returns on their investment.  14 
 15 
III. ESTIMATING THE COST OF CAPITAL FOR  16 
REGULATED UTILITIES  17 
Q. Why is it necessary to estimate the cost of capital for Minnesota Power?  18 
A. Throughout its history, the Commission has recognized that Minnesota Power is an 19 
operating division of ALLETE, which has other regulated and unregulated 20 
subsidiaries and businesses in addition to the Minnesota utility business. Even for 21 
utility companies that are traded publicly, it has been common practice to rely on 22 
market data for a proxy group of companies to estimate the cost of equity so as not 23 
to bias the estimate by a limited sample.  Thus , the ROE for the Minnesota Power 24 
regulated utility is developed on the basis of a proxy group comparison and 25 
associated market data .   26 
 27 
Following the acquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments and GIP , this structure 28 
will be unchanged .  The Minnesota Power utility  will still be only a subset of 29 
ALLETE and the regulated utility  will still not have market pricing available that 30 
could be used to estimate the investor -required ROE  for the Company.  For all of 31 
 
7 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  these reasons, the determination of Minnesota Power’s authorized ROE  is and will 1 
continue to be  based on estimates  using market data for a proxy group of publicly 2 
traded companies . 3 
 4 
Q. Please describe the guiding principles to be used in establishing the cost of 5 
capital for a regulated utility.  6 
A.  The U.S. Supreme Court’s precedent -setting Hope  and Bluefield  cases established 7 
the standards for determining the fairness or reasonableness of a utility’s authorized 8 
ROE.  Among the standards established by the U.S. Supreme Court in those cases 9 
are: (1) consistency with other businesses having similar or comparable risks; (2) 10 
adequacy of the return to support credit quality and access to capital; and (3) that 11 
the end result, as opposed to the methodology employed, is the controlling factor 12 
in arriving at just and reasonable rates.3 13 
 14 
Q. Has the Commission provided similar guidance in establishing the appropriate 15 
return on common equity?  16 
A.  Yes, it has.  For example, in a recent fully litigated case, the Commission cited 17 
Minn . Stat. § 216B.16, subd. 6, which states that:  18 
In determining just and reasonable rates, the Commission is required 19 
to “give due consideration to the public need for adequate, efficient, 20 
and reasonable service and to the need of the public utility for 21 
revenue sufficient to enable it to meet the cost of furnishing service, 22 
including adequate provision for depreciation of its utility property 23 
used and useful in rendering service to the public, and to earn a fair 24 
and reasonable return upon the investment in such property .”4 25 
 In the same Order, the Commission stated that it “must set rates at a level that 26 
permits stockholders an opportunity to earn a fair and reasonable return on their 27 
investment and permits the utility to continue to attract investment.”5 This guidance 28 
 
3 See generally  Federal Power Com. v. Hope Natural Gas Co. , 320 U.S. 591 (1944);  Bluefield Water Works 
& Improvement Co. v. Public Serv. Comm’n , 262 U.S. 679 (1923).  
4 In re Petition by Great Plains Natural Gas Co., a Div. of Montana -Dakota Utils., Co., for Auth. to Increase 
Natural Gas Rates in Minn ., Docket No. G0 04/GR-19-511, FINDINGS OF FACT, CONCLUSIONS AND ORDER  
at 14 (Oct. 26, 2020)  (quoting Minn. Stat. § 216B.16, subd. 6) (emphasis in original).  
5 Id. 
 
8 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  is in accordance with my view that an allowed rate of return must be sufficient to 1 
enable regulated companies, like Minnesota Power, the ability to attract capital on 2 
reasonable terms  on a stand -alone basis . 3 
 4 
Q. Is there also academic support for the stand -alone principle?  5 
A.  Yes.  The well -known and often relied on corporate finance  textbook, Principles of 6 
Corporate Finance , notes that t he assets of a company should be evaluated as if 7 
each asset were a “mini -firm” in which investors could invest directly in each asset.  8 
The company cost of capital is not the correct discount rate if 9 
the new projects are more or less risky than the firm’s existing 10 
business. Each project should in principle be evaluated at its 11 
own opportunity cost. This is a clear implication of the value - 12 
additivity principle introduced in Chapter 7. For a firm 13 
composed of assets A and B, the firm value is : 14 
Firm value = PV(AB)= PV (A) +PV(B)  15 
                       = sum of separate asset values.  16 
Here PV(A ) and PV(B) are valued just as if they were mini - 17 
firms in which stockholders could invest directly.  18 
*** 19 
The o pportunity cost of capital depends on the use to which 20 
that capital is put.6  21 
 22 
Q. Is determining a fair rate of return just about protecting the utility’s interests?  23 
A.  No. As the U.S. Supreme Court noted in Bluefield , a proper rate of return not only 24 
assures “confidence in the financial soundness of the utility and should be adequate, 25 
under efficient and economical management, to maintain and support its credit [but 26 
also] enable[s the utility] to raise the money necessary for the proper discharge of 27 
its public duties.”7  As the U.S. Supreme Court further explained in Hope , “[t]he 28 
 
6 Brealey Meyers Allen, Principles of Corporate Finance  at 214 (10 th ed.2011).  
7 Bluefield , 262 U.S. at 693.  
 
9 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  rate-making process . . . involves a balancing of the investor and consumer 1 
interests.”8 2 
 3 
Q. Why is it important for a utility to be allowed the opportunity to earn an ROE 4 
that is adequate to attract capital at reasonable terms?  5 
A.  An authorized ROE that is adequate to attract capital at reasonable terms enables 6 
the utility to continue to provide safe, clean, and reliable electricity service while 7 
maintaining its financial integrity.  That return should be commensurate with 8 
returns required by investors elsewhere in the market for investments of comparable 9 
risk.  It is important to recognize that equity investors , whether investing through 10 
the stock market or in a portfolio of privately held businesses,  have a choice of 11 
where to invest capital.  If the authorized ROE is not comparable to the returns 12 
available for comparable risk investments, the value to current equity holders is 13 
harmed and can affect the capital available to the utility.  Where investors are 14 
focused on short -term dividends  and earnings, the availability of capital can be 15 
severely restricted.  That said, it is reasonable to expect that equity investors will 16 
seek investment opportunities for which the expected return reflects the perceived 17 
risks  and will expect reasonable authorized returns for their investments.  18 
 19 
Q. Do Minnesota Power’s operations change as a result of the Acquisition ? 20 
A.  No. After the Acquisition , Minnesota Power will continue to be the same company, 21 
with better access to capital. Minnesota Power is still a local company. The 22 
operations of the electric utility will continue without disruption or changes in 23 
Minnesota. Regional employment opportunities at Minnesota Power and the 24 
multiplier effect of that employment in the region remains unchanged. Finally, 25 
Minnesota Power will continue to support local causes as it has throughout its 26 
existence, as owned by ALLETE and as a stand -alone entity prior to the current 27 
organizational structure.  Additionally, Minnesota Power will remain the largest 28 
segment of ALLETE, meaning that the health of ALLETE as a Minnesota 29 
 
8 Hope , 320 U.S. at 603.  
 
10 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  company, employer, and property tax base  continues to depend heavily on 1 
reasonable cost recovery and returns in the State of Minnesota.  2 
 3 
Q. Does the market -required ROE  invested in Minnesota Power change as a 4 
result of access to funds through the Partners?  5 
A. No. Consistent with the principles of corporate finance, the investor -required ROE  6 
is based on the risk of the investment, not the source of the capital that is invested.  7 
The determination of the ROE is not based on the specific investors or type of 8 
investors ( e.g., institutional investors versus individuals) who will hold an equity 9 
interest in the company. This has long been the case, as investors in ALLETE have 10 
been a mix of individuals and institutional investors, with the market -required 11 
return focused on the Company (i.e., the investment).  Therefore, the cost of equity 12 
continues to be based on the risks of Minnesota Power’s operations.  13 
 14 
Q. Does better access to capital mean that the return requirements for Minnesota 15 
Power are lower?  16 
A.  No. While the Acquisition  will provide better access to capital, investors still 17 
require a reasonable return on that investment.  Further, the Company’s operations 18 
are predominantly in Minnesota. Therefore, the return that is established by this 19 
Commission is the largest contributing factor to the return for the Company overall.  20 
 21 
Q. What are the financial benefits of the transaction for Minnesota Power ? 22 
A.  As discussed in the Company’s Petition9 the Acquisition  will provide Minnesota 23 
Power access to capital to fund its clean energy transition, which requires more than 24 
$4 billion of investment over the next five years alone. Further, the capital available 25 
through the Partners  will reduce the Company’s exposure to volatility in the 26 
financial markets, and can provide liquidity in tight market conditions when short - 27 
term market disruptions would otherwise result in illiquid markets.  These benefits 28 
 
9 Petition at 13.  
 
11 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  are discussed in more detail by other witnesses for the Company, GIP, and CPP 1 
Investments.  2 
 3 
Q. Is it appropriate to review the authorized ROE for Minnesota Power in the 4 
current Acquisition  proceeding?  5 
A.  No. A review of just the ROE  without consideration of the other costs of operations 6 
would be considered single -issue ratemaking, which is not the process that this 7 
Commission has used to establish just and reasonable rates. Traditionally , the 8 
Commission has reviewed the cost of equity and authorized a ROE  in the context 9 
of a traditional rate proceeding, when all costs of service are evaluated for prudence. 10 
It is reasonable to continue to consider the appropriate ROE  in the context of these 11 
broader rate proceedings.  12 
 13 
Q. Does the fact of the Acquisition change how the cost of equity will be estimated  14 
for Minnesota Power  going forward ? 15 
A. No.  As noted previously, the Company’s cost of equity should be evaluated in rate 16 
proceedings based on the risk of the investment, which has not changed. The 17 
Acquisition changes the source of funding, but not the risk of the operation. 18 
Therefore, it is reasonable to rely on the same methodologies that have been used 19 
in prior rate proceedings to evaluate the cost of equity for Minnesota Power.  20 
 21 
Q. Please explain further.   22 
A.  Over the past decade, the Commission has  relied on traditional cost of equity 23 
estimation models , applied to a proxy group of generally risk - comparable publicly 24 
traded companies  as one of the key indicators of the cost of equity .  In addition, the 25 
Commission has historically recognized that it is necessary to evaluate the relative 26 
business risks of the subject company as compared to the proxy group companies.  27 
Those estimation tools  do not depend on the owner of the subject company , which 28 
often itself is not publicly traded as noted above; rather,  they depend on public 29 
information and forward -looking models employing proxy group data.  Thus , while 30 
 
12 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  ALLETE may no longer be used in other proxy groups,  the Acquisition itself does 1 
not change the proxy group to which Minnesota Power  would  be compared.  2 
 3 
Q. Has this Commission changed the methodology that it has relied upon to set 4 
the ROE for a company as a result of a merger?  5 
A. No. There have been several acquisitions of utilities in Minnesota that have not 6 
resulted in any change in the methodology for determining the ROE for the acquired 7 
companies. For example, as discussed previously, Minnegasco was acquired by 8 
Reliant Energy in August 1997. Reliant was transformed into CenterPoint Energy 9 
in 2002. MERC was acquired by what is now WEC Energy Group  as part of its 10 
merger with Integrys Energy Group  in 2015. In both cases, despite the change in 11 
ownership, the Commission has continued to evaluate the cost of equity on a stand - 12 
alone basis for each of these companies.  13 
 14 
Q. Has the Commission established one methodology that they have relied on 15 
exclusively in setting ROE?  16 
A.  No. Historically , the Commission placed significant weight on the results of the 17 
TGDCF model; however, since approximately 2015, while the Commission has 18 
given primary weight to the TGDCF model, it has also considered various other 19 
factors, including the results of other models, market conditions, and company risk 20 
factors.  For example, in its 2017 Order for Otter Tail Power Company’s (“Otter 21 
Tail”) rate case, the Commission noted that:   22 
The record in this case establishes a compelling basis for selecting 23 
an ROE above the mean average within the DCF range, given Otter 24 
Tail’s unique characteristics and circumstances relative to other 25 
utilities in the proxy group. These factors include the company’s 26 
relatively smaller size, geographically diffuse customer base, and 27 
the scope of the Company’s planned infrastructure investments. The 28 
Commission has also considered Otter Tail’s recognized [sic] the 29 
Company’s performance in completing major infrastructure projects 30 
substantially under budget, its history of providing reliable service 31 
with stable rates, and its record of effectively serving the needs of 32 
 
13 
OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198 
Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  its customers, as measured by multiple customer -satisfaction 1 
metrics.10 2 
Likewise, in its 2018 Order for MERC ’s rate case, the Commission acknowledged 3 
that the record included a broad diversity of modeling and noted that the authorized 4 
ROE was set in light of the record as a whole:  5 
The Commission believes that the record evidence in this case, 6 
including the broad diversity of modeling and expert testimony, 7 
establishes a range of reasonable costs of equity, within which the 8 
Commission must identify one value.  9 
The record does not formulaically dictate a particular ROE to be 10 
approved.  Instead, the record presents a range of reasonable returns 11 
on equity that the Commission has carefully evaluated based on the 12 
analyses and arguments in the record. As such, the Commission will 13 
set the Company’s authorized ROE in light of the record as a 14 
whole.11 15 
The Commission used a similar approach in its orders for Minnesota Power12 and 16 
Great Plains Natural Gas Company (“Great Plains”).13  17 
 18 
Q. Has the Commission considered the authorized ROEs in other jurisdictions  as 19 
one data point in setting a Minnesota utility’s ROE ?  20 
A.  Yes. The Commission has routinely reviewed authorized ROEs in other 21 
jurisdictions in the determination of the ROEs for the companies that it regulates. 22 
For example, in its decision in the Company’s 2021 Rate Case, the Commission 23 
stated:  24 
[W]hile the decisions of other jurisdictions are not binding and have 25 
limited persuasive value because of the fact -intensive nature of cost - 26

Bulkley Direct Testimony and Schedule  of-equity decision -making, they do provide a check, of sorts on 1 
reasonableness.14 2 
These comparisons focus on the company in question and other comparable 3 
companies or utilities, rather than on the nature of the investors in the various 4 
companies.  5 
 6 
Q. What are your conclusions regarding the estimation of the cost of equity for 7 
Minnesota Power following the Acquisition ?  8 
A.  The investor -required return is based on the risk of the investment, not the source 9 
of funds  and it is reasonable for investors to expect a return on their investment that 10 
is commensurate with the risk of that investment.  Since the  operations of 11 
Minnesota Power are not changing as a result of the Acquisition , the investor - 12 
required return is also not changing as a result of the Acquisition . Therefore, it is 13 
appropriate that the ROE for Minnesota Power be determined as it has been  in prior 14 
proceedings , considering the risks of Minnesota Power  on a stand -alone basis . This 15 
is consistent with this Commission’s past practice  determining the cost of equity 16 
for other companies that have been acquired or consolidated into larger holding 17 
companies. Further, the methodologies that have been considered by this 18 
Commission and other regulatory commissions, which include the review of results 19 
from traditional cost of equity models, using proxy groups of publicly traded 20 
companies,  consideration of the relative business risks of the subject company, and 21 
consideration of  recent ROE determinations, established in similar market 22 
conditions  are reasonable and appropriate to review and consider in setting the ROE  23 
for Minnesota Power following the Acquisition .  24 
 25 
IV. CONCLUSION  26 
Q. Does this conclude your Direct Testimony?  27 
A.  Yes, it does.  28

With more than 25 years of experience in the energy industry, Ms. 
Bulkley specializes in regulatory economics for the electric and natural 
gas and water utility sectors , including valuation of regulated and 
unregulated utility assets, cost of capital, and capital structure issues.  
Ms. Bulkley  has extensive state and federal regulatory experience , and she has provided expert 
testimony on the cost of capital in nearly 100 regulatory proceedings before 32 state regulatory 
commissions and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission  (FERC).  
In addition to her regulatory experience, Ms. Bulkley has provided valuation and appraisal services for a 
variety of purposes , including the sale or acquisition of utility assets, regulated ratemaking, ad valorem 
tax disputes, and other litigation purposes. In addition, she has experience in the areas of contract and 
business unit valuation, strategic alliances, market restructuring , and regulatory and litigation support.   
Ms. Bulkley is a Certified General Appraiser licensed in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the 
State of New Hampshire.  
Prior to joining Brattle, Ms. Bulkley was a Senior Vice President at an economic consultancy and held 
senior positions at several other consulting firms.

Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and business address.  2 
A. My name is  John D. Quackenbu sh, CFA,  and my business address is 46320 Station 3 
Road, New Buffalo, MI 49117.  4 
 5 
Q. By whom are you employed and in what position?  6 
A. I am employed by JQ Resources , LLC . My current position is President . 7 
 8 
Q. Please summarize your qualifications and experience.  9 
A. I have more than forty years of experience working in the fields of utility regulation and 10 
finance.  That experience comprises more than nine years’ service as a utility regulator , 11 
both as chair of the Michigan Public Service Commission (“Michigan PSC”) and a  12 
finance staff member  of the Illinois Commerce Commission (“ICC”) , more than two 13 
decades of work in and with the capital markets for regulated entities , competitive firms,  14 
and a leading global financial services firm, and, most recently, consulting with 15 
regulators and regulated entities concerning capital market and utility finance issues.   16 
 17 
I have served as the President of JQ Resources, LLC since April 2016.  My primary 18 
responsibilities in that role include providing professional advice and education to 19 
participants in the regulated utility industries through consulting services that bridge the 20 
gap between the regulatory and investment communities.  In that role, I am retained by 21 
and my services are used by regulators, regulatory organizations, regulated entities, and 22 
other stakeholders in the regulatory process.  Recently, for example, on behalf of the 23 
National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners ( “NARUC ”), I authored two 24 
tariff toolkit primers, the April 2020 tariff toolkit primer entitled “A Cost of Capital and 25 
Capital Markets Primer for Utility Regulators,” and the April 2021 “Primary Drivers of 26 
Electricity Tariffs for Utility Regulators ,” which have been used to support NARUC 27

MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  training activities internationally.1  I also continue to monitor how investors perceive 1 
and evaluate utility investment opportunities and risks, and to interact with and stay 2 
abreast of the views of credit rating agencies, buy -side institutional investors, and sell - 3 
side analysts focusing on the utility sector.   4 
 5 
As a regulator, I served as the Chair of the Michigan PSC.  In that position, I was charged 6 
with both setting policy and evaluating evidence of the full range of regulatory issues, 7 
including concerning utility finance, access to capital, and the cost of that capital.  While 8 
Chair of the Michigan PSC, I served on the NARUC Committee on Gas, its Committee 9 
on Consumer Affairs, and its Subcommittee on Pipeline Safety during 2011 through 10 
2016.  11 
 12 
As a member of the ICC staff, including as its Chief Financial Analyst, I advised the 13 
Commission concerning finance issues.  Among my roles was supporting the 14 
Commission in the determination of utility cost of capital and assessing the methods by 15 
which the Commission could gain accurate insight into capital costs and the factors that 16 
affect them , including through the use of cost of capital models.  17 
  18 
I was employed for 11 years by UBS Global Asset Management (“UBS”), an affiliate 19 
of a leading international investment bank, where I led the global utilities team in 20 
building utility equity portfolios.  In that role, I covered approximately 80 North 21 
American companies, including approximately 60 to 65 regulated utilities at any time, 22 
and met regularly with their senior management, customers, suppliers, and regulators.  23 
I was primarily responsible for investment recommendations, thesis statements, and 24 
financial models for any utility investment that was selected for  U.S. or Canadian 25 
domestic equity portfolios, as well as global equity portfolios. I also regularly interacted 26

Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  III. THE IMPORTANCE OF CAPITAL MARKET  ACCESS TO UTILITIES  1 
A. Common Goals of Utilities and Regulators  2 
Q. Do utility regulators and utilities share common goals?  3 
A. Yes. Both utilities and regulators want to ensure affordable and fair bills for customers, 4 
reliable and safe service, a positive customer experience, and a transition to clean 5 
energy.  Customers are at the center of all four of these goals.  Regulators work toward 6 
these goals through their policies, rules, and orders.  Utilities contribute toward 7 
meeting these goals by investing in infrastructure, efficiently raising capital, and 8 
controlling O&M costs.  Infrastructure investment is particularly important to 9 
achieving the goals of enhancing reliability by replacing aging infrastructure and 10 
investing in new customer -facing and clean technologies.   11 
 12 
Customers have grown accustomed to reliable and safe electricity being available on 13 
demand with minimal service disruptions.  Many customers are also interested in 14 
electric ity that is produced with lower carbon and other emissions .  Utilities must 15 
interact with the capital markets regularly to raise capital to obtain the funds for new 16 
infrastructure investment as well as re -finance maturing debt.  Customers benefit if 17 
utilities are able to obtain capital at reasonable and cost -effective rates, resulting in 18 
affordable and reasonable  bills for service provided to customers . 19 
 20 
B. The Role of Capital Markets in Serving Customers  21 
Q. Why are capital markets important for regulated utilitie s, their regulators, and 22 
their customers ? 23 
A. Regulated utilities are required to raise capital from investors in order to provide safe, 24 
reliable, and affordable service to customers , and meet public policy objectives .  Utility 25 
service is provided through investments in infrastructure that is constructed to last for 26 
multiple decades, which makes utilities among the most capital -intensive industries.  27 
Investors supply capital to a utility  to pre -fund utility work that serves customers,  with 28 
 
 8 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  investors then having the appropriate  expectation of earning a return  on their 1 
investments .  Although utilities provide public information about their plans, goals, and 2 
projects, investors provide capital to  the utility company rather than for individual 3 
projects.  Specifically, i nvestors require a return on an investment in relation to the risk 4 
of that utility , which includes  a portfolio of individual projects and workstreams .  In 5 
turn, u tility customers pay bills for utility service that include a component to provide 6 
for the recovery of the utility’s cost of obtaining capital.  7 
 8 
Q. Why is the access to capital markets important for regulated utilities, their 9 
regulators, and their customers?  10 
A. Regular sustained access to the capital markets is important because regulated utilities 11 
must continually invest in infrastructure that supports the continued provision of safe, 12 
reliable, affordable, and clean service at the time customers demand it.  A financially 13 
healthy utility will have access to capital, which includes the availability of capital and 14 
the cost of that capital.  The more capital intensive an industry is, and the more frequent 15 
capital raising needs are, the more important is the access to capital.   16 
 17 
Q. Are utilities guaranteed access to capital in the public markets?  18 
A. No.  Investors have a choice of competing investments and they make their selections 19 
by weighing risks versus returns.  Capital markets are global, with investments 20 
competing against alternatives across the world on a risk -adjusted basis, and capital 21 
flows to investments that provide attractive risk -adjusted returns.  Investment 22 
opportunities in utilities – or any other company, for that matter – that do not provide 23 
sufficient risk -adjusted returns will not attract capital.  Even within a company or 24 
holding company family, capital allocation is a process that must take risk-adjusted  25 
returns into consideration.  Over time, a utility or holding company will have no choice 26 
but to direct capital to the activities, divisions, or jurisdictions that provide appropriate 27 
risk-adjusted returns that recognize the market cost of that capital.   28

Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules   1 
Q. Please describe and compare debt and equity capital markets.  2 
A. There are two primary types of capital: debt and equity.  A debt investor essentially 3 
lends debt capital to the utility and expects to receive periodic interest payments and the 4 
return of principal at the end of the life of the debt security.  In contrast, an equity 5 
investor acquires stock which represents an ownership interest in a utility and expects 6 
to receive periodic dividend payments and stock price appreciation upon selling the 7 
stock.  In general, an equity investment is considered of higher risk than a debt 8 
investment , and therefore requires a higher return.   Debt holders have a higher claim  on 9 
the assets of a company and will be paid before share holders in the event of bankruptcy.   10 
Share holders are last in line to be paid, after debt holders and other creditors.  11 
 12 
Both debt and equity securities are traded in the capital markets.  Alternative capital 13 
investments are evaluated by investors on their individual merits and risk metrics.  Debt 14 
is issued by a utility into the primary debt market, after which it may be traded in the 15 
secondary market where its market value will change as fundamental factors such as 16 
interest rates , perceived risk s, and credit ratings  change .  Public e quity is issued by a 17 
utility into the primary equity market, after which it will be traded in the secondary 18 
market on a stock exchange where its market value will fluctuate over time in response 19 
to supply and demand , fundamental factors such as perceived company -specific risk 20 
changes and economic conditions , market sentiment , and technical factors.  It is 21 
typically expected that a utility’s stock price will be more volatile than its debt prices.    22 
 23 
Q. Do customers benefit from a financially healthy utility?  24 
A. Yes.  A financially healthy utility can attract capital at a more cost -effective rate than 25 
a financially weak utility.  Customers, not just investors, benefit by having a 26 
financially stable utility that has the earnings and cash flow sufficient to attract equity 27 
and debt on reasonable terms, and the ability to provide safe, reliable electric service.  28 
Having a reasonable authorized return on equity  and regulatory adjustment 29 
mechanisms to recover costs in a timely manner are important contributor s to financial 30 
stability.  The long-term customer benefits that result from being served by a 31 
 
 10 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  financially healthy utility outweigh the illusory short -term “benefits” of artificially 1 
lower customer rates that produce a negative regulatory climate that heightens 2 
regulatory risk  and weakens financial health . 3 
 4 
Q. How do customers benefit from a financially healthy utility?  5 
A. Utilities require reliable access to the capital markets at reasonable cost in order to 6 
support and maintain that investment if they are to serve their customers effectively.  7 
Investors, in turn, supply capital with the expectation of earning a return on their 8 
investment, and they require a return proportional to the risk of their investment.  A 9 
failure to honor investor requirements will, counterproductively, leave the utility 10 
unable to secure capital at a reasonable competitive cost, can increase its perceived 11 
financial risk, and will ultimately increase its costs and make provision of service to 12 
customers more difficult.  Because customers have a strong interest in ensuring that 13 
utilities can raise the capital required for safe, reliable, clean, and affordable service, 14 
their interest in receiving service at a reasonable cost is not well -served by a financially 15 
weak utility with limited access to capital.  16 
 17 
The risks faced by utility investors are important to utility customers.  As discussed in 18 
the NARUC Cost of Capital and Capital Markets Primer for Utility Regulators:3 19 
The risks faced by utility investors are important to utility customers 20 
because risks to investors get reflected in the capital costs to the utility 21 
which are ultimately paid for by customers.  Regulatory risk as 22 
perceived by investors impacts the availability and cost of capital.  23 
When investors perceive higher risk, the corresponding costs of debt 24 
and equity increase.  If investors are les s willing to provide capital, 25 
capital is less cost -effective for customers.   26 
 27 
It is clear that t he risk levels of a  regulated utility  impact its cost of obtaining capital.   28 
For example, a heightened level of risk would place upward pressure on its cost of 29 
short -term debt and its embedded cost of long -term debt, since  new long -term debt 30 
securities would be issued at higher interest rates.  Moreover, revolving credit facilit ies 31 
often  immediately re -price upward to higher interest rates, as heightened risk is  tied to 32 
 
3 NARUC “A Cost of Capital and Capital Markets Primer for Utility Regulators,” April 2020, at 9. 
 
 11 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  higher credit spreads.  Also, elevated risk  may impact the amount of unsecured credit 1 
extended by natural gas and wholesale power counterparties as well as their collateral 2 
demands.  Additionally, the utility ’s cost of equity would increase as equity investors 3 
would require a higher rate of return to compensate for additional risk.    4 
 5 
It is often said that the role of conventional cost -of-service regulation is to “balance” 6 
the interests of utility customers and utility investors.  However, that balance is not 7 
always a seesaw where actions in the interest of one are to the detriment of the other.  8 
In many ways, the interests of investors and customers are aligned and not in conflict.  9 
As mentioned in the NARUC Cost of Capital and Capital Markets Primer  for Utility 10 
Regulators :4 11 
Utility management has a fiduciary responsibility to deploy investors’ 12 
capital productively.  Investors recognize the importance of regulatory 13 
and stakeholder relationships and expect utility management to provide 14 
safe, reliable, and affordable service to customers in order to preserve 15 
and enhance the value of their invested capital.  In many ways, the 16 
interests of investors and customers are aligned and not in conflict and 17 
can become more aligned through regulatory policy.  Regulators are 18 
more effective at serving customers when they harness investors’ desire 19 
to provide capital rather than constrain it.  20 
Customers expect that the utility will make and support the investments necessary to 21 
provide adequate, safe, and reliable service and do so with reasonably priced capital 22 
in the short and long  run.  The interests of investors and customers are aligned through 23 
regulatory practices that accurately assess utility risks and capital costs and reflect 24 
those determinations, consistently, in rates.  25 
 26 
Moreover, an additional benefit of utility  investment is the enhanced quality of life 27 
that inures to the communities in a utility’s service territory from economic 28 
development and job creation.  29 
 30 
 
4 NARUC “A Cost of Capital and Capital Markets Primer for Utility Regulators,” April 2020, at 9.

Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  Q. Please describe and compare public and private capital markets . 1 
A. The public capital markets refer to  markets for  securities that are publicly traded or 2 
listed on an exchange .  Specific  to equity investments , public equity refers to stocks 3 
that are publicly traded or listed on a stock exchange.  In the utility industry, companies 4 
that are public equity  owned are often referred to as investor -owned utilities.  MP 5 
Exhibit ___ ( Quackenbush ), Direct Schedule 3 shows a list of U.S. investor -owned 6 
electric utilities at December 31, 2023 as identified by the Edison Electric Institute 7 
(“EEI”). Public equity utility investors include a mix of long -term and short -term 8 
investors.  Long -term utility investors generally seek the lower risk attributes of low 9 
volatility, stability, certainty, and predictability, along with modest returns and are 10 
focused on fundamental factors  that drive equity valuations over the long run .  11 
ALLETE , including action on behalf of its utility operations,  compete s for capital in a 12 
global securities market and particularly against other long -term stable investment like 13 
other North American utilities.  Investors in ALLETE long-term debt and equity  14 
include large institutional investors that invest on behalf of public employee pension 15 
funds, teacher pension funds, and mutual funds, as well as ordinary Americans 16 
investing in their 401k accounts and individual Minnesotans such as those represented 17 
by the grassroots Minnesota Utility Investors Association.  Institutional investors 18 
incorporate ALLETE long-term debt and  stock into the retirement accoun ts of many 19 
ordinary Americans.   20 
 21 
Long -term utility debt investors expect regular interest payments and repayment of 22 
capital at maturity.  Long -term utility equity investors expect dividend payments and 23 
modest capital appreciation at a future sale date in line with other long -term stable 24 
investments.  Neither long-term utility debt nor equity investors are seeking  volatility 25 
or outsized returns, since there are sectors other than utilities to invest in if that is the 26 
investor’s goal.  Other  non-utility  sectors regularly earn returns greater than their cost 27 
of capital.   Long -term equity investors are likely to use fundamental valuation models 28 
that focus on earnings, cash flows, dividends, growth, and discount rates.  Efficient 29 
markets imply that long -term equity prices will gravitate toward fundamental 30 
valuations.  31 
 
 13 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules    1 
Q. Please contrast the impact of short -term equity investors and long -term equity 2 
investors.  3 
A.  Short -term equity investors in the public markets may include hedge funds  and short 4 
sellers  who are more interested in short -term stock price movements than long -term 5 
fundamentals .  Significant transactional activity by short -term investors m ay lead to 6 
temporary valuation disruptions away from long-term fundamentals.   At times, these 7 
temporary valuation  disruption s can persist for noticeable periods of time.  A n equity 8 
issuer can  be inconvenienced if it needs to raise equity capital during a valuation 9 
disruption.  A serial equity issuer can be seriously hampered during valuation 10 
disruptions because it has less control over issuance timing  and may have no choice but 11 
to issue shares at a disadvantageous price , potentially raising less capital than needed .  12 
A non-serial equity issuer  can more readily wait through a valuation disruption and time 13 
the market for a higher valuation, thus raising the amount of capital it needs.    14 
 15 
In contrast, p rivate equity investing is investing in shares of companies that are not 16 
publicly traded or listed on a stock exchange.   Private equity is stock in a private 17 
company that does not offer stock to the general public.  Typically, a private equity fund 18 
develops specific financial goals, management preferences, and investment strategies.  19 
Often , the investment strategy focuses  on the long -term growth and expansion of the 20 
acquired companies.  Private equity  often raises investment funds from institutional 21 
investors such as pension funds , infrastructure funds, and ultra -high-net-worth 22 
individuals to pursue a stated long-term investment strategy.  Private market long-term 23 
utility investors also generally seek the lower risk attributes of low volatility, stability, 24 
certainty, and predictability, along with modest returns.  Like long term -public market 25 
investors, t hey would look toward other non -utility sectors if their goal was outsized 26 
returns.   An issuer that has access to private equity has no exposure to temporary 27 
valuation disruptions caused by short -term investors.  28 
 29

Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  Q. How can other exogenous factors such as market volatility, technical factors , and 1 
market sentiment influence the public equity market?  2 
A. Markets can be volatile  during unstable times.  Utilities need to prepare as if market 3 
volatility may be  imminent because of the potentially severe consequences of swings in 4 
spreads and limitations on access to capital.  Capital market access may be diminished 5 
or severely restricted during times of crisis, such as the 2008 global financial crisis or 6 
the COVID -19 pandemic impact on the commercial paper market in March 2020.  Debt  7 
securities are typically priced as a spread to comparable -maturity U.S. Treasury 8 
securities.  Long -term spreads also widen during a crisis with lower credit quality issuers 9 
having to accept a larger spread differential compared to higher credit quality issuers 10 
than typical during stable times.  Moreover, in unstable markets, investor sensitivity to 11 
instability in the utility’s financial condition, or its regulation, is typically greater.  12 
Quarterly earnings reports, news reports, and regulatory decisions can all impact the 13 
timing of public capital issuance if they create unfavorable periods of time for issuance.  14 
 15 
Technical factors can also alter the supply of and demand for a company’s stock.  For 16 
example, a large investor might buy or short a stock as a hedge against another 17 
investment.  This hedging activity can alter the demand for the stock, thus altering the 18 
observed public market valuation for technical, rather than fundamental, reasons.  19 
Changing investor demographics, short -term momentum trends, and liquidity 20 
constraints can all impact stock valuations at any point in time.  21 
 22 
Market sentiment  refers to the individual and collective psychology of market 23 
participants .  Some stocks appear to be mispriced by the public market for noticeable 24 
periods of time for no discernable reason based on fundamentals.  The relatively new 25 
field of b ehavioral finance  is exploring this observed phenomenon .   26 
 27 
Q. How is private  equity  uniquely positioned to support long -term infrastructure 28 
investment  and enhance access to capital ? 29 
A. Private equity is typically long -term focused  and more patient , in contrast to the public 30 
equity market consisting of a mix of long -term and short -term investors.  Although 31

Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  public equity  valuations will fully reflect fundamental factors in the long run in the 1 
efficient market , potential negative impacts of other factors related  to short -term 2 
valuation disruptions , market volatility, technical factors, and market sentiment  are also 3 
avoided  with private equity .  An o ccasional  issuer of moderate to large size can perhaps 4 
navigate more nimbly through an adverse environment, but a serial issuer  assumes more 5 
risk of having to raise capital at an inopportune time .  Private equity is a more flexible 6 
and patient capital resource for a serial issuer on size and timing of repeated equity 7 
infusions and dividends.  Sensitivity to timing of quarterly earnings reports, news 8 
reports, and dividend declarations becomes less important  to private equity .  Private 9 
equity can enable a repea ting (“ serial ”) issuer  such as ALLETE  to more readily maintain 10 
a balanced capital structure.   The private equity environment can contribute toward 11 
minimizing the cost of capital that customers ultimately pay for through rates.  From a 12 
utility’s perspective, access to more flexible  private equity capital can provide a l ower 13 
risk of beneficial infrastructure investment for customers being delayed or minimized 14 
due to a constraint on public capital transactions.  15

to cost-of-service regulat ion by state public utility commissions  and the F ederal 9 
Communications Commissio n.  Additionally, Sprint Corporation was investing in 10 
rapidly growing competitive businesses including the wireless and long -distance 11 
divisions.  Virtually all subsidiaries had 100  percent  of their stock owned by the parent 12 
while having a significant need to repeatedly issue debt in the capital  markets .  Only the 13 
largest 3 -4 LECs  were large enough to issue their own debt.  The 17 -21 smaller LECs, 14 
including United Telephone Company of Minnesota (later re -named Sprint – 15 
Minnesota ), had large capital needs relative to their size but debt investors were 16 
relatively uninterested in small transaction sizes.  As a result, we created larger 17 
transaction sizes through stapled private placements whereby each smaller LEC’s debt 18 
was stapled in a package with the other small LECs  such that debt investors were eager 19 
to buy the consolidated debt package, contributing to a lower cost of debt.  We were 20 
fortunate to be able to create this unique framework to work around a potential lack of 21 
access to capital due to small size.  22 
 23 
Separately, Sprint found it advantageous to issue debt to fund its rapidly growing 24 
competitive businesses on a consolidated basis.  We created an entity named Sprint 25 
Capital Corporation that was intended to issue debt on behalf of the competitive 26 
businesses.  In November 1998, Sprint Capital was  able to issue $5  billion  of debt to 27 
eager debt investors in a single transaction which was, at the time, the second largest 28 
corporate debt issuance in history.  Again, we were fortunate to  create a framework that 29 
could avoid a potential size disadvantage that could have led to a lack of access to 30 
capital.  Both actual Sprint Treasury  examples for both regulated utilities and 31 
 
 19 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  competitive firms demonstrate that larger size positively influences an issuer ’s access 1 
to capital and the cost -effectiveness of that capital , and avoid the negative influence of 2 
smaller size . 3 
 4 
Q. Do you agree with Company Witness  Taran that customer base influences access 5 
to capital ? 6 
A. Yes.  ALLETE’s significant proportion of large industrial customers with variable load 7 
characteristics poses a risk to investors and presents a challenge when it comes to access 8 
to capital.  9 
 10 
Q. What is your understanding of the circumstances that led the ALLETE Board of 11 
Directors (the “Board”) to see advantages in private equity investmen ts? 12 
A. My understanding comes from the Definitive P roxy Statement  (the “Proxy”)  filed with 13 
the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission . The Proxy discloses that i n 2019, 14 
ALLETE developed its Sustainability -in-Action Strategy that was approved by the 15 
Board in October 2020.  This strategy included an approximately $20  billion  capital 16 
plan over the next 20 years and $10 billion over the next 10 years to reduce carbon, 17 
expand renewables, enhance resiliency and reliability of the transmission grid, and also 18 
to grow non -regulated businesses.  By October 2022, the Board began to serious ly 19 
consider a sale of the Company as a possible path to satisfy its significant capital needs 20 
and address potential financing challenges.   21 
 22 
After continued discussion through March 2023, the Board decided to focus its outreach 23 
to infrastructure and pension funds, because the Board believed that such parties would 24 
have the financial resources to invest in the substantial future capital growth needs while 25 
alternative types of strategic buyers  such as other utilities  could have divergent priorities  26 
which may not be fully aligned with ALLETE’s regulatory goals in Minnesota and 27 
Wisconsin.  Another utility would likely bring its own management team and priorities, 28 
including the policies and goals of other jurisdictions in which it operates.  In contrast, 29 
most pension and infrastructure funds could provide increased access to capital to 30 
enhance infrastructure investment as well as fast -track growth strategies, express a 31 
 
 20 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules  commitment for a long -term hold , and make regulatory commitments, including those 1 
relating to employees and maintenance of existin g headquarters.    2 
 3 
By February 2024, the Board reviewed an updated standalone financing plan that 4 
contemplated billions of dollars of capital expenditures over the next five years that 5 
introduced serial equity and debt issuance s.  By April 2024, the Board identified 6 
standalone financing plan risks including potentially challenging financial markets for 7 
debt offerings and the potential inability to pursue a change of control transaction for a 8 
significant period of time in light of serial equity and debt offerings.  9 
 10 
These observations from the Proxy suggest that private infrastructure investment  is a 11 
good fit  for ALLETE considering its unique circumstances.  12 
 13 
Q. When you served as Chair of the Michigan PSC, did you approve an acquisition of 14 
a Michigan electric utility by private infrastructure  investors?  15 
A. Yes, I did.  My colleagues and I authorized the acquisition of Upper Peninsula Power 16 
Company ( “UPPCO ”) and its holding company by approving a settlement agreement in 17 
Case  No. U -17564 on June 6, 2014  in advance of the 180 -day statutory deadline .  The 18 
application had been filed on March 17, 2014 by the seller, Integrys, and the buyer, 19 
Balfour Beatty Infrastructure Partners.   In our order, we found that there would be no 20 
adverse effect on customer rates or the provision of safe, reliable, and adequate service . 21 
Additionally, we found that subsidization  of a non -regulated activity through customer 22 
rates would not result, and UPPCO’s ability to raise necessary capital and maintain a 23 
reasonable capital structure would not be significantly impaired .  Finally, we found that  24 
the proposed transaction was consistent with the public interest.  25 
 26 
Q. What happened after the Michigan PSC  approval of the 2014 UPPCO transaction?  27 
A. UPPCO maintained its financial health, continued providing safe, reliable, affordable, 28 
and adequate service to its customers, and raised necessary capital while maintaining a 29 
reasonable capital structure.  Balfour Beatty Infrastructure Partners was subsequently 30 
re-named Basalt Infrastruc ture Partners.  31 
 
 21 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules   1 
Q. Did the Michigan PSC  subsequently approve another acquisition of UPPCO and 2 
its holding company by different private infrastructure  investors?  3 
A. Yes, it did, seven years later.  The M ichigan PSC authorized the acquisition of UPPCO 4 
and its holding company by approving a settlement agreement in Case No. U -20995 on 5 
May 26, 2021, again in advance of the 180 -day statutory deadline.  The application had 6 
been filed on February 26, 2021 by the seller, an affiliate of Basalt Infrastructure 7 
Partners, and the buyer, Axium UP Holdings LLC, a Canadian private equity investor.  8 
The M ichigan PSC order found that there was no adverse effect on customer rates or 9 
the provision of safe, reliable, and adequate electric service .  Moreover, subsidization 10 
of a non -regulated activity through customer rates would not result , and UPPCO’s 11 
ability to raise necessary capital and maintain a reasonable capital structure would not 12 
be significantly impaired .  Finally, the Michigan PSC found that  the proposed 13 
transaction was consistent with public policy and the public interest.   Axium continues 14 
to own UPPCO equity through the present.  15 
 16 
Q. What do you see as the downside  if this Acquisition is not approved?  17 
A. ALLETE  would not have access to the plentiful, patient capital that this proposed 18 
Acquisition  would provide  and would most likely revert to  being a serial issuer of its 19 
standalone capital plan in the public equity market, with an outsized capital plan relative 20 
to its size , subject to timing and market volatility constraints.  Proceeding on a 21 
standalone basis  without this proposed private equity transaction  would  heighten the 22 
risk of derailed or delayed  achievement of state policy goals  with negative implications 23 
for customers that count on safe, reliable, affordable, and clean electric utility service .  24 
The likelihood of  ALLETE  finding a subsequent private infrastructure investment 25 
transaction would be significantly diminished if this Acquisition  were not approved.  In 26 
that event, ALLETE  would lose the flexibility and timing benefits of private 27 
infrastructure investment , would have no assurance that a strategic investor would 28 
commit to Minnesota and Wisconsin state policy goals , and would, at minimum, lose 29 
multiple, valuable years of time in pursuing the path to invest in renewables, energy 30 
storage, and enabling transmission  that Minnesota customers desire . 31 
 
 22 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Quackenbush  Direct and Schedules   1 
Q. Do you agree that the proposed Acquisition would improve ALLETE’s access to 2 
capital?  3 
A. Yes, I do.  Accessing patient private infrastructure investment will support ALLETE’s 4 
multi -decade efforts to achieve Minnesota’s policy goals due to its outsized capital need 5 
relative to its si ze and the serial nature of its capital needs.  6 
 7 
IV. CONCLUSION  8 
Q. Please summarize your Direct Testimony  for the Commission’s consideration.  9 
A. Capital market access is important to regulated utilities and is even more important to 10 
ALLETE given its small size and outsized capital spending plan that is necessary to 11 
enable Minnesota Power to achieve Minnesota state policy goals.  The proposed private 12 
equity transaction is an ideal fit for ALLETE’s capital requirements .  Minnesota Power 13 
customers will benefit  from a financially healthy  utility.  Private equity  is uniquely 14 
positioned to support long -term infrastructure investment and enhance ALLETE’s 15 
access to capital and its ability to achieve carbon reduction  standards for 2030, 2035, 16 
and 2040 .   17 
 18 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony ? 19 
A. Yes. 20

Direct Testimony and Schedules  
Ellen Lapson  
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
 
State of Minnesota  
 
 
 
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No . E015/PA -24-198 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
CORPORATE SEPARATENESS AND RING -FENCING  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 12,  2024  
 
 
TABLE OF CONTENTS  
 
  Page  
 
 -i- OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Lapson Direct and Schedules  
 I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS ................................ ................................ .. 2 
II. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  ................................ ................................ ................................  5 
III. THE ACQUISITION  ................................ ................................ ................................ .........  6 
IV. FRAMEWORK FOR EVALUATING CORPORATE SEPARATENESS  ......................  8 
V. EVALUATING ALLETE’S PROTECTION IN THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION  .... 14 
VI. CREDIT RATING REACTIONS  ................................ ................................ ....................  17 
VII. CONCLUSION  ................................ ................................ ................................ ............  19 
 
 2  
  OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Lapson  Direct and Schedules  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and business address.  2 
A. My name is Ellen Lapson  and my business address is 370 Riverside Drive, New York, 3 
NY 10025 . 4 
 5 
Q. By whom are you employed and in what position?  6 
A. I am employed by Lapson Advisory , a division of Trade Resources Analytics, LLC . I 7 
am a Member of the LLC and the Principal of Lapson Advisory , where  I provide 8 
independent advisory  services relating to the financial strength of utilities and 9 
infrastructure companies  and provide  expert testimony  regarding  utility capital market 10 
matters.   11 
 12 
Q. Please summarize your professional qualifications and experience.  13 
A. I am a Chartered Financial Analyst (“CFA”) and earned a Master of Business 14 
Administration from New York University Stern School of Business with a 15 
specialization in Accounting  and Finance .  I have worked in the capital markets space 16 
with a particular focus on financing and analyzing the finances of regulated public 17 
utilities for the past 50 years.  My professional qualifications appear in MP Exhibit ___ 18 
(Lapson ), Direct Schedule  1. 19 
 20 
Q. Have you testified in any other proceeding?  21 
A. Yes, I have testified as an expert financial witness in 64 proceedings before 17 state 22 
public utility commissions and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.  The list of 23 
those proceedings and the topics of my testimony appear in MP Exhibit ___ (Lapson ), 24 
Direct Schedule 1. 25 
 26 
Q. What is the purpose of your Direct Testimony ? 27 
A. The purpose of my Direct Testimony  is first to explain  an analytical  framework for 28 
determining the adequacy and appropriateness of a suite of protective measures 29 
generally known as utility ring-fencing , and then to apply that analytical framework to 30 
evaluate the ring-fencing  measures proposed by the parties in the context of the 31 
 
 3 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Lapson  Direct and Schedules  acquisition by funds managed  by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP 1 
Investments ”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) (together, the  “Partners”) o f 2 
ALLETE, Inc. including its utility division  Minnesota Power  (the “Acquisition”) .1  3 
Finally, I will provide my conclusions about the potential impact of the ring -fencing and 4 
governance commitments proposed in this transaction by the Partners and ALLETE  to 5 
protect the interests of Minnesota Power, its customers, and the communities it serves.  6 
 7 
Q. What is the basis of your expertise concerning protective measures and ring - 8 
fencing in utility merger transactions?  9 
A.  Before found ing Lapson Advisory in January 2012, I was a Senior Director and then a 10 
Managing Director at Fitch Ratings (“Fitch”), one of the three prominent credit rating 11 
agencies in the U.S. market.  My team established and maintained the credit ratings of 12 
investor -owned electric, gas, and water utilities.  In that function, for 17 years  I 13 
performed credit evaluations and supervised other analysts to rate over 100 electric, gas, 14 
and water utilities , entailing the credit rating review of many merger transactions and 15 
reorganization s in the utility sector .  Also, I supervised and wrote the credit rating 16 
methodologies that Fitch  applied in the investor -owned electric, gas, and water sector , 17 
including criteria for utility ring -fencing regarding the effect of corporate structure and 18 
protective mechanisms on the financial viability of subsidiary companies and the 19 
separation of credit ratings within corporate groups.   Finally, I have closely studied the 20 
credit methodologies  of the two other large credit rating agencies , Moody’s Investors 21 
Service (“Moody’s”) and S &P Global Ratings (“S&P”), and in particular their criteria 22 
regarding corporate separateness and ring -fencing protections.  23 
 24 
Prior to joining Fitch, I was employed from 1974 to 1994 in commercial and investment 25 
banking.  As a banker, I structured transactions for regulated utilities, utility holding 26 
companies, and project -financed energy and natural resource projects, which frequently 27 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Direct Testimony and the 
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” i ndicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.

Q. Please summarize your Direct Testimony.   4 
A. I have reviewed the Acquisition that is the subject of the Petition of Minnesota Power 5 
for the Acquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments  and GIP, MPUC Docket 6 
No. E015/PA -24-198 (the “Petition ”). The purpose of my review was  to evaluate 7 
whether the future  integrity and  financial viability of ALLETE , including Minnesota 8 
Power,  may be vulnerable to any harm from the purchasers CPP Investments  and GIP 9 
or any of their related entities and affiliates.   10 
 11 
An important part of this review involves applying a set of systematic and 12 
comprehensive standards reflecting  prior experience regarding the protection of a 13 
company from adversity as a result of its affiliation with a parent or affiliated entities. 14 
This master list incorporates  the guidelines used by law firms and further developed  by 15 
the three major credit rating agencies  over the course of five decades  as well as my own 16 
observations of utilities  and energy companies  in financial distress or bankruptcy.   In 17 
Section IV , I explain the source of the analytical standards applied in this testimony and 18 
why they are effective in insulating a company from adverse consequences relating to 19 
the actions or liabilities of its direct or indirect owners or their affiliates.  20 
 21

structure and ring-fencing provisions proposed in the Acquisition  conform to  these 23 
standards  and will provide ALLET E and Minnesota Power with adequate protection in 24 
all circumstances .   25

IV. FRAMEWORK FOR EVALUATING CORPORATE SEPARATENESS  16 
Q. What do you mean by corporate separateness?  17 
A. I use this terminology to describe a suite of methods used to insulate and protect one 18 
enterprise or business activity from  invasion, contagion, or harm due to mingling with 19 
other related entities.  A more colloquial  term is “ring -fencing .”  20 
 21 
Q.  When and why are ring -fencing protections necessary?   22 
A. Protective ring -fencing methods typically serve one of two purposes.  First, in the 23 
context of corporate finance and corporate structure, ring -fencing mechanisms are used 24 
to protect a company and its stakeholders from financial risks associated with the 25 
company’s parent, affiliated companies, or subsidiaries.7  Another context for ring - 26 
fencing is when a financial sponsor (the seller) bundles together a portfolio of loans or 27 
mortgages and sells them to a shell entity (the purchaser) that finances the purchase by 28 
 
7 In this testimony, the term “corporate” in the context of “corporate structure,” “intercorporate separation,” or 
“corporate group” refers not only to entities structured as corporations but also to partnerships, limited 
partnerships, limited liability com panies (“LLCs”), and related forms of enterprise ownership.   
 
 9 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Lapson  Direct and Schedules  issuing loans or securities backed solely by the value and cash flows of the portfolio 1 
assets.  In the context of banking, leasing, and real estate ownership, such mechanisms 2 
separate the purchaser and its assets from exposure to the bankruptcy risk of the sponsor 3 
or seller of the assets.  This allows the funding of the assets based solely upon the quality 4 
of the asset portfolio, unaffected by the credit of the sponsor or seller.  5 
 6 
In either of these contexts, the purpose of implementing a set of ring -fencing 7 
mechanisms is to safeguard a “Protected Company ” (a business or an asset portfolio) so 8 
that the Protected Company can sustain its viability without interruption or adverse 9 
effects from invasion of its assets by its parent or affiliates or contagion from the 10 
potential financial distress of another entity in its affiliated group .   11 
 12 
Q. What is the purpose of ring -fencing in the utility sector?  13 
A. A utility typically bears a legal obligation to operate reliably and maintain its systems 14 
for existing customers and expand its facilities and systems to accommodate growth of 15 
demand and new  customer s.  Utility  capital expenditures are  generally  not discretionary 16 
but are required to enable  the utility to fulfill its franchise obligations and satisfy the 17 
requirements of the regulatory authority.  Making such capital investments typically 18 
requires access to funding from internal and  external sources.  Thus, it is important for 19 
the utility to retain access to its own resources including its bank accounts, accounts 20 
receivable, and the ability to draw under its credit arrangements, even if its parent or an 21 
affiliate is in financial distress.  If internal sources of cash flow are not sufficient, 22 
utilities need to access funding from the debt market.  Without adequate protection, the 23 
utility’s credit worthiness and access to debt capital could be impaired if its owner is in 24 
financial distress, in default, or bankrupt.  Ring -fencing mechanisms have been 25 
successfully used to protect utilities from risky parents or affiliated companies and have 26 
proven effective in allowing the Protected Companies  to carry out their mandate to serve 27 
present and future customers.  28 
 29

Lapson  Direct and Schedules  Q. Do you have  an established  framework or set of standards for evaluating the 1 
effectiveness of intercorporate separation provisions?  2 
A. Yes.  Over the years, attorneys and credit rating agencies have amassed a great deal of 3 
experience based upon actual case studies of insolvencies. Law firms that work on 4 
securities issu ances and render non -consolidation opinions have in -house standards that 5 
they apply to determine the adequacy of protective ring -fencing, but law firms generally 6 
do not publish their standards.8  Likewise, credit rating agencies have developed their 7 
own standards, drawn from the standards of their legal advisors as well as their own 8 
experiences of corporate defaults , to develop lists of corporate policies and practices 9 
that they apply to determine if two companies with corporate affiliation should be rated 10 
with the same  rating, or if the ratings of the two entities can be separated due to the 11 
presence of protective mechanisms.9   12 
 13 
While law firms’ standards are more narrowly focused on the avoidance of involuntary 14 
consolidation of one company in the bankruptcy of another company, the rating 15 
agencies display a much broader interest in preserving the integrity and financial well - 16 
being of a company from erosion by the involvement of another affiliated company even 17 
in situations that are less dire than bankruptcy.  I have incorporated  lists of standards 18 
published by rating agencies to develop a framework for the systematic evaluation of 19 
provisions that protect an individual company within a corporate group of companies.  20 
 
8 It is possible to infer the in -house standards of a law firm by reading several reasoned non-consolidation opinions 
written by law partners of the firm , but this is not as convenient as referring to the publications of credit rating 
agency methodologies .  Legal journals publish highly detailed articles about specific elements of corporate 
structure or business conduct that bore upon the results of decisions in bankruptcy court, but these are excessively 
detailed and only of interest to practitioners of bank ruptcy law.

Lapson  Direct and Schedules  By combin ing and harmoniz ing the elements that major rating agencies employ in their 1 
separate guidelines , I distilled  a master list of standards for evaluating the adequacy of 2 
intercorporate separation.  The result is the set of protective ring -fencing practices and 3 
policies provided as MP Exhibit ___ ( Lapson), Direct Schedule 2.   4 
 5 
Q.  Please explain the standards that make up this framework.  6 
A.  The master checklist is based on the concept that two types of protection are likely to 7 
safeguard the viability of a Protected Company  from adverse financial consequences 8 
stemming from its parents and affiliates :  9 
I.  Practices that allow the Protected Company to maintain access 10 
to its own physical and financial assets and sources of funding, 11 
shielded from invasion by a parent or affiliate and even despite 12 
the financial distress of its parent or affiliate; and  13 
II.  Practices that eliminate or reduce the risk that the Protected 14 
Company will be drawn into the bankruptcy of its parent or 15 
affiliate.   16 
Therefore , the framework  has two tracks: Track I contains practices that allow 17 
an entity (the Protected Company ) to preserve its own identity, remain viable, fund 18 
itself , resist incurring liabilities unrelated to its own business,  and to defend its own 19 
assets and liabilities even if its parent or an affiliate  of the parent  is in distress ; and Track 20 
II contains practices that protect a company from involuntary consolidation by a 21 
bankruptcy court with its parent or affiliate in the parent or affiliate’s  bankruptcy 22 
proceeding.  Some practices that appear in  Track I are also components  in Track II, 23 
since some practices do double duty, serving to achieve the objectives of both tracks.  24 
 25 
Q. What entity or entities is the Protected Company in this Acquisition ?  26 
A. As the  primary  entity that issues equity and debt and obtains capital for both regulated 27 
and non -regulated functions, ALLETE is the Protected Company .  Minnesota Power is 28 
an operating  division of ALLETE and not a distinct corporate entity. As a division, 29 
Minnesota Power benefits from ring -fencing provisions that are applied to ALLETE.  30 
This is the status quo ante  – that is, the situation prior to the proposed Acquisition, which 31

Minnesota Power customers.  I have observed that  the terms of the Merger Agreement 2 
preserve the same level of protections  (although they may not be in exactly the same 3 
form)  that are present in the pre -existing structure.   4 
 5 
Q. Please explain the elements that make up Track I.  6 
A. Track I includes mechanisms that allow a company within an ownership group to 7 
preserve its independent viability in the event of the financial distress of its parent or 8 
other companies in its group.  Within Track I, there are four types of measures  utilized 9 
by the rating agencies .  These are:  10 
I-A. The Protected Company’s assets are protected from diversion by 11 
having a separate legal identity, separate bank accounts and asset 12 
accounts, with no commingling of assets.  Fixed assets needed to 13 
carry out the business should be in the Protected Company’s own 14 
name.  Transfers of goods, services, and supplies with other 15 
members of the group should be conducted on an arm’s length 16 
basis.   17 
I-B.  The Protected Company can maintain its own access to funding 18 
and to sources of liquidity.  The Protected Company should have 19 
access to a liquidity credit arrangement that is available for 20 
drawing even despite the default of the company’s parent or 21 
affiliated companies.  The default by a parent or affiliate should 22 
not trigger a cross default or cross acceleration of the Protected 23 
Company ’s debt.  If the Protected Company is an accepted issuer 24 
of debt in its own name in the public or private debt market, that 25 
will enhance access to funding, and maintaining a credit rating 26 
also helps to foster that aim.  27 
I-C.    The Protected Company is insulated from the liabilities of its 28 
parent and affiliates of the parent (sister companies) .  It does not 29 
guarantee the debt or obligations of other members of its group, 30 
and the other members of the group never represent to the public 31 
 
 13 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Lapson  Direct and Schedules  or to counterparties that the Protected Company is responsible for 1 
the obligations of other group members.  2 
I-D.  The Protected Company can further protect its viability by 3 
limiting its financial leverage and preserving its individual 4 
solvency.  This is not a requirement for ring -fencing, but it is a 5 
protective element.  6 
 7 
Q. Please explain the elements of Track II.  8 
A.  Track II involves steps to avoid the involuntary consolidation of the Protected Company 9 
in the bankruptcy of its parent or an affiliate.  As I have mentioned already, several of 10 
the practices that are important in Track I to maintain the company’s separate financial 11 
viability also do double duty by helping to avoid involuntary consolidation due to the 12 
doctrine of substantive consolidation.   13 
 14 
Q. What do you mean by substantive consolidation?  15 
 A.  A solvent company within a corporate group might be vulnerable to substantive 16 
consolidation along with its bankrupt parent or affiliate if the resources, assets, and 17 
liabilities of the companies are so commingled and poorly documented that it is difficult 18 
for the bankruptcy court to untangle them.  Another possible cause for substantive 19 
consolidation is if any of the companies in the past represented to creditors that the 20 
assets or cash flow of one company (now solvent) was available to satisfy the debts of 21 
the other company (now insolvent).  When the court finds either of those patterns, then 22 
creditors of the bankrupt company would seek as a remedy the consolidation of the 23 
solvent company in the bankruptcy proceeding to enhance recovery by the bankrupt 24 
entity’s creditors.   25 
 26 
Q. What protections does a company have against substantive consolidation with a 27 
parent or another affiliate of the parent?  28 
A.   Forms of protection against substantive consolidation include : having separate 29 
corporate entities; keeping good books and records ; maintaining separate books of 30 
account ; and not commingling funds or assets .  The Protected Company should not own 31

Lapson  Direct and Schedules  shares of the parent or parent ’s affiliates, nor guarantee the parent’s or parent ’s 1 
affiliates’ debt. Also, neither the Protected Company nor its parent  or affiliates should 2 
represent to creditors of the parent or affiliates that the Protected Company is 3 
responsible for the obligations  of its parent or its parent’s affiliates .   4

 18 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339
