Lapson  Direct and Schedules  in outlook was not based upon structural concerns, but rather upon S&P’s concern that 1 
the Acquisition might be funded with the incurrence of additional debt by ALLETE, 2 
with an adverse effect upon the Company’s key cash flow credit ratio.  The S&P analyst 3 
wrote:  4 
The negative outlook reflects the possibility for higher leverage and 5 
weaker financial measures because of the acquisition. We could lower 6 
our ratings on ALLETE if its leverage increases and its financial 7 
measures weaken such that its funds from operations (FFO) to debt falls 8 
below 17%.  . . . However, if the company ’s post -acquisition capital 9 
structure incorporates a higher level of debt leverage, its consolidated 10 
financial measures could consistently weaken below our downside 11 
trigger [of FFO to debt of 17%]. We will continue to monitor the 12 
regulatory approval process and assess the company ’s planned funding 13 
strategy as it develops.11 14 
 15 
Q. How do you interpret S&P’s reaction to the Company’s announcement of the 16 
Merger Agreement?  17 
A.  It is quite common for credit rating agencies to react quickly to the initial announcement 18 
of a transaction with a negative outlook and statements of concern about the potential 19 
for added debt leverage.  A close reading of S&P’s text does not reveal that S&P had 20 
any doubts about  the nature of the post -Acquisition  corporate structure or the ultimate 21 
protective provisions ; it is abundantly clear that S&P ’s sole concern is ALLETE’s future 22 
debt leverage as measured by the agency’s key cash flow leverage ratio of FFO to Debt.  23 
If the Acquisition  does not result in excessive incremental leverage and assuming there 24 
are no negative developments prior to the closing of the Acquisition , S&P could resolve 25 
its rating for ALLETE by reverting to a Stable  rating outlook.   26 
 27 
Q.  In your view, is the concern that S&P’s analyst expressed regarding excessive 28 
leverage resulting from the Acquisition  still warranted?  29 
A.  No.  The details of the financing arrangements are now known, with no additional  debt 30 
at ALLETE  and a relatively small amount at Alloy Parent.  It appears in retrospect that 31 
S&P’s early fears in April 2024 about excessive acquisition debt have not been borne 32

Lapson  Direct and Schedules  out.  Moody’s reviewed the proposed Acquisition  several months later in July 2024, 1 
perhaps with a preliminary idea of the financing plan, and Moody’s states its view that 2 
the plan is credit neutral.     3 
 4 
VII. CONCLUSION  5 
Q. Please summarize your Direct Testimony  for the Commission’s consideration.  6 
A. Using a systematic framework to assess the ring -fencing and protective  commitments 7 
proposed by the  Partners and ALLETE , I find that the proposed commitments match 8 
up well with the standards for a robust intercorporate separation, as summarized in MP 9 
Exhibit  ___ (Lapson), Direct Schedule 3.  I conclude that the proposed structure and 10 
commitments  will constitute an effective  separation of ALLETE from exposure to the 11 
risks of its parent Alloy Parent and from the Partners (GIP and CPP Investment s) and 12 
from any liabilities or activities of GIP’s and CPP Investments’  other investments and 13 
affiliates.  ALLETE will be able to maintain access to sources of funding and to maintain 14 
control of its own assets and liquidity despite any potential financial distress of its new 15 
corporate parents or their affiliates.   16 
 17 
Furthermore, the normal supervision of the Commission enhance s the effectiveness of 18 
the protective commitments . The Commission’s  regulatory authority and controls (in 19 
such areas as a utility’s transactions with affiliates, transfers of utility assets, and 20 
issuance of debt ) provide assurance to creditors and credit rating agencies of the strength 21 
of the ring -fencing commitments.  22 
   23 
Therefore, I recommend that the Commission accept the commitments proposed by 24 
ALLETE  and the Partners .  25 
 26 
Q. Does this complete your Direct Testimony ? 27 
A. Yes.  28

TRACK I: Preserves Indivdual Viability
I. Viability:  Maintain Separate Assets and Solvency
I-A   Prevent the diversion of Protected Co. assets
a. Is a separate legal entity; maintains its separate name and identity
b. Maintains separate financial accounts in its own name; no commingling of assets.  
c. Protected Company owns all of its physical assets in its own name. 
d. Has policy/procedures to control dividends from Protected Co. 
e. Has policy/procedures to control asset transfers and asset diversion from the Protected 
Company to parent or sister companies. 
f. Assets are not pledged for the benefit of parent or sister companies. 
g. Transfers of assets, services, and supplies between the Protected Company and its parent or 
sister companies are subject to an arm's length standard.
h. Protected Co. does not lend to parent or affiliates
I-B  Access to funding
i. Protected Company has separate 3rd party borrowing sources; has credit ratings in its own 
name. 
j. Protected Company's ability to borrow is not contingent on financial condition of parent or 
affiliates. 
j 1. .. No Cross default / cross acceleration with parent or affiliates
j 2. .. No covenants tied to ratings of parent or affiliates
I-C   Avoid extraneous liabilities
k. Protected Co. does not guarantee the liabilities of affiliates
l. Parent and affiliates do not represent to the public or creditors that the Protected Co. is liable 
for parent or affiliate obligations
m. Not subject to joint tax liability, other than as required by law
n. Avoids excessive debt leverageI-DRing-Fencing Standards

III.    Additional Regulatory Conditions  
headquarters in Duluth, Minnesota ALLETE will continue to maintain  the headquarters of Minnesota Power in Duluth, Minnesota. Pet ition at 18.
Cady Direct at Section IV.

No recovery of Acquisition premium Minnesota Power will not attempt to recover the acquisition premium of the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition from its 
utility customers.Petition at 21. 
Alley Direct at Section IV.
No recovery of transaction costs Minnesota Power will not attempt to recover from its utility customers the costs of executing the transactions contemplated by the 
Acquisition. This includes, among other things, legal fees, goodwill, regulatory filing costs, and other costs historically rec ognized as 
transaction costs. Petition at 21. 
Cady Direct at Section IV.
Anderson Direct at Section VI.
Alley Direct at Section IV.
No recovery of transition costs Minnesota Power will not attempt to recover transition costs, if any, of the transactions conte mplated by the Acquisition from its utility 
customers, except to the extent the transition costs produce savings (and then only when and if such savings materialize).Petition at 22. 
Anderson Direct at Section VI.
Alley Direct at Section IV.
No "push- down accounting" Minnesota Power and the Partners will likewise not deploy “push down accounting” (i.e., adjustment of Minnesota Power’s asset o r 
liability values or books and records to reflect the purchase price) with respect to the Acquisition. Petition at 21.
Anderson Direct at Section VI.
Books and records/reporting transparency Minnesota Power will continue to provide the Commission access to Minnesota Power’s books, records, and information.  
[T]he potentially relevant information available to the Commission post-Acquisition will be substantially similar to what is av ailable 
now. 
Minnesota Power will continue to make all required annual fili ngs with the Commission, including but not limited to annual capi tal 
structure filings and Jurisdictional Annual Reports that provide extensive insight into the ownership, control, and financing o f the 
regulated utility and consolidated ALLETE entity. 
Minnesota Power will also continue to provide additional informat ion in these filings as required by Commission order, includin g its 
current obligation to provide credit rating agency reports.
Though not required by Commission Order, ALLETE will continue to publish its Corporate Sustainability Report, which contains 
information related to environmental, social, and governance issues, including the Company’s efforts to encourage diversity, eq uity, 
and inclusion efforts. 
ALLETE and Parent will provide regulators with appropriate access to ALLETE’s books and records; appropriate access to ALLETE’s  
financial information and filings; access to and audit rights with respect to the documents supporting Parent’s costs that may be 
allocable to ALLETE; and appropriate access to ALLETE’s board minutes, audit reports, and information provided to or by credit rating 
agencies pertaining to ALLETE. Also, Attachment H to the Petition  lists reporting that  the Company will continue to provide. Petition at 20, 22-23.

item 2.

content:
Petition for Intervention International Union of Operating Engineers Local 49 and 
North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters  
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of Allete by Canada Pension 
Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners (24 -198) 
 
The International Union of Operating Engineers Local 49 (“Local 49”) and the North Central 
States Regional Council of Carpenters (“NCSRCC”) hereby jointly petition for intervention as a 
party (“Labor Intervenors”) in Minnesota Public Utility Commission (“C ommission”)  
consideration of the applications by Minnesota Power for a route permit and certificate of need 
for the HVDC modernization project (“Project”).  
Local 49 is a labor organization that represents more than 12,000 construction workers and 
public employees in Minnesota.  Local 49 also represents construction workers and public 
employees in North Dakota and South Dakota.  Local 49’s principal place of b usiness is located 
at 2829 Anthony Lane South in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  
NCSRCC is a labor organization that represents more than 12,000 construction workers in 
Minnesota.  NCSRCC also represents construction workers in North Dakota, South Dakota, 
Iowa, Wisconsin and Nebraska.  NCSRCC’s principal place of business is 700 Olive St. Saint 
Paul, MN 55130.  
In addition to traditional union representation roles (collective bargaining for wages and benefits, 
representing members in disputes with employers, referring members for construction 
employment, etc.) both unions regularly advocate for our member’s inter ests in public policy 
venues.   
Both unions are active participants in Commission proceedings where the outcome could impact 
work opportunities for our members.  Both unions have members who live in Minnesota in the 
service territory of Minnesota Power.  Both unions represent workers who  build, maintain and 
repair portions of Minnesota Power’s energy infrastructure on behalf of union -signatory 
contractors.  Both unions have members  
The acquisition as proposed has a number of potential impacts on both unions and our 
members.  First, corporate policies relating to procurement and labor standards directly impacts 
the economic wellbeing of our membership as it determines whether or not t hey will be able to 
gain work opportunities through the construction and maintenance of Minnesota Power’s energy 
assets.  Second, the ability of a utility to raise the adequate capital to deploy new infrastructure 
will determine whether or not our members will have work opportunities.  The ownership 
structure of the utility has a direct impact on the ease and cost of raising capital.  Third, our 
members who live in Minnesota Power’s service territory are ratepayers and would be impacted 
by any rate changes or conditions that would result from the acquisition.  As such, both unions 
members’ legal rights, duties, and privileges are directly impacted by the disposition of this 
proceeding.   
Both unions seek joint, full party status in the above -captioned docket to protect the rights and 
welfare of our members, families and communities, and to ensure that the outcome of the 
proceeding is consistent with the interest of members and the public.  Both unions have a 
unique interest and expertise that can not be represented in this proceeding by other parties.  
Both unions understand the rights and responsibilities of parties under Minn. R. 1400.7100 and 
are prepared to meet those requirements.  
 
Dated:  11/15/24    Respectfully Submitted,  
Nate Runke, Regulatory and Political Affairs Coordinator
 International Union of Operating Engineers Local 
49 
2829 Anthony Lane South  
     Minneapolis, MN 55418  
 
 
Richard Kolodziejski, Government Affairs Director  
North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters  
700 Olive St.   
     Saint Paul, MN 55130
